Lesson 9





音频



预备测验

找出与句子中划线单词意义最相近的词。

1. Please do not smoke for the duration of the flight.

(A) length

(B) severity

(C) frequency

2. Rotifers（轮虫）are microscopic animals that dwell in quiet waters and live on algae.

(A) reside

(B) feed

(C) rest

3. The drought destroyed the crops in the Southwest of the United States.

(A) dry period

(B) precipitation

(C) locusts

4. Many pure metals have little use because they are too soft, rust too easily or have some other drawback.

(A) property

(B) additive

(C) disadvantage

5. Professor Smith continued his research and disregarded his colleague's advice.

(A) ignored

(B) deplored

(C) explored



第一部分

displace［dɪs'pleɪs］

vt. 移置，转移；取代，替代〈同 move〉

例　The building of a new dam will displace thousands of people who live in this area. 建造一座新的水坝将使数以千计生活在这里的人转移。

联　displacement n. 移置，转移

disposal［dɪ'spəʊzəl］

n. 垃圾倾倒；处置〈同 getting rid of, discarding〉

例　Locals are objecting to the park being used as a disposal site for household waste. 当地人反对将公园用作家庭垃圾的处理场。

联　dispose of 除去，扔掉，解决，处理；disposed adj. 有…倾向的

disposition［ˌdɪspə'zɪʃən］

n. 性情；倾向〈同 temperament, tendency〉

例　His cheerful and kind disposition made him popular. 他开朗和善的性格让他很受欢迎。

联　dispose vt. 布置，安排

disregard［ˌdɪsrɪ'gɑ:d］

n./vt. 不理会；漠视〈同 ignore, take no notice of〉

例　Disregarding the cold weather, we played outside all day. 我们全然不顾寒冷的天气，在外面玩了一整天。

联　disregardful adj. 不顾的，轻视的；regard n./v. 关心，尊敬

disrupt［dɪs'rʌpt］

vt. 使混乱，使中断〈同 upset, interrupt〉

例　A heavy snowfall had disrupted the city's transportation system. 一场暴雪让这座城市的交通陷入瘫痪。

dissipate［'dɪsɪpeɪt］

vi. 消失，消散〈同 disappear, scatter〉

例　Darkness soon dissipated as morning dawned. 破晓时，黑夜被一驱而散。

联　dissipated adj. 放荡的；dissipation n. 消散，挥霍

distill［dɪ'stɪl］

vt. 蒸馏，提取〈同 extract〉

例　A substance is distilled in order to purify it, to separate its liquid parts from its solid parts, or to break it down into separate substances. 蒸馏是为了净化物质，或者将液体从固体中分离出来，又或者是将它分解成分离的物质。

distort［dɪ'stɔ:t］

vt. 弄歪（形状等）；歪曲〈同 deform, twist〉

例　His face was distorted in agony. 他的表情因为痛苦而扭曲。

联　undistorted adj. 未失真的；distortion n. 曲解，歪曲；extort vt. 敲诈，强取；retort v. 反驳；contort v. 扭歪；tortuous adj. 曲折的





distract［dɪ'strækt］

vt. 使…分心，分散（注意力）〈同 disturb〉

例　The noise of traffic outside the classroom may distract the students' focus of attention. 教室外面的交通噪音可能会分散学生们的注意力。

联　distracted adj. 心烦意乱的；distraught adj. 心神错乱的，发狂的；protract vt. 延长；subtract vt. 减去

district［'dɪstrɪkt］

n. 区域，地区〈同 region, area〉

例　Wall Street is in the financial district of New York. 华尔街位于纽约的金融区。

自我检测　从第一部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

6. A quarrelsome person has a ______ to start trouble.

7. Someone has ______ my tools so I cannot find them.

8. The reckless driver was arrested for ______ of the traffic laws.

9. The driver ______ the facts of the accident to escape blame.

10. The naughty student ______ our class every day.

11. Gasoline is ______ from crude oil.



第二部分

disturbance［dɪ'stɜ:bəns］

n. 骚动，动乱〈同 disorder〉

例　The police were called to quieten the disturbance at the street corner. 警察被派去平息街角的骚乱。

联　disturb vt. 打扰，扰乱

diversion［daɪ'vɜ:ʃən; (US)daɪ'vɜ:rʒn］

n. ① 转移，转换〈同 turning aside〉

例　A magician's talk creates a diversion of attention so that people do not see how the tricks are done. 魔术师通过说话来转移观众的注意力，这样观众们就无法看清楚魔术是怎么变的了。

② 消遣，娱乐〈同 recreation〉

例　After studying for several hours, he needed a diversion from work. 在学习了几个小时之后，他需要停下来放松一会儿。

divert［daɪ'vɜ:t］

v. 转移，（使）转向〈同 distract〉

例　Traffic will be diverted through the side streets while the main road is resurfaced. 交通将从支路改道，同时主路会重新铺设。

divine［dɪ'vaɪn］

adj. 上帝的，神性的；神圣的〈同 holy〉

例　The Bible describes the creation of the world as a divine act.《圣经》将创造世界描述成神的行为。

记　div（神）+ ine → 神圣的；参考：divinity（神性）

联　divinity n. 神，神性；vine n. 葡萄藤

divorce［dɪ'vɔ:s］

v. ① 离婚

例　They divorced after ten years of marriage. 在经历了十年的婚姻之后，他们离婚了。

② 脱离〈同 separate〉

例　Economics cannot be divorced from politics. 经济无法与政治脱离关系。





dizzy［'dɪzi］

adj. 眩晕的〈同 light-headed〉

例　When you spin round and round and stop suddenly, you feel dizzy. 当你转了一圈又一圈然后突然停下来的时候，你会感到眩晕。

记　dizz（转）+ y → 转得多的 → 眩晕的

联　dizziness n. 头昏眼花，眩晕；fuzzy adj. 毛茸茸的，模糊的

dock［dɒk］

n. 码头，船坞

例　Ships load and unload beside a dock. 轮船在码头旁装卸货物。

doctrine［'dɒktrɪn］

n. 教义，教旨〈同 principle〉

例　The cult members obeyed their leader's doctrines. 信徒遵循他们教会首领的教义。

联　doctor n. 医生，博士；doctoral adj. 博士的；doctrinaire n. 教条主义者；doctrinairism n. 教条主义，空论；docile adj. 听话的，温顺的

domain［dəʊ'meɪn］

n. 领域，范围〈同 field〉

例　This valley is the domain of our people. Nobody can enter it without our permission. 这座山谷是我们的地盘，任何人未经允许不得入内。

记　dom（屋，家）+ ain → 自家的领土 → 领域

dome［dəʊm］

n. 圆屋顶〈同 vault〉

例　The new baseball stadium is covered by a dome. 新的棒球场由穹形顶覆盖。

自我检测　从第二部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

12. It was once thought in Japan that the emperor ruled by ______ right.

13. As a selfish saleswoman, she treated the business and customers' information as her private ______.

14. In the United States, government and religion are completely ______.

15. The principal investigated the ______ in the school cafeteria—two groups of boys were fighting!

16. Tie your boat at the ______ when you arrive.

17. A ditch ______ water from the stream into the fields.



第三部分

donate［dəʊ'neɪt; (US)'dəʊˌneɪt］

vt. 捐赠〈同 grant, contribute〉

例　Susan asked her lawyer to donate all her possessions to charity after her death. 苏珊要求她的律师在她去世后，把她所有的财产捐给慈善机构。

联　donation n. 捐赠，捐款；donor n. 捐助者

doom［du:m］

vt. 注定〈同 destine〉

例　The prisoner sentenced to death was doomed to be killed. 被判死刑的犯人注定会被处死。

drag［dræg］

vt. 拖动〈同 pull, haul〉

例　The woodcutter dragged the heavy fallen tree to the roadside. 樵夫将倒下的、沉重的树拖到了路边。





drainage［'dreɪnɪʤ］

n. 排水；排出物

例　The drainage of swamps improved the land. 把沼泽的水排掉提高了土地质量。

记　来自 drain（排水）

dramatic［drə'mætɪk］

adj. 戏剧性的；引人注目的〈同 striking〉

例　Shaving off his beard created a dramatic change in his appearance. 他把胡子刮掉之后，相貌发生了戏剧性的改变。

联　dramatize v. 改编成为戏剧，编写剧本

drastic［'dræstɪk］

adj. 激烈的，猛烈的〈同 radical, severe〉

例　NATO threatened more drastic action if its terms were not met. 北约威胁如果不履行条款，将采取更为激烈的措施。

联　drastically adv. 大大地

drawback［'drɔ:bæk］

n. 弊端，缺点〈同 disadvantage〉

例　The drawback to working the morning shift is having to get up early. 上早班的弊端就是你必须早早起床。

联　withdraw v. 撤回；drawer n. 抽屉

dread［dred］

n. 畏惧，恐怖〈同 fear, terror〉

例　The prospect of meeting her boyfriend's relatives filled Janet with dread. 珍妮特一想到要与她男朋友的亲属见面，就感到十分恐惧。

联　dreadful adj. 可怕的

drill［drɪl］

vt. 钻孔，打眼〈同 bore〉

例　Bob drills an opening in the door for the lock. 鲍勃为了给门装锁，把门钻了一个开口。

n./vi. 训练，操练；反复练习〈同 instruct, train〉

例　He drilled the children in what they should say. 他训练孩子们学会该说什么话。

联　grill v. 烤，拷问 n. 烤架

drought［draʊt］

n. 干旱〈同 dry period〉

例　The water level in the reservoirs was low because of the long drought. 由于长期干旱，水库里的水位变得很低。

自我检测　从第三部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

18. A ______ of three months during the summer caused the brooks and streams to dry up.

19. Our trip was interesting but the rainy weather was a ______.

20. A team of horses ______ the big log out of the forest.

21. My parents ______ some old furniture for the school rummage sale（捐赠物义卖）.

22. The police took ______ measures to put a stop to the wave of robberies.

23. A carpenter ______ several holes in the board.



第四部分

dual［'dju:əl; (US)'du:əl］

adj. 双的；双重的〈同 twofold〉

例　The driving school's cars had dual controls; one set for the learner and one for the teacher. 驾校的汽车有两套控制系统，一套为学员而设，一套为教练而设。

dubious［'dju:bɪəs; (US)'du:bɪəs］

adj. 可疑的；怀疑的，不确定的〈同 questionable, uncertain〉

例　The senator was dubious about his chances of reelection because of the scandal. 由于丑闻，参议员对他改选获胜的机会持怀疑态度。

记　dub（二，双）+ ious → 在两种状态间游移的 → 不肯定的 → 怀疑的

联　dubiety n. 怀疑，可疑的东西

duplicate

［'dju:plɪkeɪt; (US)'du:pləkeɪt］vt. 复写，复制〈同 copy, reproduce〉

例　Duplicate the picture so that we may both have a copy of it. 把照片复制下来，这样我们俩都会留一份。

［'dju:plɪkət; (US)'du:plɪkət］adj. 两重的，两倍的；完全相同的〈同 double, identical〉

例　A human being has duplicate lungs but only one heart. 人有两片肺，但是只有一个心脏。

记　du + plic（重叠）+ ate → 使重叠 → 复制

联　replicate vt. 复制；complicate vt. 使变复杂

duration［djʊə'reɪʃən; (US)dʊ'reɪʃn］

n. 持续的时间〈同 length, period〉

例　The duration of the examination is three hours. 考试时间是三个小时。

dwell［dwel］

vi. 居住，生活于〈同 reside〉

例　Janet dwells in Harbin. 珍妮特住在哈尔滨。

联　dweller n. 居住者，居民；dwelling n. 住处，寓所；swell v.（使）膨胀，（使）增大；swill vi. 涮，冲洗





earnings［'ɜ:nɪŋz］

n. 所得，收入〈同 income〉

例　My earnings for the job weren't as high as I expected. 这份工作的收入没有我期望的高。

ease［i:z］

n. 安逸；悠闲〈同 easiness, leisure〉

例　The reporter writes with great ease, because he is good at writing and did a lot of research on this topic. 因为这位记者十分擅长写作，并且对这个选题做了很多研究，所以他写起来很轻松。

eccentric［ɪk'sentrɪk］

adj./n. 古怪的（人），异常的（人）〈同 strange, odd〉

例　If you go to the palace in tennis shoes, they'll think you're rather eccentric. 如果你穿着网球鞋去王宫，他们会觉得你十分古怪。

记　ec（出）+ centr（中心）+ ic → 离开中心的 → 古怪的

联　eccentricity n. 反常，怪癖；acentric adj. 无中心的；concentric adj. 同心的；egocentric adj. 以自我为中心的

eclipse［ɪ'klɪps］

n. 日食，月食

例　There will be a lunar eclipse tonight. 今晚会有月食。

vt. 盖过，使失色；遮蔽〈同 shadow〉

例　She is completely eclipsed by her sister, who is cleverer, prettier and more amusing. 她在她妹妹面前黯然失色。她的妹妹比她更聪明、更漂亮、更迷人。

ecology［ɪ'kɒləʤi］

n. 生态（学）；生态平衡

例　The oil spill caused terrible damage to the fragile ecology of the coastline. 石油泄漏给脆弱的沿海生态环境造成了严重的破坏。

联　ecologist n. 生态学者；ecological adj. 生态的，生态学的

27. ______ is a branch of biology that deals with the relation of living things to their environment and to each other.

29. Her ______ habits made her friends feel uncomfortable.

Lesson 10





音频



预备测验

找出与句子中划线单词意义最相近的词。

1. The professor elicited a loud groan from his students with his difficult assignment.

(A) eluded

(B) heard

(C) drew out

2. Plays that entail direct interaction between actor and audience present no unusual difficulties for actors.

(A) advocate

(B) involve

(C) elicit

3. The Industrial Revolution marked the beginning of an epoch of exodus（大批的离去）from rural areas to cities.

(A) episode

(B) period

(C) migration

4. The number of United States citizens who are eligible to vote continues to increase.

(A) encouraged

(B) enforced

(C) entitled

5. Abolitionist Frederick Douglass' eloquent speeches helped him achieve great success.

(A) rigorous

(B) persuasive

(C) familiar



第一部分

edge［eʤ］

n. 边缘〈同 brink〉

例　John is at the edge of death. 约翰处于死亡的边缘。

edible［'edəbəl］

adj. 可食用的〈同 eatable〉

例　Laurels are valued for their aromatic oils and spices, edible fruits and timber. 月桂树的价值在于能提供芳香油、香料、可食用的果实以及木料。

记　ed（= eat 吃）+ ible → 可食用的

effective［ɪ'fektɪv］

adj. 有效的；生效的〈同 efficient, productive〉

例　Sharing corporate stocks with employees can be an effective way to promote harmony, efficiency and equitability in the workplace. 让员工入股可以有效地提高职场的和谐、效率和公平的程度。

记　effect（效果）+ ive → 有效的

联　effect vt. 实施 n. 效果；effectiveness n. 效力；effectual adj. 有效的；affective adj. 情感的，表达感情的；disaffected adj. 不满的

eject［ɪ'ʤekt］

vt. ① 逐出，驱逐〈同 expel〉

例　The hooligans were ejected from the restaurant. 小流氓被赶出了餐厅。

② 喷出，喷射〈同 discharge〉

例　Ants eject formic acid when another insect tries to attack them. 当被其他昆虫攻击的时候，蚂蚁就会释放出蚁酸。

记　e + ject（推）→ 推出 → 逐出

联　abject adj. 卑鄙的，可怜的；dejected adj. 沮丧的

elapse［ɪ'læps］

vi.（时间）过去，消逝〈同 slip away, pass〉

例　Many hours elapsed while I slept. 我睡了好多个小时。

elderly［'eldəli］

adj. 过了中年的；近老年的；稍老的〈同 old〉

例　The elderly woman lives with her grandson. 老妇人和她的孙子一起生活。





elevate［'elɪveɪt］

vt. 举起；抬高；使上升〈同 raise〉

例　The marchers elevated the flag as they passed the president. 从总统身边走过的时候，游行者举起了旗帜。

联　elevation n. 高度，海拔；elevator n. 电梯，起重机

elicit［ɪ'lɪsɪt］

vt. 得出；引出〈同 draw forth〉

例　The comedian's joke elicited laughter from the audience. 喜剧演员的笑话逗得观众哈哈大笑。

记　e（出）+ licit（引导）→ 引出

联　illicit adj. 违法的

eligible［'elɪʤəbəl］

adj. 合格的，有资格的〈同 qualified〉

例　Only native-born citizens are eligible for the office of President. 只有本国公民才有资格当总统。

记　e + lig（选）+ ible → 选出来的 → 合格的

联　ineligible adj. 不合格的；legible adj. 清晰的，易读的；negligible adj. 可以忽略的，不予重视的

elite［eɪ'li:t］

n. 精英，中坚分子

例　Only the elites attended the reception for the visiting queen. 只有社会精英们参加了女王访问招待会。

记　e + lite（= lig 选择）→ 选出来的 → 精英

联　elitism n. 精英论

自我检测　从第一部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

6. The stage was ______ to allow a clear view for the spectators.

7. Pupils had to pass all subjects to be ______ for graduation.

8. The volcano ______ lava and ashes.

9. The old man lived in a little shack（小室）on the ______ of the town.

10. Four years have ______ since Janet left business school and now she is a successful businesswoman.

11. His rude remarks only served to ______ boos（嘘声）from the crowd.



第二部分

eloquent［'eləkwənt］

adj. 善于表达的，有口才的，雄辩的〈同 persuasive〉

例　Janet is an eloquent speaker and good at business negotiation. 珍妮特口才很好，擅长商业谈判。

记　e + loqu（说话）+ ent → 能说出来的 → 有口才的

联　eloquence n. 雄辩，口才；elocution n. 雄辩术，演说法；soliloquy n. 独白，自言自语；loquacious adj. 多话的，饶舌的

embark［ɪm'bɑ:k］

v. ①（使）上船（或飞机）〈同 board〉

例　The ship will leave soon and all passengers must embark in ten minutes. 船马上就要起航了，所有乘客务必在十分钟内登船。

②（使）着手，（使）开始〈同 start〉

例　After leaving college, Janet embarked upon a business career. 离开大学之后，珍妮特开始了商业生涯。

记　em（= in）+ bark（三桅船）→ 进到船里 →（使）上船（或飞机）

联　embargo n./vt. 禁止，禁运；embarrass vt. 使困窘

embassy［'embəsi］

n. 大使馆〈同 consulate〉

例　While traveling abroad we had to go to the Chinese embassy to resolve the emergency. 在境外旅行遇到紧急情况时，我们不得不去中国大使馆寻求帮助。

embed［ɪm'bed］

vt. 插入；镶嵌〈同 encase〉

例　Small stones were embedded in the ice. 小石子嵌入了冰块里。

联　embellish v. 修饰；embezzle vt. 盗用，挪用

embody［ɪm'bɒdi］

vt. 使具体化；包含，收录〈同 express, include〉

例　My grandmother embodies all the qualities of her generation. 我的祖母体现了她这一代人所具有的所有素质。

记　em + body（身体）→（思想）变成身体 → 使具体化

联　antibody n. 抗体；melody n. 旋律，歌曲

emigrate［'emɪgreɪt］

vi. 移居他国

例　Her family emigrated to America in the 1850s. 在19世纪50年代，她们家移居到了美国。

联　migrate v.（使）移居，迁徙；immigrate v.（使）移居入境

emission［ɪ'mɪʃən］

n. 散发；发射〈同 radiation, discharge〉

例　An emission of smoke showed that there was a fire in the house. 有烟冒出来说明房子起火了。

记　来自 emit（发出），e（出来）+ mit（送）→ 送出 → 发出

联　emit vt. 发出；remission n. 宽恕，赦免





empirical［em'pɪrɪkəl］

adj. 以实际经验为依据的〈同 experimental〉

例　This theory needed to be backed up with solid empirical evidence. 这个理论需要可靠的实验来证明。

记　来自 empiric，原指单凭经验行医的医生

联　empire n. 帝国

encourage［ɪn'kʌrɪʤ］

vt. 鼓励，支持〈同 stimulate〉

例　The coach encourages Jimmy to practice more often. 教练鼓励吉米再多加练习。

联　courage n. 勇气，精神；outrage n. 暴行，愤怒；disparage vt. 蔑视，贬损；mirage n. 海市蜃楼，幻想

endanger［ɪn'deɪnʤə(r)］

vt. 危及；危害〈同 threaten, jeopardize〉

例　Drinking endangers one's liver. 饮酒对肝脏有害。

联　endangered adj.（生命等）有灭绝危险的，将要绝种的

自我检测　从第二部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

12. Precious stones are often found ______ in rock.

13. The storm ______ many lives.

14. ______ from the coal-fired power plant exceeded federal pollution standards.

15. My father will ______ for America at noon tomorrow and I will see him off at the airport then.

16. A building ______ the idea of an architect.

17. Chemistry is largely an ______ science.



第三部分

endeavor［ɪn'devə(r)］

n./vi. 尝试，努力〈同 effort, try〉

例　No matter how much he endeavors to move it, the stone remains in its place. 无论他怎么努力去搬，这块石头就是纹丝不动。

记　en（放进）+ deavor（责任）→ 放进责任 → 尝试，努力

endow［ɪn'daʊ］

vt. ① 捐赠〈同 grant〉

例　Graduates endowed their colleges with funds to support their operation. 毕业生们给母校捐款，支持学校运营。

② 赋予

例　Nature not only gave the Middle Atlantic region fine harbors, but also endowed it with a first-class system of inland waterways. 大自然不仅给予大西洋中部地区优良的海港，也赋予其一流的内陆水运系统。

联　endowment n. 禀赋，捐款

endurance［ɪn'djʊərəns］

n. 忍耐（力），持久（力）〈同 perseverance, stamina〉

例　Triathlon athletes must have incredible endurance. 铁人三项运动员必须具有惊人的耐力。

energetic［ˌenə'ʤetɪk］

adj. 精力充沛的；积极的〈同 active〉

例　The energetic athlete runs 5 miles every day. 那位精力充沛的运动员每天跑5英里。

记　en + erg（能量，活力）+ y + etic → 精力充沛的

联　energize v.（使）活跃，给予精力；enervate vt. 使失去精力





enforce［ɪn'fɔ:s］

vt. ① 强制服从或遵守；实施，执行〈同 execute〉

例　The police enforce the law. 警察执行法律。

② 坚持（主张等）；加强（论点等）〈同 compel〉

例　The speed limit is strongly enforced in this state. 这个国家严格执行限速规定。

enlighten［ɪn'laɪtən］

vt. 启发，启蒙〈同 educate〉

例　The book enlightened me on the subject of medicine. 这本书在医药方面启发了我。

记　en + light（光）+ en →（使）进入有光的状态 → 启发

联　enlightenment n. 启迪，教化

enrich［ɪn'rɪtʃ］

vt. 加料于（食物）；使富足，使肥沃〈同 make rich, improve〉

例　I shall try to enrich my knowledge of the English language during this summer vacation. 我会在这个暑假扩充英语知识量。

记　en + rich（富足）→ 使富足

enrol(l)［ɪn'rəʊl］

vi. 参军；注册〈同 enlist, register〉

例　We must enroll in school on Friday. 我们必须在周五注册学籍。

ensue［ɪn'sju:; (US)ɪn'su:］

vi. 接着发生，因而产生〈同 follow〉

例　Soldiers began firing at each other and a gun battle ensued. 士兵们开始互相射击，继而发生了一场枪战。

联　ensuing adj. 接着发生的；sue v. 控告；（向…）请求

ensure［ɪn'ʃʊə(r)］

vt. 保证，担保〈同 insure〉

例　Your term paper is good enough to ensure a passing grade. 你的学期报告很优秀，一定能及格。

自我检测　从第三部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

18. He didn't know he had to pay his rent in advance until I ______ him.

19. The extra lessons ______ him a good score on the examination.

20. The farmer ______ his field with fertilizers.

21. Our discussion became heated, and an argument ______.

22. The rich philanthropist（慈善家）______ the school with a lot of money.

23. We have laws to ______ the payment of income taxes.



第四部分

entail［ɪn'teɪl］

vt. 使成为必要，使承担；使…发生〈同 involve〉

例　Owning an automobile entailed greater expense than we had expected. 拥有一辆汽车必须承担超过我们预期的开支。

记　en + tail（尾巴）→ 给…加上尾巴 → 使承担

联　detail n. 细节，详情 vt. 详述，细说；retail v. 零售

entertainment［ˌentə'teɪnmənt］

n. 娱乐；款待〈同 amusement〉

例　The monkeys at the zoo provided the children with a lot of entertainment. 动物园里的猴子给孩子们带来了很多欢乐。





entity［'entɪti］

n. 实体

例　England, Scotland and Wales are all parts of Great Britain but each is also a separate entity. 英格兰、苏格兰和威尔士都属于英国，但是它们每一个都是独立体。

联　entitle vt. 给…权利（或资格）；给…题名；entitled adj. 有资格的

entrepreneur［ˌɒntrəprə'nɜ:(r)］

n. 企业家，创业人〈同 businessperson〉

例　The intrepid entrepreneur transformed the town into a thriving shopping area. 那位强悍的企业家把这个城镇变成了繁华的商业中心。

envelop［ɪn'veləp］

vt. 把…包住，裹住〈同 enclose, encase〉

例　The mountains were enveloped in sunlight. 群山笼罩在阳光里。

记　en（放进）+ velop（包）→ 把…包住

envisage［ɪn'vɪzɪʤ］

vt. 设想，预见

例　The architect looked at the plans and envisaged the finished house. 建筑师看着设计图，想像房子建成以后的样子。

联　envy n./vt. 羡慕，嫉妒

epidemic［ˌepɪ'demɪk］

n. 传染病，流行病〈同 plague〉

例　There are epidemics of influenza nearly every winter. 几乎每个冬天都有流感。

episode［'epɪsəʊd］

n. 一段情节；【音】插曲

例　He told me about an episode in the war. 他给我讲了战争时期的一个故事。

epoch［'i:pɒk］

n. 新纪元，时代〈同 period of time, era〉

例　The glacial epoch lasted for thousands of years. 冰河期持续了数千年。

equilibrium［ˌi:kwɪ'lɪbrɪəm］

n. 平衡，均衡〈同 balance〉

例　The acrobat in the circus maintained equilibrium on a tightrope. 杂技团的演员在拉紧的绳索上保持平衡。

联　equate vt. 使相等 vi. 等同；equator n. 赤道

25. Being named the best athlete of the year was an important ______ in the baseball player's life.

26. Scales are in ______ when the weights on each side are equal.

27. Persons, mountains, languages and beliefs are distinct ______.

28. An ______ of measles broke out in our summer camp.

29. The overcoat（外套，大衣）completely ______ my little sister.

Lesson 11





音频



预备测验

找出与句子中划线单词意义最相近的词。

1. Eventually the proportion of people of working age will decline.

(A) Ultimately

(B) Actually

(C) Definitely

2. Exposure to excessive amounts of noise can cause hearing loss.

(A) high pitched

(B) constant

(C) extreme

3. Although barbers now restrict their services to cutting and styling hair, their predecessors used to extract teeth as well.

(A) clean

(B) remove

(C) drill

4. Mount St. Helens erupted in March 1980 after 123 years of silence.

(A) exploded

(B) split

(C) roared

5. Feudal society（封建社会）depended on the existence of faithful vassals（诸侯）.

(A) diligent

(B) gullible

(C) loyal



第一部分

erosion［ɪ'rəʊʒən］

n. 腐蚀，侵蚀〈同 corrosion〉

例　The disintegration of the stone wall was caused by erosion. 石墙由于腐蚀作用而瓦解。

联　erode v.（受）腐蚀，（受）侵蚀；erosive adj. 侵蚀性的，腐蚀性的；corrode v.（受）腐蚀，（受）侵蚀

erroneous［ɪ'rəʊnɪəs］

adj. 错误的〈同 wrong〉

例　Janet held the erroneous belief that the more the goods cost the better they must be. 珍妮特错误地认为价格越贵，商品越好。

记　err（错误，谬误）+ oneous → 错误的

联　error n. 错误；errant adj. 周游的，犯错的

erupt［ɪ'rʌpt］

vi. 喷出，爆发〈同 explode〉

例　Steam erupted from the broken pipe. 蒸汽从破损的管道里喷发出来。

联　eruption n. 爆发，喷发；corrupt adj. 腐败的；rupture n./v.（使）破裂，断绝（关系等）；bankrupt adj. 破产的

escort［'eskɔ:t］

n. 护卫（队）；护送，陪同（人员）〈同 guard〉

例　The Prime Minister's car has a police escort. 总理的车有警察护卫。

essence［'esns］

n. 本质，要素；精髓，精华〈同 nature, substance〉

例　Being thoughtful of others is the essence of politeness. 为别人考虑是礼貌的本质。

联　essential adj. 本质的，实质的，基本的，精华的

eternal［ɪ'tɜ:nəl］

adj. 永恒的；永远的〈同 forever, everlasting〉

例　Not only do the tides advance and retreat in their eternal rhythms, but the surface of the sea itself is never at rest. 不仅是潮涨潮落有其本身永恒的规律，而且海平面也从来都不是静止的。

记　etern（时间，岁月）+ al → 永恒的

联　eternity n. 永远，来世；external adj. 外部的

ethics［'eθɪks］

n. 伦理学；道德规范〈同 morals, principles〉

例　Ethics is the branch of philosophy that deals with the values of life in a coherent, systematic and scientific manner. 伦理学是哲学的分支，其对生命价值的探讨具有连贯性、系统性以及科学性。

联　ethical adj. 道德的，伦理的

ethnic［'eθnɪk］

adj. 种族的〈同 racial〉

例　The city's population includes a wide range of different ethnic groups. 城市的人口包括许多不同的种族。

联　ethnics n. 伦理学；人种学；ethnology n. 民族学





eventually［ɪ'ventjʊəli］

adv. 终于〈同 ultimately, finally〉

例　We eventually arrived home after a long and tiring journey. 在经历了漫长而劳累的旅行之后，我们终于到家了。

everlasting［ˌevə'lɑ:stɪŋ］

adj. 永久的，永恒的；无止境的

例　We wished them everlasting happiness. 我们祝他们永远幸福。

记　ever + lasting（持久的）→ 在任何时候都持久的 → 永恒的

联　lasting adj. 持久的，耐久的

6. The ______ of the rock singer's appeal is his boyish（少年的，孩子气的）looks.

7. Years ago many people held the ______ belief that the earth was flat.

8. Romeo and Juliet pledged ______ love to each other.

9. There are many ______ groups in our large country.

10. The queen's ______ walked with her to the carriage（马车；客车).

11. ______ reduced the once mighty boulder to a tiny nubbin(小片）.



第二部分

evidence［'evɪdəns］

vt. 证明；表明，显示〈同 reveal, indicate〉

例　The volcano is still active, as evidenced by the recent eruption. 这座火山仍然活跃，最近的喷发就证明了这一点。

n. 证据〈同 proof〉

例　Is there any scientific evidence that a person's character is reflected in their handwriting? 有科学证据表明，笔迹能反映一个人的性格吗？

联　evident adj. 明显的

evoke［ɪ'vəʊk］

vt. 引起，激起，唤起〈同 bring out, arouse〉

例　This fragrance evokes the memory of a cool summer evening. 这种芳香唤起了我对一个凉爽夏夜的回忆。

记　e + voke（喊）→ 喊出来 → 唤起

联　provoke vt. 惹怒；revoke vt. 取消；invoke vt. 乞求，恳求；convoke vt. 召集（开会）

exception［ɪk'sepʃən］

n. 例外

例　Everyone passed the math test, with the exception of Tom. 除了汤姆之外，所有人都通过了数学考试。

exceptional［ɪk'sepʃənəl］

adj. 异常的；杰出的〈同 extraordinary, unusual〉

例　The exceptional tennis player won the championship. 这个杰出的网球选手赢得了冠军。

记　ex（出）+ cept（拿）+ ion + al → 异常的；杰出的





excessive［ɪk'sesɪv］

adj. 过度的，过分的，过多的〈同 extreme, too much〉

例　You must curb your excessive spending, or you will become penniless. 你必须控制你的过度消费，否则你会变得身无分文。

记　ex + cess（走）+ ive → 走出去的 → 过分的

联　excess n. 过度；access n. 接近，入口；recessive adj. 隐性遗传的，后退的

exclusive［ɪk'sklu:sɪv］

adj. 单独的，唯一的，排外的〈同 single, sole〉

例　A patent gives inventors exclusive rights to their inventions for a fixed period of time. 专利赋予发明人在特定的时期内对该项发明的独占权。

记　ex + clus（关闭）+ ive → 关出去的 → 排外的

联　exclusively adv. 完全地，仅仅；exclude vt. 排除；inclusive adj. 包含的，包括的；elusive adj. 难懂的，易忘的

execution［ˌeksɪ'kju:ʃən］

n. 实施，执行；完成〈同 putting into practice〉

例　The committee is planning carefully for the execution of the project. 委员会仔细地为执行该项计划而进行规划。

联　execute v. 执行，完成，实行；executioner n. 死刑执行人，刽子手；executive adj. 执行的，行政的 n. 经理，主管人员；excursion n. 远足

exemplify［ɪg'zemplɪfaɪ］

vt. 例证；作为…的例子〈同 illustrate〉

例　This building exemplifies the architect's dedication and hard work. 这座建筑是建筑师无私奉献和辛苦工作的例证。

联　example n. 例子；exemplary adj. 可仿效的，可做模范的

exempt［ɪg'zempt］

vt. 使免除，豁免（from）〈同 immune〉

例　His lame leg exempted him from military service. 他因为瘸腿而被免除兵役。

记　ex + empt（拿，买）→ 拿出去 → 使免除

联　exemption n. 免除；preempt v. 抢先占有；tempt vt. 引诱

exile［'eksaɪl; 'egsaɪl］

vt. 放逐，流放〈同 expel〉

例　The deposed leaders were exiled to a neighboring country. 这几位被罢免的首领被流放到邻国。

记　ex（出）+ il（无目的地游荡）+ e → 出去无目的地游荡 → 放逐

联　exit n. 出口；expatriate v. 逐出国外 n. 亡命国外者

12. The speaker's witty remarks ______ many smiles from the audience.

13. Although the original idea was good, its ______ has produced a disappointing result.

14. Her conduct ______ the high standards we should all maintain.

15. His attempted escape is ______ of his guilt.

16. In business school, students who get an A on this homework are ______ from final examinations.

17. It is hard to get admitted to an ______ club.



第三部分

exotic［ɪg'zɒtɪk］

adj. 异国的，外来的；奇异的〈同 foreign, unusual〉

例　We saw many exotic plants at the flower show; some of them were seen for the first time by the local people. 我们在花展上看到了很多外来植物，有些是本地人第一次看到的。

记　exo（外面）+ tic → 外来的

联　erotic adj. 性爱的，色情的；quixotic adj. 堂吉诃德式的，空想的

expedition［ˌekspɪ'dɪʃən］

n. 远征；探险队〈同 journey〉

例　The explorers started on a year-long expedition down the Nile. 探险家们沿尼罗河而下，开始了为期一年的探险。

联　expeditionary adj. 远征的；expedient adj. 方便的，有利的；expediency n. 方便，便利，权宜之计

expel［ɪk'spel］

vt. 驱逐，开除；排出〈同 oust, discharge〉

例　When we exhale we expel air from our lungs. 当我们呼气的时候，肺将空气排出体外。





expend［ɪk'spend］

vt. 花费；用光（精力、时间、体力等）〈同 spend〉

例　He expended thought, work and money on this big project. 这个重要工程使他费尽心思、精力和金钱。

联　expense n. 费用，代价，开支；expenditure n. 支出，花费；expensive adj. 花费的，昂贵的

expertise［ˌekspɜ:'ti:z］

n. 专门技术、技能〈同 skill〉

例　Because of his expertise in analysis, John was hired as a consultant. 由于约翰有分析的专门技术，他被聘为顾问。

记　expert（专家）+ ise → 专家知识 → 专门技术、技能

expire［ɪk'spaɪə(r)］

vi. ① 期满，到期〈同 end〉

例　My driver's license will expire next month and I have to renew it. 我的驾照下个月就要到期了，我必须更新。

② 呼气〈同 exhale〉

例　Air is expired from the lungs. 空气从肺部排出来。

explicit［ɪk'splɪsɪt］

adj. 明确的，清楚的〈同 clear〉

例　Your remarks are explicit; no one can misinterpret them. 你的评论很清楚，没人会误解。

联　explicitly adv. 明确地，明白地；implicit adj. 暗示的，含蓄的

exposition［ˌekspə'zɪʃən］

n. 博览会，展览会〈同 exhibition〉

例　A world's fair with exhibits from many countries is an exposition. 展品来自世界各国的展览称为博览会。

记　ex + pos（放）+ ition → 放出来（让人看）→ 博览会

联　expose vt. 暴露，揭露，使曝光；exposure n. 暴露，揭露，曝光

exquisite［ɪk'skwɪzɪt］

adj. 优美的，精致的，高雅的〈同 delicate, elegant〉

例　I've just bought an exquisite piece of china. 我刚买了一件精美的瓷器。

记　ex + quisit（要求，寻求）+ e → 按要求（做出来）的 → 精致的

联　requisite adj. 必要的 n. 必需品；prerequisite n. 先决条件；perquisite n. 额外补贴，津贴

extension［ɪk'stenʃən］

n. 延长，扩充；增加的部分〈同 supplement, expansion〉

例　The handle isn't long enough; I need an extension. 手柄不够长，我需要延长它。

自我检测　从第三部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

18. He has received a six-month ______ on the deadline for his book writing.

19. She gave such ______ directions that everyone understood them.

20. In 1856, Sir Richard Burton led an ______ to discover the source of the Nile River.

21. She ______ too much energy for such a small profit.

22. You must obtain a new permission when the old one ______.

23. The unruly（不守规矩的）student was ______ from school.



第四部分

extensive［ɪk'stensɪv］

adj. 广的；多方面的；广泛的〈同 vast, widespread〉

例　The newspaper reported extensive damage from the fire. 报纸报道了火灾造成的重大损失。

extinct［ɪk'stɪŋkt］

adj.（动物）灭绝的；（火山）不再活跃的，熄灭的〈同 nonexistent, vanished〉

例　Dinosaurs may have become extinct when a meteor struck Earth. 恐龙可能在陨石撞击地球的时候灭绝了。

记　ex（出）+ tinct（促使）→ 促使失去的 → 灭绝的

联　extinction n. 灭绝；extinctive adj. 使熄灭的，使消亡的；extinguish vt. 熄灭，消灭；distinct adj. 清楚的，明显的；instinct n. 本能，天性





extinguish［ɪk'stɪŋgwɪʃ］

vt. 熄灭；消灭，压制〈同 put out, destroy〉

例　Water extinguished the fire. 水浇灭了火。

记　ex（出去）+ (s)tingu（压制，破坏）+ ish → 消灭，压制

联　distinguish v. 区别

extract

［'ekstrækt］n. 精，汁；榨出物〈同 essence〉

例　Vanilla extract is a common ingredient in candies. 香草提取物是糖果的常用配料。

［ɪk'strækt］ vt. 拔出；榨取〈同 derive, squeeze〉

例　The doctor extracted the snake's poison from the bite. 医生把蛇毒从蛇咬的伤口处吸了出来。

联　retract v. 缩回，收回；protract vt. 延长

extravagant［ɪk'strævəgənt］

adj. 奢侈的，浪费的〈同 wasteful〉

例　His extravagant buying habits will have to stop. 他花钱大手大脚的习惯得改掉。

记　extra + vag（走）+ ant → 走得过分的 → 奢侈的

联　vagrant n. 流浪者

fable［'feɪbəl］

n. 寓言，神话〈同 tale, myth〉

例　My favorite fable is the one about the tortoise and the hare. 我最喜欢的一个寓言是关于乌龟和兔子的。

记　fabl（讲，说）+ e → 一代代讲的故事 → 神话

联　fabulous adj. 令人难以置信的；affable adj. 温和的，和蔼的；effable adj. 能表达出来的；ineffable adj. 说不出的

fabricate［'fæbrɪkeɪt］

vt. ① 制作，构成〈同 make, assemble〉

例　Automobiles are fabricated from parts made in different factories. 汽车由不同工厂生产出来的配件组装而成。

② 伪造，虚构

例　The clerk fabricated an excuse to avoid questioning. 这个职员编造了一个理由，以免被质询。

记　fabric（构造）+ ate → 构造出来 → 伪造

联　prefabricate vt. 预制（房屋），预先构想；fabric n. 织物，构造；fabrication n. 制作，捏造

facet［'fæsɪt］

n. 面；（问题等的）方面〈同 side, aspect〉

例　The problem that we face now has many legal and financial facets. 我们现在面临的问题有很多法律和金融方面的问题。

联　facetious adj. 幽默的，滑稽的，轻浮的；multifaceted adj. 多层面的；face vt. 面对

facilitate［fə'sɪlɪteɪt］

vt. 使容易；有助于，促进〈同 promote, expedite〉

例　Modern technology has facilitated the production process. 现代科技促进了生产力的发展。

联　facilitation n. 促进，帮助；facile adj. 容易的，敏捷的；facility n. 容易，方便

faithful［'feɪθfʊl］

adj. 忠实的〈同 loyal, devoted〉

例　Several senior workers were given awards for long and faithful service. 几位高级工人因为长期、忠诚的奉献而获得表彰。

联　faithfulness n. 忠诚，诚实

28. The spy ______ the secret plans from a security guard.

Lesson 12





音频



预备测验

找出与句子中划线单词意义最相近的词。

1. Archaeologists have discovered fossils of ancient animals in excavations.

(A) remnants

(B) graves

(C) records

2. The white blood cell count in one's body may fluctuate by 50 percent throughout a day.

(A) undulate

(B) multiply

(C) vary

3. Many people who can't afford fur coats can buy fake furs.

(A) costly

(B) soft

(C) imitation

4. This item has a flaw in it.

(A) defect

(B) chimney

(C) shard

5. My grandfather has become feeble since his bad fall.

(A) weak

(B) rhythmic

(C) deliberate



第一部分

fake［feɪk］

n. 赝品，假货〈同 imitation, counterfeit〉

例　The antique collector must be able to distinguish real antiques from fakes. 古董收藏者一定要有鉴别古董真伪的能力。

adj. 假的，伪造的〈同 false〉

例　Her ring is set with a fake diamond. 她的戒指上镶了一颗假钻石。

联　counterfeit n. 伪造品（货币、文件等）

fantastic［fæn'tæstɪk］

adj.〈口〉极好的；奇异的〈同 marvelous, extraordinary〉

例　He told a fantastic story about being abducted by creatures from outer space. 他讲了一个他被外太空生物绑架的离奇故事。

记　来自 fantasy（幻想，怪念头）

联　fantasy n. 想像，幻想；fantasia n. 幻想曲；fantasize v. 幻想，做白日梦

fare［feə(r)］

n. 车（船）费〈同 charge〉

例　What is the plane fare from London to Los Angeles? 从伦敦飞往洛杉矶的机票价格是多少？

fascinate［'fæsɪneɪt］

vt. 使着迷，使神魂颠倒〈同 intrigue, enthrall〉

例　She fascinated the audience with tales of her adventures. 她的冒险故事令观众们很着迷。

联　fascinating adj. 迷人的，醉人的；fascination n. 魅力，入迷，着迷

faulty［'fɔ:lti］

adj. 有过失的；有缺点的，不完美的〈同 defective, imperfect〉

例　You should repair the faulty electrical machines because it's dangerous for people to touch them. 你应该修理好这些有问题的电机，因为要是有人碰到它会很危险。

favorable［'feɪvərəbəl］

adj. 有利的；顺利的；赢得赞扬的〈同 beneficial, approving〉

例　We ought to set sail soon, while the weather is still favorable. 我们应该趁着天气还不错的时候马上起航。

联　favored adj. 首选的，受到优待的，受优惠的；unfavorable adj. 不宜的，相反的

feast［fi:st］

n. 节日，盛宴〈同 banquet〉

例　The queen held a feast in honor of her son's marriage. 女王设宴为儿子庆祝新婚。

federation［ˌfedə'reɪʃən］

n. 联盟，同盟，联邦

例　Each member of the federation keeps control over its own affairs. 联盟中每个成员的事务由他们自己来控制。

feeble［'fi:bəl］

adj. 微弱的；衰弱的〈同 weak, faint〉

例　The old man was too feeble to walk. 老人太虚弱了，连路都没法走了。





feedback［'fi:dbæk］

n. 反馈，反应〈同 response〉

例　Janet received a lot of feedback on her ideas about baby-sitting. 珍妮特当保姆的想法得到了很多人的回应。

6. Janet was ______ by the designs and colors in African art and bought many artworks of this style.

7. The old man's voice was so ______ that we could barely hear him.

8. He just paid $100, 000 for a painting that turned out to be a ______.

9. His new play is successful because it received ______ reviews.

10. The idea that machines could be made to fly seemed ______ hundreds of years ago.

11. His car doesn't run well because it has a ______ valve（阀）.



第二部分

fellowship［'feləʊʃɪp］

n. 奖学金；研究员基金；同伙关系

例　She's applied to various foundations for a research fellowship. 她向许多基金会提交了研究员基金申请。

feminine［'femɪnɪn］

adj. 女性的；有女性气质的；［语法学］阴性的〈同 womanly〉

例　The shop was decorated in a feminine manner. 这个商店的装饰风格很女性化。

记　femin（= woman女人）+ ine → 女人的

联　female adj. 女性的；feminism n. 男女平等主义，女权运动；effeminate adj. 柔弱的，女人气的；masculine adj. 男性的，男子气概的

fertilize［'fɜ:tɪlaɪz; 'fɜ:təlaɪz］

vt. 施肥，使丰饶；使受精〈同 enrich〉

例　Many farmers fertilize their farmland with chemicals. 很多农民给他们的农田施化肥。

联　fertilized adj. 施过肥的，受精的；fertilized egg 受精卵；fertilizer n. 肥料（尤指化学肥料）

finite［'faɪnaɪt］

adj. 有限（制）的〈同 limited〉

例　The resources of our planet are finite. 我们地球上的资源是有限的。

记　fin（范围，结束）+ ite → 有范围的 → 有限（制）的

联　infinite adj. 无限的；definite adj. 确定的，限定的；indefinite adj. 模糊的，不确定的；infinitesimal adj. 无限小的

fist［fɪst］

n. 拳头

例　She clenched her fists because of the pain. 她因为疼痛而紧握双拳。

fixture［'fɪkstʃə(r)］

n.（房屋等的）固定装置；固定设备

例　All fixtures are included in the house price. 房价包含房屋内的所有固定装置。

flank［flæŋk］

n. 侧面，侧翼

例　The general concentrated his attack on the left flank of the opposing army. 将军集中火力攻击敌军的左翼。

flap［flæp］

v. 拍动，拍打；鼓翼而飞〈同 flutter, vibrate〉

例　The caged bird flapped its wings in a vain attempt to fly away. 笼子里的鸟拍打着翅膀想飞走，但却徒劳无功。





flare［fleə(r)］

n. 闪光，闪耀〈同 flash〉

例　There was a sudden flare when she threw the petrol onto the fire. 当她把汽油浇到火上的时候，火势突然增大了。

vi. 闪光，突然爆发或燃烧，闪耀〈同 glare〉

例　The candle flared in the darkness. 蜡烛的火焰在黑暗中闪耀。

flatter［'flætə(r)］

v. 阿谀奉承；讨好〈同 overpraise〉

例　He flattered her by saying she looked like a movie star. 他讨好她，说她长得像电影明星。

联　flattery n. 谄媚，阿谀，巴结

14. The goose ______ its wings but could not rise from the ground.

15. The funds available for the health service are ______ and we cannot afford to waste money.

16. Janet financed her MBA study with a ______ granted by the business school.

17. It's a good idea to ______ your garden every spring.



第三部分

flaw［flɔ:］

n. 缺点，瑕疵〈同 fault〉

例　This shirt is inexpensive because it has a minor flaw. 这件衬衫价钱不贵，因为有一个小瑕疵。

联　flawless adj. 完美的，无瑕疵的；flow vi. 流，流动

fleet［fli:t］

n.（尤指有固定活动地区的）舰队，船队

例　A fleet is a group of ships under one command. 舰队由一组军舰组成，并接受统一指挥。

adj. 快速的，敏捷的〈同 rapid〉

例　The robber made a fleet escape. 强盗飞快地逃走了。

fling［flɪŋ］

v. 猛投，掷〈同 throw〉

例　In a rage the wife flung the cup out of the room. 妻子一怒之下把杯子从房间里扔了出去。





fluctuate［'flʌktjʊeɪt］

vi. 波动，起伏〈同 alternate〉

例　The citizens' opinion of the president fluctuated from week to week. 人民对总统的看法每周都有所不同。

记　fluct（= flu 流动）+ uate → 波动，起伏

联　fluctuant adj. 变动的，波动的；fluctuation n. 波动，起伏；flux n. 流动，变迁；influx n. 流入

flush［flʌʃ］

v. ① 冲洗；奔涌〈同 wash〉

例　After dinner, she flushed food scraps down the garbage disposal. 晚饭以后，她把剩饭倒到垃圾处理机里冲走。

②（使脸）发红〈同 redden〉

例　He flushed with anger when I insulted him. 我羞辱了他，他的脸气得通红。

联　flushed adj. 兴奋的，洋溢着喜悦的；blush vi. 脸红，羞愧

flutter［'flʌtə(r)］

v. 鼓翼，拍（翅膀）；（使）飘动〈同 wave〉

例　The flag fluttered in the breeze. 旗子在微风中飘扬。

foam［fəʊm］

n. 泡沫

例　I like to shake my soda to create a foam. 我喜欢摇晃苏打水来产生泡沫。

foil［fɔɪl］

n. 金属薄片，箔

例　Candy is sometimes wrapped in foil to keep it fresh. 为了保鲜，糖果有时会被裹上一层箔纸。

v. 阻止，挫败〈同 thwart, frustrate〉

例　His attempt to kill the leader was foiled by the guard. 他试图刺杀首领，被守卫阻止了。

fold［fəʊld］

v. 折叠；抢〈同 crease〉

例　He folded his arms in anticipation of a long wait at the doctor's office. 他把双臂抱在胸前，做好在医生的办公室里等很长时间的准备。

n. 折痕，褶〈同 pleat〉

例　The kitten played in the folds of the curtain. 小猫在窗帘的皱褶处玩耍。

联　scaffolding n. 脚手架；thousandfold adj. 千倍的；unfold v. 打开，显露

foremost［'fɔ:məʊst］

adj. 最重要的；最先的〈同 primary, leading〉

例　Getting home safely was the lost hiker's foremost thought. 迷路的徒步旅行者的首要目的是平安到家。

记　组合词：fore（提前）+ most（最）→ 在最前面的 → 最先的

联　furthermost adj. 最远的；uppermost adj. 至上的，最高的；forerunner n. 先驱者

自我检测　从第三部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

18. The price of oil ______ from year to year.

19. The birds perched on a wire and ______ their wings.

20. An alert guard ______ the robbery attempt.

21. Constant embarrassment ______ his cheeks.

22. Janet is a hard-working and smart assistant; however her quick temper is a ______ in her character.

23. Some people like a good head of ______ on their beer.



第四部分

foresee［fɔ:'si:］

vt. 预见，预知〈同 anticipate〉

例　We didn't take our bathing suits because we could foresee that the water would be too cold for us to swim. 我们没有带泳衣，因为我们预计水会很凉而不适合游泳。

记　fore（前面）+ see（看见）→ 提前看见 → 预见

联　foresight n. 远见，深谋远虑；foreshadow vt. 预示；forehead n. 前额；forestall vt. 阻止；forefather n. 前人，祖先；forearm n. 前臂

formidable［fə'mɪdəbəl; 'fɔ:mɪdəbəl］

adj. 令人敬畏的，可怕的〈同 dreadful, forbidding〉

例　Cancer is a formidable disease, killing millions of people every year. 癌症是一种可怕的疾病，每年夺去数百万人的生命。

记　formid（看作formic，蚂蚁的）→ 蚁群很可怕 → 可怕的

formulate［'fɔ:mjʊleɪt］

vt. 系统地阐述（或提出）

例　The best way to formulate one's ideas is usually to write them down. 要想清楚地阐述自己的观点，最好的办法是把它们都写下来。

联　formulation n. 制造，系统地阐述；formula n. 公式；formation n. 样式，形式

fort［fɔ:t］

n. 要塞 ，堡垒〈同 fortress〉

例　The soldiers hastily constructed a crude log fort. 战士们匆忙地建造了一座简易的木头堡垒。

联　fortress n. 要塞，堡垒；fortify v. 增强，筑堡垒（于）；forte n. 特长，专长，强项

forthcoming［fɔ:θ'kʌmɪŋ］

adj. 即将来临的〈同 approaching〉

例　The forthcoming year for Janet will be busy because she needs to find a new job. 来年珍妮特将会很忙，因为她需要重新找工作。

记　组合词：forth（向前）+ com(e)（来）+ ing → 即将来临的

联　coming adj. 即将到来的；oncoming adj. 即将到来的，接近的

forum［'fɔ:rəm］

n. 论坛，讨论会〈同 meeting〉

例　The phone-in program provides a forum for the public to express their views on different topics. 热线电话直播节目提供了一个平台，让公众针对不同话题表达自己的观点。

fossil［'fɒsəl］

n. 化石；僵化的事物〈同 remnant〉

例　Fossils of ferns are found in coal. 煤炭里发现了蕨类植物的化石。

联　fossilize vt. 使成化石

foster［'fɒstə(r); (US)'fɔ:stər］

vt. ① 鼓励，促进〈同 encourage〉

例　The leader fostered the growth of small-scale industries. 领导鼓励小型企业的发展。

② 养育，抚养〈同 raise〉

例　This orphanage fosters many children. 这家孤儿院收养了很多小孩。

foul［faʊl］

adj. 污秽的，肮脏的〈同 disgusting〉

例　His muddy clothes smelled foul. 他那件沾满泥巴的衣服闻着很臭。

fracture［'fræktʃə(r)］

n. 骨折；破裂〈同 fragment〉

例　He did not think that he had broken his arm, but the X-rays revealed a slight fracture. 他不觉得胳膊断了，但是X光片显示有轻微骨折。

vt. 使破裂，断裂〈同 break〉

例　The rock fractured under the tremendous pressure. 石头在受到重压之后裂了。

记　fract（破开）+ ure → 裂开，破开 → 骨折；破裂

联　fracas n. 喧闹；fraction n. 小部分，碎片；fractional adj. 部分的，分数的；fractious adj. 易怒的，好争吵的

Lesson 13





音频



预备测验

找出与句子中划线单词意义最相近的词。

1. Once started, a chain reaction sustains itself without further outside influence.

(A) endless

(B) measurable

(C) additional

2. He looked gloomy when he showed up this morning.

(A) terrible

(B) energetic

(C) dismal

3. Tennessee possesses many caverns with gorgeous rock formations.

(A) beautiful

(B) large

(C) significant

4. Cattle graze on the dry uplands（丘陵地）of the island of Hawaii.

(A) wander

(B) breed

(C) browse

5. Charles Wilson Peale is generally considered the most gifted of the Philadelphia colonial artists.

(A) talented

(B) presented

(C) eccentric



第一部分

fragile［'fræʤaɪl; (US)'fræʤɪl］

adj. 易碎的，脆的；脆弱的〈同 brittle, delicate〉

例　That dish is fragile, so be careful. 那个盘子容易碎，小心点。

联　fragility n. 脆弱

fragrant［'freɪgrənt］

adj. 香的，芬芳的〈同 aromatic〉

例　In the park, Anne bent over to smell the fragrant rosebuds. 在公园里，安妮俯下身来闻玫瑰花蕾的芳香。

联　fragrance n. 芬芳，香气；flagrant adj. 恶名昭著的

fraud［frɔ:d］

n. 欺骗；骗子〈同 deceit〉

例　The politician's conviction for tax fraud jeopardized his future in public life. 这个政客的税务欺诈罪名成立，这影响了他未来在公众生活中的形象。

联　fraudulent adj. 欺骗的，不诚实的；fraught adj. 充满…的

frigid［'frɪʤɪd］

adj. ① 寒冷的〈同 icy〉

例　People in Harbin enjoy swimming in the frigid water in winter. 哈尔滨人喜欢冬天在冰冷刺骨的水里游泳。

② 冷淡的

例　He received a frigid greeting from the man he had insulted. 那个曾经被他辱骂过的人给了他一个冷冰冰的问候。

fringe［frɪnʤ］

n. 边缘；边界〈同 border, margin〉

例　The spaceship traveled to the outer fringe of the solar system. 宇宙飞船飞抵太阳系边缘。

联　flange n.【机】法兰，凸缘

frontier［'frʌntɪə(r); (US)frʌn'tɪər］

n. 国境，边境〈同 boundary〉

例　Lewis and Clark led an expedition that explored America's frontier. 刘易斯和克拉克率领一支勘查过美国边境的探险队。

fulfill［fʊl'fɪl］

vt. 履行，实现；使满足〈同 satisfy〉

例　She has to take only one more course to fulfill her graduation requirements. 她再学习一门课程就能达到毕业要求了。

furious［'fjʊərɪəs］

adj. 狂怒的；狂暴的〈同 angry, violent〉

例　He is furious over the theft of his wallet. 他的钱包被偷了，这让他感到十分恼火。





further［'fɜ:ðə(r)］

vt. 促进，增进〈同 advance〉

例　She hoped that taking night classes would further her career. 她希望读夜校能进一步发展她的事业。

adj. 更多的，另外的〈同 additional, extra〉

例　Have you received any further news about the accident? 关于这场事故，你有更多新的消息吗？

fuse［fju:z］

v. 熔合〈同 combine〉

例　The chemist fused two metals together to create a new alloy. 化学家把两种金属熔合，形成了新的合金。

联　fusion n.【物】核聚变，熔化，联合

自我检测　从第一部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

6. My parents were ______ when I stayed out past midnight.

7. The two rivals are ______ by their common motives.

8. The arctic region has a ______ climate.

9. This crystal vase is very ______.

10. He was arrested for ______ when he sold a counterfeit painting.

11. These ______ flowers made the room smell nice.



第二部分

galaxy［'gæləksi］

n. 星系；银河

例　We live in a huge galaxy called the Milky Way. 我们生活在一个叫银河系的巨大星系中。

gamble［'gæmbəl］

n./v. 冒险，赌博，投机〈同 bet〉

例　Don't gamble what you can't afford to lose. 别拿你输不起的东西当赌注。

garbage［'gɑ:bɪʤ］

n. 垃圾，废物〈同 trash, waste〉

例　I forgot to put the garbage out for collection this morning. 我早上忘记把垃圾拿出去扔到垃圾收集站了。

联　garage n. 修车厂，车库

garment［'gɑ:mənt］

n. 衣服，外衣〈同 apparel, clothing〉

例　She hung her garments in the closet. 她把她的衣服挂在了衣橱里。





gasp［'gɑ:sp; (US)gæsp］

vi. 气喘，急促地喘气

例　The hiker gasped for air as she reached the destination. 当那位徒步旅行者到达目的地时，她大口喘着气。

gaze［geɪz］

vi. 盯，凝视〈同 stare〉

例　The child gazed at the magician to see what would happen. 小孩盯着魔术师，想看看将会发生什么事。

联　faze vt. 打扰，使狼狈；maze n. 曲径，迷宫；graze v. 放牧，吃草

generalize［'ʤenərəlaɪz］

v. 归纳，概括〈同 infer, deduce〉

例　He generalized from the president's speech that the nation is not going to be involved in the war. 他从总统的演讲中推断出国家不会卷入战争。

联　generalization n. 归纳，概括；general adj. 一般；generality n. 一般性；generalist n. 多面手，通才

genetic［ʤə'netɪk］

adj. 遗传的，起源的〈同 hereditary〉

例　His heart problems are a result of his genetic code; his father also had heart problems. 他的心脏病是遗传的，他的父亲也有心脏病。

联　genetics n. 遗传学

genius［'ʤi:njəs］

n. 天才；天赋〈同 talent, gift〉

例　Important discoveries are usually made by men and women of genius. 天才往往会有重大发现。

giant［'ʤaɪənt］

adj. 庞大的，巨大的〈同 enormous〉

例　This huge project cost a giant amount of money. 这个庞大的项目开支数额巨大。

记　通过念此词的嘴形及发音可体会出“巨大的”的意思

自我检测　从第二部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

13. Investing in the stock market can be a ______.

14. I ______ at her in disbelief when she told me the result of the examination.

15. The Earth and the Sun are part of one ______.

16. The cleaner picks up the ______ on the lawn every morning.

17. He's got amazingly long legs and walks with ______ steps.



第三部分

gifted［'gɪftɪd］

adj. 有天赋的〈同 talented〉

例　Gifted children need special teaching. 有天赋的孩子需要特殊教育。

联　gift n. 礼物，天赋

gigantic［ʤaɪ'gæntɪk］

adj. 巨大的〈同 mammoth, huge〉

例　An elephant is a gigantic animal. 大象是一种庞大的动物。

记　giant（巨人）中间加一个g，成为gigant + ic → gigantic → 巨大的

glance［glɑ:ns; (US)glæns］

n. /v. 掠过，匆匆一看〈同 glimpse〉

例　Tom took one glance at the wretched animal and turned away. 汤姆瞟了一眼那只可怜的动物，随即离开了。

glare［gleə(r)］

n. 炫目的光〈同 light, brightness〉

例　Sunglasses will eliminate the glare. 太阳镜能减少（射入眼睛的）强光。

v. 闪耀〈同 flare〉

例　The headlights of the truck glared, illuminating the street. 卡车刺眼的前灯照亮了街道。





gleam［gli:m］

n. 微弱的闪光，一丝光线〈同 glimmer〉

例　A gleam of light shone through the prison window. 一缕微光从监狱的窗户照射进来。

glide［glaɪd］

vi. 滑动，滑行〈同 slide〉

例　The plane glided to a safe landing after its engines failed. 飞机引擎出故障之后，飞机靠滑翔下降并安全着陆。

联　gliding adj. 流畅的，滑行的；glider n. 滑行者，滑翔机；slide v. 滑过；glade n. 林间空地

glitter［'glɪtə(r)］

vi. 闪闪发光，闪烁〈同 sparkle〉

例　From the top of the hill we could see city lights glittering below. 从山顶往下看，我们能看见城市的灯光闪闪发亮。

联　由gl组成的一些词与发光（glow）相关，例如：glimmer n. 微光；glisten vi. 闪耀；glare n. 炫目的光

global［'gləʊbəl］

adj. 全球性的〈同 worldwide〉

例　The energy problem, far from being limited to the United States, is truly global. 能源危机不仅是美国更是全球都面临的问题。

gloomy［'glu:mi］

adj. 黑暗的；阴沉的，使人沮丧或恐惧的〈同 dark, dim〉

例　She has been in a gloomy mood since she lost the contest. 自从竞赛失败之后，她情绪一直很低落。

记　来自gloom（阴暗）

联　gloom n. 黑暗，阴暗；bloom v. 开花；groom n. 马夫，新郎

glorify［'glɔ:rɪfaɪ］

vt. 美化，赞扬〈同 exalt, beautify〉

例　It's not a good idea to glorify money above all else. 赞美金钱至高无上并不是一个好主意。

第四部分

gorgeous［'gɔ:ʤəs］

adj. 绚丽的；灿烂的〈同 beautiful, magnificent〉

例　A gorgeous model won the beauty contest. 一个魅力十足的模特赢得了选美比赛。

记　来自gorge（峡谷）+ ous → 峡谷的风景是美丽的 → 绚丽的

联　gorge n. 咽喉，峡谷 v. 狼吞虎咽





gossip［'gɒsɪp］

n. 社会新闻，小道传闻〈同 rumor〉

例　There was a lot of gossip in the village about their affair. 关于他们的风流韵事，村子里有很多传闻。

govern［'gʌvən］

vt. 统治，管理；控制〈同 rule, control〉

例　The president governed the nation for eight years. 这位总统统治了这个国家八年。

联　governable adj. 可控制的；governance n. 统治，支配；government n. 政府；governor n. 州长，总督

gracious［'greɪʃəs］

adj. 亲切的；高雅的〈同 kind〉

例　Her gracious manners were appreciated by the guests. 她优雅的举止深受客人赞赏。

grateful［'greɪtfʊl］

adj. 感激的，感谢的〈同 thankful〉

例　I am grateful for the help that you have given to me. 我十分感谢你给予我的帮助。

graze［greɪz］

v.（牲畜）吃草；放牧〈同 feed〉

例　Sheep graze in the meadows. 羊群在草地上吃草。

联　overgraze v. 过度放牧；grazing land 牧场，草场；grave n. 墓穴，坟墓 adj. 严重的；raze vt. 夷为平地；glaze vt. 上釉，使表面光滑

grease［gri:s］

n. 油脂〈同 oil, fat〉

例　For any adhesive to make a really strong bond, the surfaces to be glued must be absolutely clean and free from moisture or grease. 对任何黏合剂来说，要想真正粘得结实，胶合面必须要干净，没有一点水或油脂。

grief［gri:f］

n. 悲痛；不幸〈同 sorrow〉

例　The beggar's life was full of grief. 这个乞丐的生活充满了不幸。

联　grieve v.（使）悲伤，（使）伤心

grim［grɪm］

adj. 严厉的；严峻的〈同 severe, harsh〉

例　My parents were grim when they heard about the broken window. 我的父母听说窗户被打破时生气了。

grin［grɪn］

vi. 露齿笑，咧嘴笑〈同 smile broadly〉

例　She grinned at the chipmunk's antics. 花栗鼠做出的滑稽动作逗得她咧嘴大笑。

Lesson 14





音频



预备测验

找出与句子中划线单词意义最相近的词。

1. That's a quite interesting hypothesis.

(A) assumption

(B) hazard

(C) solution

2. The truck was hampered by a stone.

(A) evaded

(B) overlooked

(C) hindered

3. The antifreeze（防冻剂）in motor oil hinders its freezing in cold weather.

(A) requires

(B) measures

(C) impedes

4. Beethoven was handicapped by deafness but wrote some of the world's best music.

(A) afflicted

(B) crippled

(C) restricted

5. If stored while wet, hay（干草）may build up heat and ignite spontaneously.

(A) sprout

(B) catch fire

(C) release gases



第一部分

groan［grəʊn］

v. 呻吟；叹息〈同 moan〉

例　The wounded men groaned in agony as the stretcher-bearers tried to move them. 抬担架的人试着去挪动伤员时，伤员们发出了痛苦的呻吟。

联　moan n./v. 呻吟

grope［grəʊp］

v. 摸索，探索〈同 probe〉

例　Tom groped around in the dark in order to find the light switch. 汤姆在黑暗中摸索着，想找到电灯的开关。

记　分割记忆：g（看作 grasp 抓住）+ rope（绳子）→ 抓住绳子，摸索向前 → 摸索，探索

联　gripe v./n. 抓牢；rope n. 绳；lope v.（尤指动物）轻跳着奔跑





gross［grəʊs］

adj. 总的；毛重的〈同 total, entire〉

例　Gross receipts are all the money taken in before costs are deducted. 总收入是指未扣除开支的所有收入。

guardian［'gɑ:dɪən］

n. 保护人，监护人〈同 protector〉

例　Mary's stepmother was a terrible guardian. 玛丽的继母是一个很糟糕的监护人。

habitual［hə'bɪtjʊəl］

adj. 习惯的〈同 customary〉

例　Janet can't start work in the morning without her habitual cup of coffee. 珍妮特如果早上没有习惯性地喝一杯咖啡的话，就无法开始工作。

记　habit（住，习惯）+ ual → 习惯的

联　habit n. 习惯；habituate vt. 使习惯于

hail［heɪl］

n. 冰雹

例　Hail ruined the farmer's wheat crop. 冰雹摧毁了农民种植的小麦。

vt. 向…致敬；向…欢呼；热情地承认〈同 salute, acclaim〉

例　The crowds hailed him as winner. 人群高呼他是胜利者。

联　bail n. 保释，保证金；rail vi. 责骂，抱怨；frail adj. 虚弱的，脆弱的；retail n./v. 零售；wail n./v. 悲叹

hamper［'hæmpə(r)］

vt. 妨碍，使困难〈同 impede, hinder〉

例　The project was hampered by a lack of funds. 项目由于缺少资金而受阻。

handicap［'hændɪkæp］

n. 残疾〈同 disadvantage〉

例　His stuttering was a handicap when meeting new people. 当他和新朋友交谈时，他的口吃成了一个障碍。

vt. 严重妨碍，削弱〈同 cripple, hinder〉

例　The noise of traffic outside the classroom may handicap the students' ability to focus on the lesson. 教室外面的交通噪音可能会影响学生们听课的注意力。

联　handicraft n. 手工艺，手工艺品；handcuff n. 手铐；handy adj. 手边的，便利的

hasty［'heɪsti］

adj. 急急忙忙的，草率的〈同 quick〉

例　For a CEO, it's foolish to make hasty decisions. 对于一个CEO来说，草率地做决定是一件愚蠢的事。

记　hast（速度）+ y → 速度快的 → 急急忙忙的

联　hasten v. 催促，赶紧；haste n. 匆忙，急忙，草率；nasty adj. 肮脏的

hatch［hætʃ］

v. 孵化〈同 breed〉

例　The heat of the incubator helped hatch the chick. 孵化器的热量帮助孵化小鸡。

联　hatchling n.（尤指由人工）孵化的鱼苗或小鸟；hatchery n. 孵卵所；hatchet n. 短柄斧；thatch n. 茅草屋顶 vt. 用茅草盖（房子等的屋顶）；snatch v. 攫取

自我检测　从第一部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

6. He ______ in the grass for his lost contact lens.

7. We heard the injured people ______ and tried to handle them gently.

8. The muddy track ______ the horse's performance.

9. We ______ the chicken eggs in an incubator.

10. Everyone ______ the good news from the peace conference.

11. They appointed him ______ of the orphan.



第二部分

haul［hɔ:l］

v. 拉，拖〈同 draw〉

例　Help me haul the hay bales into the barn. 帮我把这些干草捆拖到谷仓里。

联　hauler n. 搬运工；overhaul vt. 仔细检查

haunt［hɔ:nt］

vt.（想法、回忆等）萦绕心头，困扰〈同 bother〉

例　The idea that he had forgotten to do something haunted Bod all day. 鲍勃总感觉自己忘记做什么事了，这种感觉困扰了他一整天。

联　haunting adj. 不易忘怀的；daunt vt. 使胆怯；jaunt n. 短途旅游；flaunt v. 炫耀，夸示；taunt vt. 嘲弄，奚落；vaunt v. 吹嘘，自夸

heave［hi:v］

v. 举起〈同 raise〉

例　Laborers heaved the crate onto the truck. 工人把板条箱抬到了卡车上。

联　weave v. 编织；heavy adj. 重的





heighten［'haɪtən］

vt. 提高，升高；加深〈同 enhance, hoist〉

例　As protection, they heightened the city walls by a further three feet. 作为防御措施，他们把城墙又加高了三英尺。

联　height n. 高度，海拔

heir［eə(r)］

n. 继承人，后嗣〈同 inheritor〉

例　The monarch died before he could name an heir to the throne. 君主还没任命皇位继承者就去世了。

hemisphere［'hemɪsfɪə(r)］

n. 半球；大脑半球〈同 half〉

例　The eastern hemisphere is the half of the world that includes part of Europe, Asia, Africa and Australia. 东半球是指包括部分欧洲、亚洲、非洲和澳洲的那一半地球。

heritage［'herɪtɪʤ］

n. 遗产，继承物；传统〈同 legacy, tradition〉

例　The government must spend more money on preserving our national heritage. 政府必须增加对保护国家遗产方面的支出。

hierarchy［'haɪərɑ:ki］

n. 阶层，等级制度〈同 class, order〉

例　The military has a rigid hierarchy with numerous ranks. 军队里有严格的等级制度，军衔也有很多种。

记　hier（神圣）+ archy（统治）→ 神圣的统治阶层 → 阶层

联　anarchy n. 无政府状态；hieratic adj. 僧侣的

highlight［'haɪlaɪt］

vt. 使显著，使突出〈同 emphasize〉

例　The editor highlighted the mistakes in the manuscript in red ink. 编辑把手稿中错误的部分用红笔标了出来。

n. 最显著或重要的部分〈同 focal point〉

例　The highlight of our trip to New York was going to the top of the Empire State Building. 我们这次纽约之行的高潮就是登顶帝国大厦。

记　high + light → 高挂着的灯照着 → 使突出

联　highland n. 高地，丘陵地带；spotlight n. 聚光灯 vt. 使显眼、突出

hinder［'hɪndə(r)］

vt. 阻碍，妨碍〈同 stunt, inhibit〉

例　The tall fence hindered the children from going near the house. 高高的栅栏使孩子们无法靠近这座房子。

记　hind（后面）+ er → 拉在后面 → 阻碍

第三部分

hinge［hɪnʤ］

n.（门等的）铰链，枢纽

例　The door squeaks because the hinges need oil. 门吱吱响，因为铰链缺油。

hoist［hɔɪst］

n. 起重机

例　A mechanic used a hoist to lift an engine from an automobile. 机械师使用起重机将汽车里的引擎吊了出来。

v. 举起，升起，吊起〈同 raise〉

例　The father hoisted his small child onto his shoulders. 父亲把他的小孩举到了肩膀上。

horn［hɔ:n］

n.（牛、羊等的）角

例　Cattle, sheep and goats have a pair of horns, but the Indian rhinoceros only has one. 牛、绵羊和山羊都有一对角，但是印度犀牛只有一只角。

联　horned adj. 有角的，角状的；hornbill n.【动】犀鸟，犀鸟科；hornet n. 大黄蜂；pronghorn n.【动】（墨西哥与美国西部产的）叉角羚；foghorn n.【航】雾角（对船只发出的浓雾信号）；thorn n.【植】刺，棘；thorny adj. 多刺的

horrible［'hɒrəbəl; (US)'hɔ:rəbəl］

adj. 可怕的，恐怖的〈同 terrible〉

例　We have to report the horrible accident to the police. 我们必须将这起可怕的事故报警。

联　horrify vt. 使恐惧，使惊骇；horror n. 恐怖，恐惧

hose［həʊz］

n. 软管，水龙带

例　A garden hose often has a nozzle on one end to help spray. 花园浇水用的软管通常在一端有一个喷嘴来帮助其喷水。

vt. 用软管浇水

例　The driver hosed down the car. 司机用水管冲洗汽车。

hospitality［ˌhɒspɪ'tæləti］

n. 好客，盛情

例　The local people provided a car to bring me from the airport and showed me great hospitality. 当地人派了一辆车把我从机场接了回来，并且对我十分热情。

联　hospitable adj. 好客的；hospital n. 医院

hostage［'hɒstɪʤ］

n. 人质；抵押品

例　The terrorist took hostages and threatened to kill them. 恐怖分子挟制了人质，并威胁要杀了他们。

hover［'hɒvə(r); (US)'hʌvər］

vi. 翱翔，盘旋；徘徊〈同 float〉

例　The helicopter hovered in the air. 直升飞机在空中盘旋。

联　hovercraft n. 气垫船

hug［hʌg］

n./v. 拥抱〈同 embrace〉

例　The little girl hugged her stuffed rabbit while sleeping. 小女孩睡觉的时候抱着她的玩具兔子。





humanity［hju:'mænɪti］

n. 人类；人性；博爱，仁慈〈同 kindness〉

例　Adolf Hitler was guilty of enormous crimes against humanity. 阿道夫·希特勒犯了反人类的滔天罪行。

联　humane adj. 仁慈的；inhumane adj. 残忍的；humanism n. 人道主义；humanist n. 人道主义者；humanitarian n. 人道主义者 adj. 人道主义的；nonhuman adj. 非人类的

第四部分

humidity［hju:'mɪdɪti］

n. 湿气，湿度〈同 dampness〉

例　On a hot, sultry day, the humidity is high. 天气又热又闷的时候，湿度会很高。

联　humid adj. 潮湿的，湿润的

hurl［hɜ:l］

v. 用力投掷〈同 throw〉

例　Rebel youths hurled stones at the soldiers. 抗议的年轻人向士兵扔石头。

hurricane［'hʌrɪkən］

n. 飓风，暴风雨〈同 storm〉

例　The wind in a hurricane can reach speeds over 75 miles per hour. 龙卷风的风速可超过每小时75英里。

hypothesis［haɪ'pɒθɪsɪz］

n. 假设，假说〈同 assumption〉

例　One scientist's hypothesis has to be tested by other scientists before it is generally accepted as truth. 科学家的设想在作为真理为人们接受之前，总是要经受其他科学家的考验。

记　hypo（在…下面）+ thesis（论点）→ 非真正论点 → 假说

联　hypothesize v. 假设，假定；hypothetical adj. 假定的；hypotenuse n.（直角三角形的）斜边

hysterical［hɪ'sterɪkəl］

adj. 歇斯底里的；异常兴奋的〈同 frenzied〉

例　We could not control the hysterical man. 我们没法控制这个歇斯底里的人。

记　来自名词hysteria（歇斯底里症，早先人们认为患歇斯底里症是因为子宫机能失调所致）：hyste(r)（子宫）+ rical → 子宫功能失调的 → 歇斯底里的

idiom［'ɪdɪəm］

n. 方言，土语；习惯用语〈同 lingo〉

例　“Hold one's tongue”is an English idiom meaning“keep quiet”. Hold one's tongue 是一个英语习语，意思是“保持沉默”。

联　idiomatic adj. 惯用的

ignite［ɪg'naɪt］

v. 点燃，（使）燃烧〈同 light, burn〉

例　One match can ignite an entire forest. 一根火柴可以点燃整个森林。

联　ignition n. 点火，点燃；igneous adj. 火的；【地】火成的；ignitable adj. 易起火的，可燃性的





ignorant［'ɪgnərənt］

adj. 无知的；不了解的〈同 unlearned, unaware〉

例　People who live in the city are often ignorant of farm life. 住在城市里的人通常不了解农村的生活。

联　ignorance n. 无知；ignore vt. 不理睬，忽视

illuminate［ɪ'lu:mɪneɪt］

v. ① 照明，照亮〈同 brighten〉

例　Fireworks illuminated the cold night. 烟火照亮了寒冷的夜晚。

② 说明，阐明〈同 clarify, explain〉

例　The teacher illuminated a difficult chapter in the book to make students understand it clearly. 老师讲解了书中有难度的一章，好让学生们清楚地理解。

记　il（一再）+ lumin（明亮）+ ate → 给予光明 → 照明

联　illumination n. 照明，启发；luminary n. 发光天体，杰出人物；illuminant n. 光源，发光体

illusion［ɪ'lu:ʒən］

n. 幻觉；错觉〈同 misconception〉

例　Janet had the illusion that it would be easy to find a job but she soon discovered how wrong she was. 珍妮特错误地以为找工作是一件很容易的事，但是不久她就发现自己错得有多离谱。

联　illusive adj. 迷惑人的；错觉的

Lesson 15





音频



预备测验

找出与句子中划线单词意义最相近的词。

1. Infectious diseases may be spread by viruses and bacteria.

(A) Childhood

(B) Deadly

(C) Contagious

2. He implied that you didn't tell the truth.

(A) communicated

(B) suggested

(C) resolved

3. It is imperative that they arrive on time for the lecture.

(A) necessary

(B) suggested

(C) hoped

4. Very often bacteria or viruses inhabit the body without causing illness, a condition known as the“carrier state”.

(A) surround

(B) repel

(C) occupy

5. Acting is defined as the ability to react to imaginary stimuli.

(A) unexpected

(B) uncommon

(C) unreal



第一部分

imaginary［ɪ'mæʤɪnəri］

adj. 想像中的，虚构的〈同 unreal, imagined〉

例　He is playing a video game against an imaginary opponent. 他正在和一个虚拟的对手玩电子游戏。

记　imagin(e)（想像）+ ary → 想像的

imaginative［ɪ'mæʤɪnətɪv］

adj. 富于想像力的〈同 fanciful, creative〉

例　Science fictionists are so imaginative that create the nonexistent. 科幻小说家太有想像力了，他们能创作出前所未有的事物。

联　imagination n. 想像，空想

imitation［ˌɪmɪ'teɪʃən］

n. 模仿；仿制品〈同 mimicry, copy〉

例　In imitation of older girls, the ten-year-old girls have started wearing make-up. 为了模仿大姑娘，这些十岁的小女孩们已经开始化妆了。

联　imitate vt. 模仿，仿效

immerse［ɪ'mɜ:s］

vt. 浸入；使全神贯注于，使沉浸于〈同 submerge, engross〉

例　The hippopotamus immersed itself in the cool river. 河马把身体浸在凉爽的河水中。

记　im（进入）+ merse（= merge 浸入）→ 浸入

联　immersion n. 沉入，浸入；immense adj. 极广大的，无边的；immerge vi. 浸入，浸没，埋头；submersion n. 淹没

immune［ɪ'mju:n］

adj.（对…）免疫的，不受影响的〈同 exempt〉

例　This vaccine will make you immune to this disease for two years. 接种这种疫苗可使你对这种疾病有两年的免疫力。

记　im（没有）+ mune（责任）→ 没有责任约束的 → 不受影响的

联　immune system 免疫系统；immunity n. 免疫，免除；immunize vt. 使免疫；immutable adj. 不可改变的；immure vt. 监禁，禁闭

impair［ɪm'peə(r)］

vt. 损害，削弱〈同 hurt〉

例　His misdeeds greatly impaired our friendship. 他的罪行严重伤害了我们的友谊。

记　im（进入）+ pair（坏）→ 使变坏 → 损害

联　impairment n. 损害，损伤；mar vt. 破坏，损伤

impart［ɪm'pɑ:t］

vt. 给予，传授；传递，传达〈同 deliver, convey〉

例　Schools impart education. 学校提供教育。

记　im（进入）+ part（部分）→ 成为（知识的）一部分 → 传授

联　impartation n. 告知；impartial adj. 公平的

imperative［ɪm'perətɪv］

adj. 必要的；强制的〈同 necessary〉

例　Mutual respect and understanding among all racial and ethnic groups have become imperative in the life of this nation. 所有种族和民族之间互相尊重、互相理解已经成为这个国家生存的必需因素。

n. 命令；需要；必要的事〈同 command, order〉

例　It is an imperative that you take calculus before you start to study advanced economics. 在你学习高级经济学之前，你需要学习微积分。

记　imper（命令）+ ative → 强制的

imperial［ɪm'pɪərɪəl］

adj. 帝王的；威严的，至高无上的〈同 royal〉

例　The palace was decorated with imperial splendor. 宫殿装修得很有皇室风范。

联　imperator n. 绝对统治者；empire n. 帝国；imperious adj. 傲慢的，专横的；imperil vt. 使处于危险，危害

impetus［'ɪmpɪtəs］

n. 推动力；激励物〈同 incentive〉

例　Janet's longing for another kind of life is a major impetus for working hard. 珍妮特对另外一种生活的渴望成为了她努力工作的主要动力。

记　im（进入）+ pet（追求）+ us → 内心追求 → 推动力

联　impetuous adj. 冲动的，鲁莽的；impervious adj. 密封的

自我检测　从第一部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

6. A vaccination can make a person practically ______ to polio（脊髓灰质炎；小儿麻痹症）.

7. Ambition is an ______ to work for success.

8. It is ______ that you pay your taxes on time.

9. The ______ child made up stories about life on other planets.

10. She was totally ______ in the book she was reading.

11. They ______ the news of their engagement to their families.



第二部分

implicit［ɪm'plɪsɪt］

adj. 不明确的，含蓄的〈同 implied〉

例　My boss's surly facial expression was an implicit message that we did something wrong. 老板阴沉沉的表情暗示着我们犯了错误。

记　im（进入）+ plic（重叠）+ it（意义）→ 叠在里面 → 含蓄的

联　implicative adj. 含蓄的；implicate vt. 暗示，使牵连；explicit adj. 清楚的

imply［ɪm'plaɪ］

vt. 暗示，意味〈同 suggest, hint〉

例　The teacher's smile implied that she had forgiven us. 老师的微笑表明她已经原谅了我们。

impress［ɪm'pres］

vt. ① 印，盖印

例　A pattern of flowers had been impressed onto the cloth. 花的图案已经印在了这块布上。

② 给…以深刻印象

例　Mr. Bao impressed Janet with his honesty and kindness. 包先生的诚实和友善给珍妮特留下了深刻的印象。

联　impression n. 印象；impressive adj. 给人深刻印象的；impressionable adj. 容易受感动的，易受影响的；impresario n.（剧团）经理；imprint vt. 盖印于





impulse［'ɪmpʌls］

n. 冲动；刺激，驱使〈同 urge, force〉

例　She was so hot that she had the impulse to jump into the pool even with her clothes on. 她实在是太热了，有一股不脱衣服就想跳到池塘里的冲动。

inaugurate［ɪ'nɔ:gjʊreɪt］

vt. ① 创新，开辟〈同 begin, initiate〉

例　The health club inaugurated a morning exercise session, which they did not have before. 这个健康俱乐部开创了一个他们以前从未有过的晨练项目。

② 使就职〈同 install〉

例　The new president was inaugurated with much ceremony. 新任总统举行了盛大的就职仪式。

记　in（进入）+ augur（预示，开始）+ ate → 开始进入 → 使就职

联　inauguration n. 就职典礼，开幕式；augury n. 占卜，预言

incentive［ɪn'sentɪv］

n. 动机；刺激；鼓励〈同 motivation〉

例　The theater offered two tickets for the price of one as an incentive to draw customers. 电影院推出电影票买一赠一的促销活动，以吸引更多的消费者。

记　in（进入）+ cent（= cant 唱，说）+ ive → 说服人做事 → 刺激；鼓励

联　incense n. 熏香，熏香的烟 vt. 激怒；inception n. 起初，获得学位

incidence［'ɪnsɪdəns］

n. 发生，出现；发生率〈同 occurrence〉

例　In an epidemic the incidence of a disease is widespread. 传染病流行时，到处都是被感染的人。

联　incident n. 事件，事变

incidentally［ɪnsɪ'dentəli］

adv. 附带地，偶然地〈同 by chance〉

例　She wanted to tell me how hard-working she is, and only incidentally mentioned that she hadn't eaten. 她想告诉我她的工作有多努力，只是顺便提了一下她还没有吃饭。

inclusive［ɪn'klu:sɪv］

adj. 包含的，包括的〈同 being included〉

例　This meeting will run from January 10 to February 15 inclusive. 会议将从1月10日持续到2月15日（含2月15日）。

incorporate［ɪn'kɔ:pəreɪt］

vt. 合并，并入；包含〈同 merge, contain〉

例　It is hard to incorporate all his ideas in the new model of the car. 这辆新型汽车很难体现他所有的想法。

记　in（进入）+ corpor（团体）+ ate → 进入团体 → 合并

联　incorporation n. 结合，合并；corporation n. 公司，企业；corps n. 军团，兵种；corporeal adj. 肉体的，物质的；corpse n. 尸体

自我检测　从第二部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

12.“Read pages 10 to 20 ______”means“Begin with page 10 and read through to the very end of page 20.”

13. The fun of playing the game was a greater ______ than the prize.

14. Her opposition to the present tax laws was ______ in her speech on tax reform.

15. We will ______ your suggestion in this new plan.

16. A new President of the United States is ______ every four or eight years.

17. She repeated the words to ______ them on her memory.



第三部分

incur［ɪn'kɜ:(r)］

vt. 招致，引起〈同 cause〉

例　Janet incurred her boyfriend's anger for telling a lie. 珍妮特因为说谎而惹怒了男朋友。

记　in（进入）+ cur（跑）→ 引着跑进来 → 招致

联　incurable adj. 不能治愈的；incursive adj. 侵入的，侵略的；inculpate vt. 使…有罪，控告

indefinite［ɪn'defɪnɪt］

adj. 模糊的；不明确的〈同 uncertain〉

例　You should give the worker a deadline, not an indefinite time, to finish this work. 你应该给工人规定一个完成工作的最后日期，而不是给他们一个不明确的时间。

联　indefinitely adv. 不确定地，无穷尽地

independence［ˌɪndɪ'pendəns］

n. 独立，自主〈同 freedom〉

例　The rebels fought to win independence for their country. 反抗者为赢得国家的独立而战斗。

联　independent adj. 独立的，自主的

indignant［ɪn'dɪgnənt］

adj.（因错事或不公正的事而）愤怒的，愤慨的〈同 angry〉

例　He was indignant when his girlfriend didn't show up at his mother's birthday party. 他女朋友没有在他母亲的生日派对上露面，这让他很愤怒。

记　in（不）+ dign（礼貌）+ ant → 不礼貌 → 愤慨的

联　indignation n. 愤慨，义愤；indignity n. 轻蔑，侮辱；indigent adj. 贫困的

induce［ɪn'dju:s; (US)ɪn'du:s］

vt. 诱使，促使；导致〈同 influence, cause〉

例　She was induced to move out of the city because of the increase in crime. 犯罪率上升促使她搬离这座城市。

记　in（进入）+ duce（引导）→ 诱使；导致

联　inducement n. 引诱物；inductive adj. 诱导的；deduce vt. 推论，演绎出；inductile adj. 没有延展性的

indulge［ɪn'dʌlʤ］

v.（使）沉溺（于）；纵容〈同 pamper〉

例　Janet is an easily angered person and often indulges in fits of temper. 珍妮特是一个很容易生气的人，她经常动不动就发脾气。

联　indulgent adj. 纵容的；indulgence n. 放任

industrious［ɪn'dʌstrɪəs］

adj. 勤勉的；勤奋的〈同 assiduous, diligent〉

例　Janet is a very industrious assistant; she works day in and day out. 珍妮特是一个非常勤奋的助理，没白天没黑夜地工作。

记　industr(y)（勤劳，勤奋）+ ious → 勤勉的

联　industrialize v. 工业化；industrialist n. 工业家，实业家；industrial adj. 工业的





inert［ɪ'nɜ:t］

adj. 惰性的；不活泼的〈同 inactive〉

例　Helium and neon are inert gases. 氦和氖是惰性气体。

联　inertia n.【物】惯性

infectious［ɪn'fekʃəs］

adj. 传染性的，易传染的〈同 contagious〉

例　Don't approach her; because she has an infectious disease. 不要接近她，她有传染病。

联　infect v.（受）传染；infeasible adj. 不可实行的

infer［ɪn'fɜ:(r)］

v. 推论，推断〈同 deduce〉

例　I inferred from the smell that he had just smoked. 我从他身上的气味可以推断出他刚抽完烟。

18. He was ______ because he worked the whole night yesterday and now felt very sleepy.

19. You must be ______ in order to succeed in your own business.

20.“Maybe”is a very ______ answer.

21. Advertisements ______ people to buy.

22. The gambler ______ heavy debts, but he could not quit gambling.

23. I ______ from the smoke that something was burning.



第四部分

inferior［ɪn'fɪərɪə(r)］

adj.（质量等）差的；（等级、社会地位等）较低的〈同 poor, lower〉

例　She's so clever, and she makes me feel inferior. 她太聪明了，让我自惭形秽。

记　infer（低下）+ ior → 低下的

联　superior adj. 上级的，较好的；infernal adj. 阴间的，恶魔的；inferno n. 阴间，地狱；infertile adj. 不肥沃的，贫瘠的

inflict［ɪn'flɪkt］

vt. 造成；使遭受（痛苦、损伤等）〈同 cause, impose〉

例　The economic depression has inflicted heavy losses in Asia. 经济衰退使亚洲遭受了重大的损失。

记　in（进入）+ flict（打击）→ 进入打击 → 使遭受（痛苦、损伤等）

联　infliction n. 施加，痛苦，负担；conflict n./vi. 冲突，斗争；afflict vt. 使苦恼，折磨；affliction n. 苦恼，痛苦；inflect v. 弯曲，使屈曲

ingenious［ɪn'ʤi:nɪəs］

adj. 机灵的，有独创性的〈同 clever, inventive〉

例　Bob devised an ingenious plan to cheat on his income tax. 鲍勃设计了一个巧妙的计划来逃避所得税。

记　in（内在）+ gen（产生）+ ious → 聪明产生于内在 → 机灵的

联　ingenuity n. 灵巧，精巧；genius n. 天才，天赋；ingenuous adj. 坦白的，直率的

inhabit［ɪn'hæbɪt］

vt. 居住于，栖息于〈同 live in, occupy〉

例　These remote islands are inhabited only by some animals. 只有一些动物在这些偏僻的岛屿上生存。

联　inhabitant n. 居民，住户；habitat n. 栖息地

inherent［ɪn'hɪərənt］

adj. 固有的，内在的〈同 intrinsic, built in〉

例　The ability to fly is an inherent trait of birds. 飞翔是鸟儿与生俱来的本领。

联　inherit vt. 继承，遗传

inhibit［ɪn'hɪbɪt］

vt. 抑制，阻止〈同 restrain, deter〉

例　Poverty inhibited him from going to school to study. 他穷得上不起学。

initiate［ɪ'nɪʃɪeɪt］

vt. 开始，发起〈同 begin, originate〉

例　Although Canada's Parliament can neither administer or enforce laws nor initiate policy, it does have the power to make laws and vote on the allocation of funds. 尽管加拿大议会既没有执法的权力，也没有启动政策的权力，但是它有权力制定法律，并且在资金分配方面有投票权。

联　initially adv. 最初，开头；initiative n. 主动，积极性；initial adj. 最初的；ingratiate vt. 使迎合，使讨好；satiate vt. 满足；propitiate vt. 讨好，抚慰

inject［ɪn'ʤekt］

vt. 注射；注入，灌输〈同 infuse〉

例　A nurse has to take care not to inject air into the patient's bloodstream. 护士必须要小心，不要把空气注射到患者的血液里。

联　injection n. 注入；eject vt. 逐出，喷射出；abject adj. 卑鄙的，可怜的；interject vt. 插嘴，突然插入





innovation［ˌɪnə'veɪʃən］

n. 改革，创新〈同 novelty〉

例　The inventor felt that his self-polishing shoes would be an important innovation in the fashion industry. 发明人认为他的免擦鞋可能是时尚界一项重要的发明。

联　innovative adj. 创新的，革新的；innovator n. 改革者，革新者

innumerable［ɪ'nju:mərəbəl］

adj. 无数的，数不清的〈同 countless〉

例　Stars in the summer sky are so innumerable that nobody would try to count them. 夏天夜空中的星星多得数不清。

记　in（不）+ numer（数目）+ able → 无数的

联　number n. 数字，数量；numerate v. 数，计算

27. The inventor created an ______ device that irons your clothes while you sleep.

Lesson 16





音频



预备测验

找出与句子中划线单词意义最相近的词。

1. The kidnapping of pets has become a national problem.

(A) abduction

(B) poisoning

(C) desertion

2. You must have insight into the international market.

(A) experience with

(B) identification with

(C) understanding of

3. He refused to be intimidated by the gang.

(A) inspired

(B) applauded

(C) threated

4. We decided to pay for the furniture on the installment plan.

(A) cash and carry

(B) hire purchase

(C) piece by piece

5. The politician's conviction for tax fraud jeopardized his future in public life.

(A) jettisoned

(B) penalized

(C) endangered



第一部分

insane［ɪn'seɪn］

adj. 精神失常的，疯狂的〈同 crazy〉

例　The teacher refused their insane plea to cross the ocean in a canoe. 老师拒绝了他们乘坐独木舟横跨海洋的疯狂要求。

记　in（不）+ sane（清醒的，神智正常的）→ 精神失常的

联　insanity n. 精神错乱，疯狂；insanitary adj. 不卫生的；insatiable adj. 无法满足的，贪得无厌的；insalutary adj. 不健康的

insight［'ɪnsaɪt］

n. 洞察力，见识〈同 understanding〉

例　Alice's insight into the stock market was incredible and helped her make a large sum of money. 艾丽斯对股市敏锐的洞察力使她赚了很多钱。

记　in（进入）+ sight（眼光）→ 眼光看进去 → 洞察力

联　insightful adj. 富有洞察力的，有深刻见解的；insidious adj. 阴险的；insignia n. 勋章

inspect［ɪn'spekt］

vt. 检查；审查〈同 look over, examine〉

例　You should inspect the car before buying it. 在买车之前，你应该验车。

联　inspection n. 检查；inspector n. 检查员，巡视员；introspection n. 反省，内省；aspect n. 方面；circumspect adj. 慎重的；prospect n. 前景；suspect v. 怀疑





installment［ɪn'stɔ:lmənt］

n. 分期付款〈同 hire purchase〉

例　The table cost $100; we paid for it in two installments of $50 each. 这张桌子100美元，我们分两期付款，每期50美元。

instantaneous［ˌɪnstən'teɪnɪəs］

adj. 瞬间的，即刻的〈同 instant〉

例　He gave me an instantaneous response without considering his words first. 他没有先斟酌语言，就马上回答了我。

记　instant（马上的，立即的）+ aneous → 即刻的

联　instance n. 例子，事例

institute［'ɪnstɪtju:t; (US)'ɪnstɪtu:t］

n. 学院；学会，协会

例　An art institute teaches or displays art. 艺术学院讲授艺术知识或者展览艺术品。

vt. 制定；开始；着手（调查等）〈同 start, establish〉

例　The police instituted a probe into the murder. 警察就谋杀案展开调查。

记　in（进入）+ stitute（站）→ 站进去 → 制定；着手（调查等）

联　institutor n. 设立者；institution n. 公共机构，制度；constitution n. 宪法，规章；restitution n. 赔偿；destitute adj. 缺乏的

instrumental［ˌɪnstrʊ'mentəl］

adj. 有帮助的，可作为手段的〈同 effective, helpful〉

例　Radio and television are instrumental in providing information to the public. 广播和电视有助于为公众提供信息。

insulate［'ɪnsjʊleɪt; (US)'ɪnsəleɪt］

vt. 使绝缘或隔热；隔离〈同 isolate〉

例　Telephone wires are often insulated by a covering of rubber. 电话线通常由橡胶包裹绝缘。

记　insul（岛）+ ate → 像岛一样 → 隔离

联　insulator n. 绝缘体；insular adj. 岛国的，岛民的，思想狭隘的；insulin n. 胰岛素；peninsula n. 半岛

insurance［ɪn'ʃʊərəns］

n. 保险；保险费，保险单〈同 protection, assurance〉

例　Fire, burglary, accident, life and health are some of the many kinds of insurance. 保险有许多种：火险、盗窃险、交通意外险、人身意外险以及健康险等。

联　insure v.（给…）保险，确保

intact［ɪn'tækt］

adj. 尚未被人碰过的，完整的〈同 whole, unaltered〉

例　The building remained intact after hundreds of years solely because it was carefully designed and constructed. 这栋建筑在数百年之后仍完整无损，就是因为它是精心设计和建造的。

记　in（不）+ tact（接触）→ 未接触过 → 完整的

联　intactness n. 完整无缺，未受损伤；contact n./v. 接触，联系；tact n. 机智，手法；tactic n. 策略，战略；tactile adj. 接触的，有触觉的

自我检测　从第一部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

6. Government officials ______ factories and mines to make sure that they are safe for workers.

7. A technical school or college is often called an ______.

8. The money was returned ______ by the person who found it.

9. A strong resume was ______ in getting me a job.

10. Take the machine apart and get an ______ into how it works.

11. After spending twenty years alone in the mountains, the hermit（隐居者）was slightly ______.



第二部分

integral［'ɪntɪgrəl］

adj. 整体的；构成整体所需要的〈同 complete, essential〉

例　He is an integral part of the team and we can't win without him. 他是我们队不可或缺的一部分，没有他我们不可能获胜。

联　integrate vt. 使成整体，使一体化

integrity［ɪn'tegrəti］

n. 完整性；正直，诚实〈同 honesty〉

例　A person of integrity is respected. 正直的人赢得尊敬。

intellect［'ɪntɪlekt］

n. 智力，理解力

例　Early philosophers believed that the mind was divided into three faculties known as emotion, intellect and will. 早期的哲学家认为头脑有三种功能：情感、智力和意志。

联　intelligence n. 智力，聪明；intellectual n. 知识分子

intelligible［ɪn'tenlɪʤəbəl］

adj. 明了的，可理解的〈同 understandable〉

例　The biology article is not really intelligible unless you already know a lot about genetics. 除非你了解很多遗传学的知识，否则你很难读懂这篇生物学文章。

intensify［ɪn'tensɪfaɪ］

vt. 加强；扩大〈同 strengthen, magnify〉

例　We'll have to intensify our efforts if we want to finish this project on time. 如果我们想按时完成这个项目，就得更加努力。

联　intense adj. 强烈的，剧烈的；intensive adj. 强烈的；intension n. 紧张；intention n. 意图，目的；extensive adj. 广阔的，广泛的

intensive［ɪn'tensɪv］

adj. 加强的；集中的，密集的〈同 thorough, concentrated〉

例　Janet took an intensive TOEFL course and gained a relatively high score. 珍妮特参加了一个托福强化班，取得了比较高的分数。

intent［ɪn'tent］

n. 意图〈同 purpose〉

例　I'm sorry if I hurt you; that wasn't my intent. 如果伤到你了，对不起，我不是有意的。

interim［'ɪntərɪm］

n. 中间时期，过渡时期〈同 interval〉

例　The new secretary starts in June, but in the interim we have to type letters by ourselves. 新秘书六月份上岗，在这之前，我们得自己打字。

记　inter（在中间）+ im（名词后缀）→ 中间时期

intermittent［ˌɪntə'mɪtənt］

adj. 间歇的，断断续续的〈同 periodic, recurrent〉

例　Many infants are hit by intermittent fevers. 许多婴儿患有间歇热。

记　inter（在中间）+ mit（送）+ tent → 在中间送东西 → 打断 → 断断续续的

联　intermission n. 间断；intern n. 实习生

internal［ɪn'tɜ:nəl］

adj. 内在的〈同 inside, interior〉

例　The accident victim had internal injuries, although he looked good from the outside. 那位交通事故受害者受了内伤，虽然从外表上看他没什么事。

联　external adj. 外部的

自我检测　从第二部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

12. Janet trusts Mr. Bao without any doubt for he is a man of the highest ______.

13. Our efforts must ______ if we are to succeed.

14. The fitting-out works of my new house hasn't finished yet, so in the ______ I have to stay in my friend's apartment.

15. They carried out an ______ search of the building for bombs after they received the bomb threat.

16. He is very smart and has a high value on ______.

17. Steel is an ______ part of a modern skyscraper.



第三部分

intervene［ˌɪntə'vi:n］

vi. 介入，干涉〈同 interfere〉

例　The Central Bank intervened in the currency markets today in order to try to stabilize the exchange rate. 中央银行今天干预了货币市场以稳定汇率。

记　inter + vene（来）→ 来到中间 → 干涉

联　intervention n. 干涉，介入；interview vt. 接见，会见；interweave v.（使）交织，织进

intimidate［ɪn'tɪmɪdeɪt］

vt. 恐吓〈同 scare〉

例　The defendant intimidated the witness into keeping mum. 被告威胁目击证人使其保持沉默。

记　in（使）+ timid（害怕）+ ate → 使人害怕 → 恐吓

联　intimate adj. 亲密的





intricate［'ɪntrɪkɪt］

adj. 复杂的，错综的〈同 complex〉

例　The police officers who interrogated the suspects were involved in an intricate web of deceit. 审问嫌疑犯的警察被卷入了错综复杂的谎言里。

联　intricately adv. 复杂难懂地，杂乱地

intriguing［ɪn'tri:gɪŋ］

adj. 吸引人的，引起兴趣（或好奇心）的〈同 interesting〉

例　The book's intriguing title caught my attention. 这本书的书名很有趣，引起了我的注意。

记　in（使）+ trigu(e)（引出，引发）+ ing → 引起兴趣（或好奇心）的

联　intrigue n. 阴谋，诡计 vt. 搞阴谋诡计，激起好奇心；trigger vt. 引发，引起 n. 扳机

intrinsic［ɪn'trɪnsɪk］

adj. 固有的，内在的〈同 inherent〉

例　The intrinsic value of the jewellery is very little, but because it was owned by a film star its actual value is very high. 这件珠宝本身很便宜，但由于它曾属于一位电影明星，所以实际价值很高。

intuition［ˌɪntju:'ɪʃən; (US)ˌɪntu:'ɪʃən］

n. 直觉；直觉知识；直觉感知的事〈同 instinct〉

例　Her intuition told her it was dangerous to drive across this old wooden bridge. 直觉告诉她，驱车穿过这座古老的木桥是危险的。

invalid［ɪn'væli:d］

adj. 无效的〈同 void〉

例　All passes for the movie are invalid on weekends. 这部电影的所有免费入场券在周末都无效。

联　invalidity n. 无效力；validate vt. 使有效，证实

invariably［ɪn'verɪəbəli］

adv. 不变地，总是〈同 constantly, always〉

例　The trains are invariably late so there's no need to hurry. 列车总是晚点，所以不用着急。

inventory［'ɪnvəntəri; (US)'ɪnvəntɔ:ri］

n. 存货清单；库存品〈同 check list〉

例　The clerk checked the inventory to see if large paper clips were available. 店员查看存货清单，想知道大号回形针是否还有货。

记　in（进入）+ vent（来）+ ory → 进入仓库来对库存货物进行清查 → 库存品

联　invention n. 发明；inventor n. 发明家；ventilation n. 通风，空气流通

invert［ɪn'vɜ:t］

vt. 上下倒置；倒转〈同 turn upside down〉

例　I inverted the pan and the cake dropped onto the table. 我弄翻了锅，蛋糕掉在了桌子上。

联　avert vt. 避开；convert v. 转化；divert v.（使）转向

自我检测　从第三部分中选出最适当的词填入空格内。

18. By dealing with many kinds of patients, the doctor had developed great powers of ______ .

19. A mystery story usually has a very ______ plot.

20. An ______ of property or goods tells how many there are of each article.

21. The aggression of the male moose（驼鹿）in the fall is of an ______ nature.

22. They were ______ into accepting a pay cut by the threat of losing their jobs.

23. Spring ______ follows winter.



第四部分

irony［'aɪərəni］

n. 反讽，讽刺〈同 satire〉

例　The tallest person was called“Shorty”in irony. 个子最高的人被反讽为矮子。

联　ironic adj. 讽刺的

irrespective［ˌɪrɪ'spektɪv］

adj. 不顾的，不考虑的〈同 regardless〉

例　All pupils, irrespective of age, may join the club. 所有学生都可以加入俱乐部，不限年龄。

irrigate［'ɪrɪgeɪt］

vt. 灌溉〈同 water〉

例　The government is devising a plan to build reservoirs and pumping stations to irrigate land in the northeastern region. 政府正计划修建几座水库和泵站来灌溉东北地区的土地。

联　irrigation n. 灌溉

irritate［'ɪrɪteɪt］

vt. 激怒；使过敏〈同 provoke, annoy〉

例　When he has a headache, even the slightest noise irritates him. 当他头疼的时候，即使是轻微的声响都能激怒他。

联　irritant n. 刺激物；irritable adj. 易怒的，急躁的





jeopardize［'ʤepədaɪz］

vt. 危害，使陷于险境〈同 harm〉

例　Janet decided to quit smoking, because it jeopardizes her health. 珍妮特决定戒烟，因为抽烟危害了她的健康。

记　jeopard（危及）+ ize → 使处于危险中 → 危害

联　jeopardy n. 危险；jeopardous adj. 危险的；leopard n. 豹；hazard n. 危险；blizzard n. 大风雪

jerk［ʤɜ:k］

n./v. 急拉；猛然一动（或颤动）〈同 sudden pull〉

例　The train stopped with a jerk. 火车猛地一颠，停住了。

junction［'ʤʌŋkʃən］

n. 连接；汇合处〈同 joint, intersection〉

例　The junction of the two rivers results in a large flow of water downstream. 两条河汇流，导致了下游的大水流量。

联　juncture n. 接合，接缝；adjunction n. 附属物，添加物；conjunction n. 联合，连接

justice［'ʤʌstɪs］

n. 正义，公平，公正〈同 fairness〉

例　Judges should have a sense of justice. 法官应该有正义感。

记　just（正义的）+ ice → 正义

联　justify vt. 证明…是正当的；injustice n. 不公平；justly adv. 公正地，正当地

kidnap［'kɪdnæp］

vt./n. 绑架〈同 abduct〉

例　The wife of a businessman has been kidnapped from her home and the kidnappers are asking her husband for money. 一位商人的妻子被人从家里绑架走了，绑匪正在向她的丈夫索要赎金。

kit［kɪt］

n. 成套工具；工具包，工具箱

例　I keep a tool kit in the back of my car. 我在汽车的后备箱里放着一个工具箱。

27. I cannot use that brand of soap, because it ______ my skin.
