前言

本丛书专为哪些人编写？

◎ 准备参加TOEFL、IELTS、GRE、GMAT等考试，但英语水平或词汇量不足，难以直接复习备考，需要实实在在、循序渐进提高词汇量及英文水平的人——本丛书词汇从“Vocabulary Basic”开始，难度逐级提高，直到“Vocabulary 23000”。

◎ 准备参加大学英语四级考试的人——“Vocabulary Basic”包括了《大学英语教学大纲》规定的英语四级应掌握的全部核心词汇。

◎ 准备参加大学英语六级考试的人——“Vocabulary Basic”+“Vocabulary 6000”，包括了《大学英语教学大纲》规定的英语六级应掌握的全部核心词汇。

◎ 准备参加TOEFL、研究生入学等考试的人——“Vocabulary Basic”+“Vocabulary 6000”+“Vocabulary 12000”，包含了TOEFL、研究生入学考试应掌握的全部核心词汇。

◎ 以上所有类型的读者均可首先学习或最后总结学习“Vocabulary 23000”。该书采用“词根词缀”记忆法，为读者构建词汇学习之框架，同时结合“近形”和“同根”记忆法，帮助读者轻松、快速地扩大词汇量。



本丛书有何特点？

◎ 以“课”为单元，每课包括4个部分或3～5个Group，各部分虽只有10个左右的主词，但由其衍生出来的同义、反义、形近、同根、同类词等的量非常之大。这样既可方便读者安排学习进度（每天1～2课），又能够保证其3个月内词汇量迅速达到20000以上。

◎ 每个单词均附有国际音标、词性说明、中文释义、英文例句及译文。

◎ 列出各单词的同义词，帮助读者迅速扩大词汇量。配合联想记忆法，举一反三，事半功倍。

◎ 根据词义精心设计了助记插图，既便于读者更好地理解单词，又为学习增加了趣味性。

◎ 前三册每一部分后均附有习题，以加深读者对所学单词的印象；全四册每一课后均有综合复习，便于读者自我检测对所学单词的了解程度，并增强活用单词的能力。

◎ 附赠MP3录音，可在网络上免费下载，其中包含书中的所有主词和英文例句。录音由英音外教朗读，发音纯正地道，配合学习，效果更佳。

词汇量的增加不可一蹴而就，但是若能采用系统的方法，还是可以缩短扩大词汇量所需的时间。为此，我们特别为全国广大的英语学习者编写了这套词汇丛书。从最基本的“Vocabulary Basic”到足以应付留学考试之需的“Vocabulary 23000”，读者只要按部就班、循序渐进地学习本丛书，必可在最短的时间内取得最大的成效。无论您目前是在校求学或已步入社会，都会发现本系列书籍即是您苦寻已久、增强英文实力的最佳利器。学校老师更可采用本系列书籍作为辅助教材，以弥补平时上课内容之不足。

编者



Lesson 1





音频



Group 1: a=not “不、无、非”

agnostic［æɡ'nɒstɪk］

n. 不可知论者 adj. 不可知论的

解　n. a person who doubts the truth of religion adj. uncertain of all claims to knowledge

例　Rebelling against the religious training of his youth, he was for many years an agnostic. 他年轻的时候就反抗宗教培训，多年来一直是个无神论者。

构　a (=not) + gnost (=to know) + ic

amorphous［ə'mɔ:fəs］

adj. 无定形的

解　having no definite form or distinct shape

例　Unless frozen, water is naturally amorphous. 除了结冰，水在自然状态下是没有形状的。

构　a (=not, without) + morph (=form) + ous





anomalous［ə'nɒmələs］

adj. 反常的，不规则的

解　deviating from the general or common order or type

例　Both geniuses and mad men usually follow anomalous patterns of behavior. 天才和疯子通常都行为异常。

同　anomaly n. 异常，反常；反常的事件

anonymity［ˌænə'nɪmɪti］

n. 无名，匿名

解　state of being nameless

例　The donor of the gift asked the college not to mention him by name; and the dean readily agreed to respect his anonymity. 礼物捐赠人要求学院不要提起他的姓名，院长欣然同意尊重他的匿名请求。

构　an (=not, without) + onym (=name) + ity

apathy［'æpəθi］

n. 漠然，冷淡

解　the trait of lacking enthusiasm for or interest in things generally

例　The people's apathy towards pollution contributed to the destruction of the environment. 人们对污染的冷漠导致了对环境的破坏。

近　pithy adj. （讲话或文章）简练的

同　apathetic adj. 冷漠的，无动于衷的

构　a (=not, without) + path (=to feel) + y

atrophy［'ætrəfi］

n. ① 【医】萎缩，萎缩症 ② 衰退

解　① a decrease in size of an organ caused by disease or disuse ② any weakening or degeneration (especially through lack of use)

例　Medical experts state that almost every case of muscle and tissue atrophy is the result of changes in cell nutrition, disease, or prolonged disuse. 医学专家称，几乎所有肌肉和组织萎缩都是由细胞营养的变化、疾病或长期不运动所引起的。

近　trophy n. 奖品，战利品；troupe n. 剧团；歌唱团

构　a (=not, without) + troph (=nourishment) + y



Group 2: acid, acri, ac=acid; bitter, harsh “酸；尖酸，锐利”

acid［'æsɪd］

adj. ① 酸的 ② 尖刻的

解　① sharp or biting to the taste; sour ② sharp in manner or temper

例　Lemons are an acid fruit. 柠檬是一种酸味水果。

acrid［'ækrɪd］

adj. ① （气味等）刺激的，辛辣的 ② 刻薄的

解　① strong and sharp ② harsh or corrosive in tone

例　Acrid coal smoke made my eyes water. 刺鼻的煤烟把我的眼睛熏得流泪。

同　acridity n. （气味等）辛辣，刺激

acrimonious［ˌækrɪ'məʊnjəs］

adj. 言词或语调等刻薄的，激烈的

解　bitter and caustic in temper, manner, or speech

例　An acrimonious dispute broke out between the drivers who had the accident. 一场激烈的冲突在发生事故的司机之间爆发了。

同　acrimony n. 尖刻，刻薄

近　parsimonious adj. 太节省的，小气的

acute［ə'kjʊ:t］

adj. ① 灵敏的，敏锐的 ② （病）急性的，剧烈的

解　① quick in perceiving and responding to impressions; keen ② afflicted by a disease exhibiting a rapid onset followed by a short, severe course

例　Dogs have an acute sense of smell. 狗有着敏锐的嗅觉。

同　acuity n. 敏锐，灵敏

acumen［ə'kjʊ:mən］

n. 精明，敏锐，明智

解　shrewdness shown by keen insight

例　Sherlock Holmes' acumen helped him solve hundreds of mysteries. 夏洛克·福尔摩斯的聪明帮助他破解了数百个谜案。





acerbic［ə'sɜ:bɪk］

adj. ① 酸的 ② 尖刻的

解　① sour or bitter in taste ② harsh or corrosive in tone

例　You should not eat the fruit if it is not ripe, since it will probably taste acerbic. 你应该等水果熟了再吃，不然可能会很酸。

exacerbate［ɪk'sæsɜ:beɪt］

v. 加重，恶化

解　to make worse; to aggravate

例　His lies to cover up his previous lies only served to exacerbate his troubles. 他用谎言来弥补之前的谎言，只能加重他的麻烦。

构　ex (=intensive) + acerb (=bitter, harsh) + ate



Group 3: act=act “行动”

action［'ækʃən］

n. 行为，行动

解　the state or process of acting or doing; a deed

例　The judge told her she had to be responsible for her actions. 法官告诉她要为自己的行为负责。

interaction［ˌɪntər'ækʃən］

n. 相互作用（影响）

解　a mutual or reciprocal action; interacting

例　The study found that the interaction people have with their parents as they grow up is pivotal in creating a sound psychological foundation for them. 研究发现，人们在成长过程中与父母间的相互影响，对他们形成健康的心理基础至关重要。

radioactive［ˌreɪdɪəʊ'æktɪv］

adj. 放射性的，辐射性的

解　of or exhibiting radioactivity

例　Radium, uranium, and thorium are radioactive metallic elements. 镭、铀和钍都属于放射性金属元素。

activate［'æktɪveɪt］

vt. 刺激，激发，使活动

解　to set in motion; to make active or more active

例　The driving instructor taught her to put the key into the ignition to activate the car. 驾驶教练教她把钥匙插入点火装置来启动车辆。

active［'æktɪv］

adj. ① 积极的，活跃的 ② 活性的

解　① working hard or with energy; busy and energetic; lively ② working

例　The professor was very active in his lectures, throwing his hands in the air and jumping up and down. 教授在讲课过程中很活跃，挥舞双手，跳上跳下。

同　activity n. 活动；活跃，活力

enact［ɪ'nækt］

v. ① 制定 （法律）② 扮演（角色）

解　① to make into law ② to play

例　Congress enacted a bill to restrict the sale of guns. 国会制定了一条限制枪支销售的法令。

同　enactment n. （法律、法规的）制定，颁布；扮演

exacting［ɪɡ'zæktɪŋ］

adj. ① 苛求的，要求严格的 ② 吃力的，需付出极大耐心的

解　① requiring much; hard to please ② requiring effort, care, or attention

例　An exacting teacher will not permit careless work. 严格的教师不会允许学生在作业上马马虎虎。

同　exact v. 苛求 adj. 精确的；exactitude n. 精确

构　ex (=out) + act (=to act) + ing

reactionary［ri: 'ækʃənəri］

n. 反动分子，保守分子 adj. 保守的，反动的

解　n. an opponent of progress or liberalism

adj. extremely conservative

例　The reactionaries colluded in a conspiracy to prevent the liberal candidate from being elected president. 反动分子串通一气，阴谋阻止自由党候选人被选为总统。

reactant［ri:'æktənt］

n. 反应剂，反应物

解　a chemical substance that is present at the start of a chemical reaction

例　The chemistry student added the reactant into the liquid to start the experiment. 学化学的学生把反应剂加入液体里，开始了实验。

同　react v. 反应；reaction n. 反应

Lesson 2





音频



Group 4: add=add “加，增加”

addition［ə'dɪʃən］

n. 增加；加法

解　the act of adding one thing to another

例　The addition of new factories around the community would hinder the local air quality. 在社区周围建造新的工厂会影响当地的空气质量。

additional［ə'dɪʃənəl］

adj. 附加的

解　added; extra; more

例　The teacher realized the test was too long and gave the students an additional ten minutes to finish it. 老师意识到测试内容太多，给了学生额外10分钟来完成。

additive［'ædɪtɪv］

n. 添加剂，添加物

解　something added to enhance food or gasoline or paint or medicine

例　The food from fast food restaurants has a lot of chemical additives, such as preservatives. 快餐店的食物有很多化学添加剂，比如防腐剂。

近

addicted adj. 沉溺于某种嗜好中的，上瘾的；addiction n. 沉溺，上瘾



其他与“加，增加”意义有关的词汇

aggrandize v. 增大，扩大（权势、地位、财富等）

augment v. 增大，增值

hike n. （数量、数额的）提高，增加

proliferate v. 繁殖；（数目）激增

accrete v. 因不停地生长而使增大

escalate v. （战争等）升级；扩大，上升





Group 5: agog=lead “引导”

agog［ə'ɡɒɡ］

adj. 兴奋的，热切的，有强烈兴趣的

解　highly excited

例　After four long years, many students were agog to graduate. 漫长的四年之后，许多学生都兴奋地盼着毕业。

pedagogy［'pedəɡɒɡi］

n. 教育学，教学法

解　the profession of a teacher; activities that impart knowledge

例　The English teacher had published her doctoral thesis on the pedagogy of languages. 英语老师出版了她关于语言教学法的博士论文。

近　pediatrics n. 儿科学；pedantic adj. 迂腐的，学究气的；pedantry n. 假装学者，卖弄学问；pedant n. 书呆子，迂腐之人

同　pedagogue n. 教师

demagogue［'deməɡɒɡ］

n. 煽动者，煽动政治家

解　an orator who appeals to the passions and prejudices of his audience

例　The demagogue had been elected senator during the economic depression because of his campaign speeches on implementing economic reform. 在经济萧条时期，那位具有煽动力的政客因为在竞选演讲中提出实施经济改革而被选为参议员。

同　demagogic adj. 煽动的，蛊惑人心的

构　dem (=people) + agog (=to lead) + ue



Group 6: agon=struggle “挣扎，斗争”

agony［'æɡəni］

n. 苦恼，极大的痛苦

解　very painful suffering; very great anguish

例　The loss of their child filled them with agony. 他们失去了自己的孩子，痛苦万分。

同　agonize v. 使极度痛苦，折磨





antagonize［æn'tæɡənaɪz］

v. ① 与…对抗 ② 激怒

解　① to act in opposition to ② to provoke the hostility of

例　The fly antagonized him as he sat peacefully reading a book. 在他平静地坐着看书时，一只苍蝇惹恼了他。

antagonistic［ænˌtæɡə'nɪstɪk］

adj. 对立的，敌对的

解　acting against each other; opposing; hostile

例　Cats and dogs are antagonistic towards each other. 猫类和狗类互相敌视。

同　antagonism n. 对抗，敌对

protagonist［prəʊ'tæɡənɪst］

n. ① 提倡者，支持者 ② （戏剧、故事、小说中的）主角

解　① a proponent; an advocate ② the main character in a drama or other literary work

例　The politician had a group of loyal protagonists help promote his campaign for reelection. 这名政治家有一群忠实的拥护者来帮助他进行连任竞选活动。



Group 7: agra, agri, agro=field; agriculture “田地；农业”

agrarian［ə'ɡrərɪən］

adj. 耕地的，土地的

解　pertaining to the cultivation of land

例　The agrarian society depended mainly on its crops for food, rather than meat from hunting. 农耕社会主要依靠农作物作为食物来源，而不是靠打猎获取肉类。

近　chagrin n./v. 失望，懊恼；saccharin n. 糖精；grin n./v. 露齿笑，咧嘴笑





agriculture［'æɡrɪkʌltʃə(r)］

n. 农业

解　the practice of cultivating the land or raising stock

例　The farmer's son studied agriculture in college so he could return and successfully run the family farm. 这位农民的儿子在大学学习农业，这样他学成归来后就可以成功地经营家庭农场。

agronomy［əɡ'rɒnəmi］

n. 农学

解　the application of soil and plant sciences to land management and crop production

例　The farmer used agronomy to make his farm more productive. 这位农民运用农学使他的农场更加高产。

agronomist［ə'ɡrɒnəmɪst］

n. 农学家

解　scientist engaged in the management of land

例　The professor was an agronomist and he met with local farmers to discuss advances in agricultural science. 这位教授是一位农学家，他与当地的农民们会面，讨论农业科学的进步问题。



Group 8: air, aer=air “空气；充气”

aircraft［'əkrɑ:ft］

n. 飞行器

解　a vehicle that can fly

例　Airplanes, airships, helicopters, and hot air balloons are all aircraft. 飞机、飞艇、直升机和热气球都属于飞行器。

airtight［'ətaɪt］

adj. 密封的

解　not allowing air to pass in or out

例　She put her lunch in an airtight container so it would stay fresh. 她把午餐放到密封容器里，这样可以保鲜。

aerate［'eəreɪt］

v. 充气，让空气进入

解　to fill with a gas

例　Soda water is water that has been aerated with carbon dioxide. 苏打水是压入二氧化碳的水溶液。

anaerobic［ˌæneə'rəʊbɪk］

adj. 【微】没有空气而能生活的，厌氧性的

解　living or active in the absence of oxygen

例　Although the distant planet did not have an oxygenated atmosphere, scientists could not rule out the possible existence of anaerobic life forms. 尽管这颗遥远的星球并不存在有氧环境，但是科学家也不能排除厌氧生命体存在的可能。



其他与“空气”意义有关的词汇

atmosphere n. 大气

gaseous adj. 气体的

gasification n. 气化

oxygen n. 氧，氧气

hydrogen n. 氢气

chlorine n. 氯气

inflate v. 打气，使膨胀；通货膨胀

deflate v. 放气；通货紧缩

aroma n. 芳香，香气

stratosphere n. 大气平流层





Group 9: alter, altru, ali=other “其他的”

alter［'ɔ:ltə(r)］

v. 改变，变更

解　to cause to change; to make different

例　They had to alter their vacation plans to the Caribbean because of the hurricane present there. 由于加勒比海风暴肆虐，他们不得不改变去那儿的休假计划。

alternate［'ɔ:ltəneɪt］

v. 交替，轮流

解　to do something in turns

例　We alternated work and pleasure. 我们劳逸结合。

altruist［'æltrʊɪst］

n. 利他主义者，爱他主义者

解　someone who makes charitable donations intended to increase human well-being

例　The rich altruist made regular donations for homeless people. 这位无私的富翁经常为无家可归的人捐款。

同　altruism n. 利他主义，不自私；altruistic adj. 利他主义的

alias［'eɪlɪəs］

n. 化名，别名

解　a name that has been assumed temporarily

例　The thief had so many aliases that no one knew his real name. 这个小偷有许多化名，没人知道他的真实姓名。

alibi［'ælɪbaɪ］

n. 借口，托辞

解　an explanation offered to avoid blame or justify action; an excuse

例　The inspector was able to put his finger on the weak point in the suspect's alibi. 检察官能准确指出嫌疑人辩辞中的弱点。

近　ad-lib v. 即兴表演；albinism n. 白化病；albino n. 白化病者；album n. 集邮册；相册；唱片

alienate［'eɪlɪəneɪt］

v. 疏远

解　turn from affection to indifference, dislike, or hatred; make unfriendly

例　The other students alienated her because she looked different. 由于她看上去和别人不一样，其他的同学都疏远她。

构　ali (=other) + en (=quality) + ate （动词后缀）

Lesson 3





音频



Group 10: am=love; friendly “爱；友好的”

amateur［'æmətə(r)］

n. 业余爱好者

解　someone who pursues a study or sport as a pastime

例　This painting is the work of an amateur; it shows very little skill. 这幅画是一位业余爱好者的作品，没有什么技巧。

enamor［ɪ'næmə(r)］

vt. 使倾心，使迷恋

解　to inspire with ardent love

例　The princess was enamored with the boy because of his passionate love letters. 公主因为男孩给她写的一些热情洋溢的情书而深深地爱上了他。

近　enamel n. 搪瓷；珐琅

glamorous［'ɡlæmərəs］

adj. 富有魅力的，迷人的

解　full of glamor; fascinating

例　She thought becoming a fashion model would be glamorous. 她觉得成为一名时尚模特会很迷人。

amity［'æməti］

n. 友好

解　peace and friendship; friendly relations

例　If there were amity between nations, there would be no wars. 如果国家与国家之间都相互友好，就不会有战争了。

amenity［ə'mi:nɪti］

n. 舒适，宜人

解　pleasantness resulting from agreeable conditions

例　We went to Hawaii to enjoy the amenity of a warm climate. 我们去了夏威夷，享受到了舒适宜 人 的温暖气候。

近　amnesty n. 大赦，特赦

构　am (=to love) + en (=nature of) + ity





amiable［'eɪmɪəbəl］

adj. 和蔼的，亲切的

解　diffusing warmth and friendliness

例　She has an amiable personality that everyone can get along with. 她的性格和蔼可亲，每个人都能与她和睦相处。

同　amiability n. 和蔼可亲，友善

amicable［'æmɪkəbəl］

adj. 友好的

解　characterized by friendship and goodwill

例　The local people liked the senator because of his amicable and warm personality. 因为这位参议员性格友善而热情，当地老百姓都喜欢他。

构　am (=to love) + ic (=nature of) + able



Group 11: ambi, amphi=both “两个，两种”

ambiguous［æm'bɪɡjʊəs］

adj. 模棱两可的，含糊的

解　having more than one possible meaning

例　The language of poetry cannot be too ambiguous; by nature, it relies on specific, concrete expressions to convey the essence of a feeling. 诗歌的语言不能太含糊不清；从本质上来讲，它依靠确切、具体的词语来表达情感的本质。

同　unambiguous adj. 清楚的；ambiguity n. 模棱两可，含糊不清

ambivalent［æm'bɪvələnt］

adj. （对人或物）有矛盾情绪的，举棋不定的

解　characterized by a mixture of opposite feelings or attitudes

例　At one moment, she seemed fascinating to me, at the next, a little short of revolting; I found it hard to understand my own ambivalent reactions. 在这一刻，我似乎对她很着迷，而在下一刻，我似乎对她又有点厌恶；我发现我很难理解自己矛盾的反应。

同　ambivalence n. 矛盾心理

构　ambi (=both) + val (=worth) + ent

ambidextrous［ˌæmbi'dekstrəs］

adj. 双手灵巧的

解　equally skillful with each hand

例　As an ambidextrous person, she had no problem using chopsticks with her right or left hands. 她是一个双手灵巧的人，使用左右手拿筷子都没问题。

近　dexterity n. 纯熟，灵巧；index n. 索引

构　ambi (=both) + dextr (=right hand) + ous

amphibian［æm'fɪbɪən］

n. 两栖动物

解　cold-blooded vertebrate typically living on land but breeding in water

例　Amphibians are very versatile creatures, being able to live in water or on land. 两栖动物都有着多种本领，既能在水里生存，也能在陆地上生存。

同　amphibious adj. 两栖的

近　ambitious adj. 有雄心抱负的

构　amphi (=both) + bi (=life) + an



Group 12: anim=life; spirit; mind “生命；精神；感觉”

animated［'ænɪmeɪtɪd］

adj. ① 栩栩如生的 ② 活泼的，生机勃勃的

解　① seeming to be alive ② lively; vigorous

例　The clown's animated performance made both the children and the adults laugh. 小丑栩栩如生的表演逗得孩子和大人都哈哈大笑。

同　animate v. 使有生命；animation n. 兴奋，活跃；inanimate adj. 死气沉沉的，无生命的

unanimous［ju:'nænɪməs］

adj. 全体意见一致的

解　in complete agreement

例　The board came to the unanimous decision to elect Olin as president. 董事会一致决定推选奥林为主席。

同　unanimity n. 全体一致，一致同意

pusillanimous［ˌpju:sɪ'lænɪməs］

adj. 懦弱的，胆小的

解　cowardly; fainthearted

例　The pusillanimous elephant ran away at the sight of the mouse. 胆小的大象一看见老鼠就跑掉了。

同　pusillanimity n. 胆小，胆怯

animosity［ˌænɪ'mɒsɪti］

n. 憎恶，仇恨

解　violent hatred; active dislike; ill will

例　The wife held a great deal of animosity towards her ex-husband for the way he had treated her. 妻子因其前夫对待她的方式很恶劣而十分憎恨他。

magnanimous［mæɡ'nænɪməs］

adj. ① 宽宏大量的 ② 慷慨的

解　① understanding and tolerant ② generous

例　The magnanimous emperor released the prisoners of war after the war had ended. 战争结束后，宽宏大量的统治者释放了战犯。

同　magnanimity n. 宽宏大量；慷慨

构　magn (=great) + anim (=mind) + ous



Group 13: anti=against; opposite “抗…；相反”

antibody［'æntɪbɒdi］

n. 抗体

解　a protein substance produced in the blood or tissues in response to a specific antigen, such as a bacterium or a toxin

例　The professor explained to the biology students how our bodies create antibodies in response to foreign substances in our blood. 教授向生物系学生讲解当外来物质进入我们的血液中时，我们的身体是如何产生抗体的。

构　anti (=against) + body (=body)

antibiotic［ˌæntɪbaɪ'ɒtɪk］

n. 抗生素

解　a substance produced by a living organism, especially a bacterium or fungus, that destroys or weakens germs

例　Penicillin is an antibiotic. 青霉素是一种抗生素。

构　anti (=against) + bio (=life) + tic

antidote［'æntɪdəʊt］

n. 解毒剂

解　a remedy or other agent used to neutralize or counteract the effects of a poison

例　They gave the patient an antidote to reverse the course the poison had taken. 他们给病人服用解毒剂来中和毒药的毒性。

构　anti (=against) + dote (=to give)

anticlimax［æntɪ'klaɪmæks］

n. 高潮突降（从上升趋势突然转为令人失望的下降趋势）；虎头蛇尾

解　a disappointing decline after a previous rise

例　After all the suspense for the new movie, the actor's poor performance made the last scene an anticlimax. 这部新电影在前面设置了许多悬念，但这个男演员拙劣的表演使最后一场戏变得虎头蛇尾。

antipathy［æn'tɪpəθi］

n. 憎恶，反感，不相容

解　a feeling of intense dislike

例　Cats naturally have a strong antipathy towards dogs. 猫和狗天生不相容。

构　anti (=against, opposite) + path (=to feel) + y

antique［æn'ti:k］

n. 古董，古物 adj. 古老的，古代的

解　n. something made long ago adj. of times long ago; from times long ago

例　This carved chest is a genuine antique. 这个雕花的箱子是一件真正的古董。





antiquated［'æntɪkweɪtɪd］

adj. ① 陈旧的 ② 过时的

解　① extremely old as seeming to belong to an earlier period ② being out of style or fashion

例　Marine explorers discovered the remains of an antiquated city at the bottom of the ocean. 海洋探险家在海底发现了一座废弃城市的残骸。



Group 14: apo=off “离开，远离”

apophasis［ə'pɒfəsɪs］

n. 【修辞】婉转表达法，表面否认要说或正说的话来加以暗示

解　allusion to something by denying that it will be mentioned

例　The attorney's use of apophasis aimed to discredit his rival without accusing him of anything outright. 这位律师没有直接指控对手的罪行，而是通过婉转表述来达到使其名誉扫地的目的。

apostrophe［ə'pɒstrəfi］

n. 撇号 (')

解　the mark (') used to indicate possession as well as the omission of one or more letters from a printed word

例　The apostrophe is used to express possession. 撇号用来表达所有格。

apostasy［ə'pɒstəsi］

n. 背教；脱党

解　a total departure from one's faith or religion

例　His statements revealed his apostasy and he was excommunicated from the church. 他的陈述透露了他的叛教，因此被逐出教会。

同　apostate n. 背教者，变节者

构　apo (=off) + stas (=to stand) + y

apoplectic［ˌæpəʊ'plektɪk］

adj. ① 狂怒的；大怒的 ② 中风的，濒于中风的

解　① extremely angry; furious ② having or inclined to have apoplexy

例　Members of Congress became apoplectic about wasteful government spending. 国会成员对于政府开支的浪费感到非常愤怒。



其他与“离开，远离”意义有关的词汇

deflect v. 偏离，转向

deviate v. 越轨，脱离

deviation n. 背离

disengaged adj. 【机】脱离啮合的；空闲的，无公务在身的

exodus n. 大批离去，成群外出

outgoing adj. 即将离去的

sever v. 切断，脱离

sunder v. 切开，分裂，分离

Group 15: arch, archy=government; rule “政府；统治”

anarchy［'ænəki］

n. 无政府，政治混乱

解　absence of a system of government and law; disorder and confusion; a state of lawlessness and disorder (usually resulting from a failure of government)

例　The assassination of the leaders led to a period of anarchy. 领导人遭遇暗杀导致这个国家陷入无政府主义。

构　an (=not, without) + arch (=government) + y

anarchist［'ænəkɪst］

n. 无政府主义者

解　an advocate of anarchism

例　The anarchist was against any form of government. 无政府主义者抵制任何形式的统治。

hierarchy［'haɪərɑ:ki］

n. ① 阶层；等级制度 ② 层次

解　① categorization of a group of people according to ability or status ② a series in which each element is graded or ranked

例　The church hierarchy includes archbishops, bishops and priests. 教会的等级包括大主教、主教和神父。

近　hieroglyph n. 象形文字，图画文字

monarch［'mɒnək］

n. 君主，帝王

解　the ruler of a nation

例　Queen Victoria was Great Britain's monarch from 1837 to 1901. 从1837年到1901年，维多利亚女王是大不列颠的君主。



其他与“政府；统治”意义有关的词汇

reign n. 统治，统治时期；王朝；领域

government n. 统治；政府

dominant adj. 统治的，主要的

potentate n. 统治者，当权者

aristocracy n. 贵族统治

autocracy n. 独裁统治，独裁政体

coercion n. 强制；高压统治

democracy n. 民主，民主统治

autonomy n. 自治，自主

gerontocracy n. 老人统治

plutocracy n. 财阀统治；富豪

technocracy n. 技术统治





Group 16: arm=arm; weapon “手；武器”

firearm［'faɪərɑ:m］

n. 枪

解　a portable gun

例　You are prohibited from carrying firearms on airplanes. 禁止携带枪支登机。

近　fire n. 火 v. 生火；firefly n. 萤火虫

army［'ɑ:mi］

n. 军队 （陆军）

解　an organization of military land forces

例　The army battled to keep their flag waving. 军队奋力作战，为使国家争光。

disarm［dɪs'ɑ:m］

v. ① 解除武装 ② 缓和，消除（敌意、疑虑），取得…的信任或好感

解　① to take away the weapons from ② to gain the trust or favor of, esp. through friendliness

例　The police disarmed the thief before he could hurt anyone. 警察缴了小偷的械防止他伤害到别人。

同　disarming adj. 使消除的，使解除警戒心的

构　dis (=away) + arm (=weapon)

armada［ɑ:'mɑ:də］

n. 舰队

解　a large fleet

例　The country sent an armada to block any ships from crossing the strait. 国家派遣一支舰队封锁海峡，禁止任何船只进入。

armory［'ɑ:məri］

n. 军械库，兵工厂

解　a place where arms are manufactured

例　The soldiers went to the armory before the battle to choose their favorite weapons. 开战之前，士兵们到军械库挑选自己喜欢的武器。

alarm［ə'lɑ:m］

v. 警告 n. 警报

解　v. to give warning to n. an automatic signal (usually a sound) warning of danger

例　The alarm rang and woke her up. 警报响了起来，把她吵醒了。

同　alarmed adj. 被惊吓的



Group 17: art=art “技巧，诡计”

artifact［'ɑ:tɪfækt］

n. 人工制品

解　a man-made object

例　The artifacts unearthed around the mountain suggested that technically proficient people had lived there centuries ago. 在这座山周围出土的古代器物表明，数百年前这里曾生活着一群技术熟练的人。

artifice［'ɑ:tɪfɪs］

n. ① 诡计 ② 巧办法，机智

解　① subtle but base deception; trickery ② cleverness or skill; ingenuity

例　The spy employed the artifice of disguise to avoid being caught by the authorities. 间谍使用巧妙的伪装来避免被当局抓获。

artificial［ˌɑ:tɪ'fɪʃəl］

adj. ① 人工的 ② 做作的

解　① made by human beings; produced rather than natural ② not genuine or natural

例　When nervous, he had an artificial laugh. 在紧张的时候，他笑起来就很假。

artist［'ɑ:tɪst］

n. 艺术家

解　a person whose creative work shows sensitivity and imagination

例　The versatile artist could draw, paint, sculpt and sing. 这位多才多艺的艺术家既会画画，又会雕刻，而且还会唱歌。

同　artistry n. 艺术技巧；艺术性

artless［'ɑ:tləs］

adj. ① 自然的，不谙世故的 ② 粗俗的

解　① simple and natural; without cunning or deceit ② (of persons) lacking art or knowledge

例　Little children often ask artless questions. 小孩常常会问一些天真的问题。

同　artlessness n. 朴实，天真，自然





Group 18: auto=self “自己”

autobiography［ˌɔ:təʊbaɪ'ɒɡrəfi］

n. 自传，回忆录

解　story of a person's life written by himself

例　He wrote his autobiography during his retirement. 他在退休期间写了一本自传。

构　auto (=self) + bio (=life) + graph (=to write) + y

autocrat［'ɔ:təkræt］

n. 独裁者

解　ruler with unlimited power; monarch with supreme power

例　He ran his office like an autocrat, giving no one else any authority. 他管理办公室像个独裁者，不给其他人一点儿权力。

同　autocracy n. 独裁统治，独裁政体

构　auto (=self) + crat (=to govern)

automatically［ˌɔ:tə'mætɪkli］

adv. 自动地；机械地

解　acting or operating in a manner essentially independent of external influence or control; mechanically

例　In the hotel, the water sprinklers will automatically turn on if they sense smoke in the room. 在酒店，如果洒水喷头感应到了房间里的烟，就会自动开启。

构　auto (=self) + mat (=to move) + ically

autonomy［ɔ:'tɒnəmi］

n. 独立，自治，自主

解　self-government or the right of self-government; self-determination

例　The federal government gives each state a certain extent of autonomy. 联邦政府赋予每个州一定程度的自治权。

构　auto (=self) + nom (=law) + y

automobile［'ɔ:təməbi:l］

n. 汽车

解　a passenger vehicle, for use on roads and streets, that carries its own engine

例　The automobile and the airplane revolutionized transportation. 汽车和飞机使交通出行发生了革命性的变化。

Lesson 5





音频



Group 19: ball=dance; ball “舞；球”

balloon［bə'lu:n］

n. 气球 v. 像气球般鼓起，使激增

解　n. an inverted bag of very light material, which rises and floats in the air v. to become inflated

例　The room was filled with streamers and balloons for the party. 房间里到处都是为聚会而准备的彩色纸带和气球。

balet［'bæleɪ］

n. 芭蕾舞

解　a theatrical representation of a story performed to music by ballet dancers

例　A ballet is a beautiful, graceful dance. 芭蕾是一种美丽而优雅的舞蹈。

ballroom［'bɔ:lrʊm］

n. 大舞厅

解　a large room used mainly for dancing

例　The dance competition was held in the main ballroom of the luxurious hotel. 这个舞蹈比赛在这座豪华酒店的大舞厅举办。

baseball［'beɪsbɔ:l］

n. 棒球

解　a game played with a bat and ball between two teams of 9 players

例　Baseball is a popular recreation for young boys who like to see how far they can hit the ball. 对于想看看自己能把球击多远的年轻人来说，棒球是一种受欢迎的消遣方式。

近　baseboard n. 护壁板；cardboard n. 硬纸板；aboveboard adj. 光明正大的



其他与“舞蹈”意义有关的词汇

tango n. 探戈舞

waltz n. 华尔兹

choreographer n. 舞蹈编排者

choreography n. 舞蹈编排；舞蹈

pirouette n. （舞蹈）脚尖立地的旋转





Group 20: base=low; foundation “低下的；基础”

base［beɪs］

adj. ① 卑鄙的 ② 低级的

解　① morally low or mean ② having little value when compared with something else; inferior

例　People were offended by his base jokes. 人们被他低俗的笑话激怒。

同　baseness n. 卑微

basic［'beɪsɪk］

adj. 基础的

解　of, relating to, or forming a base; fundamental

例　The basic ingredients for success include hard work and a pinch of luck. 成功的基本要素包括努力工作和少许的幸运。

debase［dɪ'beɪs］

v. ① 贬低，降格 ② 降值

解　① to make low or lower ② to lessen the value of

例　They debased themselves through greed. 他们因为贪婪而贬低了自己。

近　baste v. 涂油 （于烤肉上，以防烤干）；debate n./v. 辩论

basement［'beɪsmənt］

n. 地下室

解　the lowermost portion of a structure partly or wholly below ground level, often used for storage

例　It is advisable to store your wine in the basement so it will not be spoiled by the heat. 把酒储藏在地下室是可取的，这样酒就不会由于受热而变质。



Group 21: beat, bat=beat “打、击”

beater［'bi:tə(r)］

n. 搅拌器

解　device or utensil for beating eggs, cream, etc.

例　She used a beater to mix ingredients when making baked goods. 在制作烘焙食品时，她使用搅拌机把各种材料混合在一起。

abate［ə'beɪt］

v. ① 减轻，降低 ② 缓和

解　① to reduce in amount, degree, or intensity; lessen ② to fall off in degree or intensity; subside

例　When the rain abated, we went outside again. 雨变小了之后，我们又出去了。

构　a (=to) + bat (=to beat) + e





baton［'bætən; (US)bə'tɒn］

n. 接力棒；指挥棒

解　a slender wooden stick or rod passed from runner to runner in a relay race or used by a conductor to direct an orchestra

例　If one of the runners in the relay race dropped the baton, the whole relay team would be disqualified. 在接力赛中，如果其中一名队员掉了接力棒，那么整个接力队将失去比赛资格。

battle［'bætəl］

n. 战斗

解　a hostile meeting of opposing military forces in the course of a war

例　The general told his adversary that he may have won the battle, but not the war. 将军告诉他的敌人，他可能赢了这场战役，但赢不了整个战争。

近　belittle v. 轻视；贬低；brittle adj. 易碎的；脆弱的；bristle v. 毛发竖立，气势汹汹 n. 硬毛

combative［'kɒmbətɪv］

adj. 好斗的

解　having or showing a ready disposition to fight

例　The general first sent his most combative soldiers to fight. 将军首先派遣最能征善战的士兵参战。

同　combatant n. 战士



Group 22: bel=war “战争”

rebel［ri'bel］v. 造反，反抗［'rebəl］ n. 反叛者

解　v. to break with established customs

n. a person who takes part in a rebellion in the hopes of improving conditions

例　It is natural for teenagers to rebel against their parents. 反抗父母是青少年的天性。

bellicose［'belɪkəʊs］

adj. 好战的；好斗的

解　having or showing a ready disposition to fight

例　The bellicose warrior always wanted to pick a fight with someone. 这个好斗的勇士总是喜欢寻衅打架。

rebellion［rɪ'beljən］

n. 叛乱

解　organized opposition to authority; a conflict in which one faction tries to wrest control from another

例　The rebellion overthrew the king from his throne. 这场叛乱推翻了国王的统治。

belligerent［bɪ'lɪʤərənt］

adj. 好战的；寻衅的；（国家等）交战的

解　characteristic of an enemy or one eager to fight; warlike

例　The man became belligerent when he drank too much beer. 这个男人喝多了啤酒之后就变得爱寻衅滋事。

同　belligerence n. 好战，好斗

Lesson 6





音频



Group 23: bene=good “好，善”

beneficent［bɪ'nefɪsənt］

adj. 慈善的，仁慈的

解　doing or producing good

例　The beneficent donation helped many children learn how to read and write. 慈善捐助帮助许多孩子学会了读书和写字。

同　beneficence n. 行善，慈善

beneficial［ˌbenɪ'fɪʃəl］

adj. 有益的；有用的

解　favorable; helpful

例　Daily exercise is beneficial to your health. 每天锻炼对身体有益。

构　bene (=good) + fic (=to make, to do) + ial





benevolent［bɪ'nevələnt］

adj. 善意的，好意的

解　intending or showing kindness

例　The benevolent man gave his money and volunteered his time to help the poor and sick. 这位乐善好施的男士自愿捐钱并花时间来帮助那些穷人和病人。

同　benevolence n. 善行；善心，仁心

构　bene (=good) + vol (=will) + ent

benediction［ˌbenɪ'dɪkʃən］

n. 祝福；祈祷

解　the act of praying for divine protection, saying a blessing

例　The priest gave him a benediction for his good deeds. 牧师因他所做的善事而为他祈祷。

构　bene (=good) + dict (=to say) + ion

benefactor［'benɪfæktə(r)］

n. 行善者，捐助人

解　a person who helps people or institutions

例　Pip's benefactor paid for his education and helped him find a job. 皮普的捐助人为他支付了教育费用，并且帮他找到了一份工作。

构　bene (=good) + fact (=to do, to make) + or



其他与“好，善”意义有关的词汇

amicable adj. 友好的

amity n. 友好

goodwill n. 友好，善意

hospitality n. 好客，殷勤

charitable adj. 仁慈的，宽厚的

charity n. 仁慈，慈善；施舍

clemency n. 仁慈，宽厚

leniency n. 仁慈，怜悯

lenient adj. 宽大的；仁慈的

mercy n. 仁慈，宽恕，怜悯

philanthropy n. 慈善事业





Group 24: bi=double; two “两”

bifurcate［'baɪfɜ:keɪt］

v. 分为两支；分叉

解　to divide into two branches

例　The townspeople were bifurcated over whether or not to build a factory in the community. 小镇居民在是否在社区建造工厂这一问题上分为两派。

构　bi (=two) + furc (=fork) + ate

bilingual［baɪ'lɪŋɡwəl］

adj. 双语的 （能说两种语言的）

解　using or knowing two languages

例　Since his parents spoke English and Chinese, he grew up in a bilingual environment. 因为他的父母既说英语，又说中文，他从小在双语的环境中长大。

同　linguist n. 语言学家；linguistics n. 语言学

biped［'baɪped］

n. 两足动物

解　an animal with two feet

例　Humans are among the few species of bipeds on the planet. 人类是地球上少数的两足物种之一。

duality［dju:'æləti］

n. 两重性

解　dual condition or quality

例　His duality was expressed in two identities, Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. 他的双重人格表现在两种身份上：杰基尔博士和海德先生。

duet［dju:'et; (US)du:'et］

n. 二重奏；二重唱

解　a musical composition for two performers

例　The two singers sang a duet together. 两位歌手一起演唱了二重唱。

近　duel n. 决斗；dulcet adj. 美妙的，悦耳的；lancet n. 柳叶刀，采血针



Group 25: body=body “身体”

full-bodied［ˌfʊl'bɒdɪd］

adj. （味道等）浓郁而强烈的

解　marked by richness and fullness of flavor

例　People enjoyed the Italian restaurant because of the full-bodied wine it served with the meals. 人们之所以喜欢这家意大利餐厅，是因为它提供用来佐餐的味道醇厚的葡萄酒。

antibody［'æntɪbɒdi］

n. 抗体

解　substance formed in the blood tending to inhibit or destroy harmful bacteria, etc.

例　The antibodies surrounded and killed the bacteria in his liver. 抗体包围并消灭了他肝脏里的细菌。

bodyguard［'bɒdiɡɑ:d］

n. 保镖，侍卫

解　someone who escorts and protects a prominent person

例　The actress' bodyguard was tall, dark and handsome. 这位女演员的保镖皮肤黝黑，又高又帅。

近　guard n. 哨兵 v. 保卫，保护；guarded adj. 谨慎的，提防的；guardian n. 护卫者；监护人；safeguard n. 防卫措施，防范措施

busybody［'bɪzɪbɒdi］

n. 爱管闲事的人，好事的人

解　a person who meddles in the affairs of others

例　She was a busybody at work, always having something to do. 她在工作上是个爱管闲事的人，总是有事情要做。

disembodied［ˌdɪsɪm'bɒdid］

adj. 无实质的，无实体的

解　not having a material body

例　Ghosts are usually thought of as disembodied spirits. 鬼魂通常被看做是无实体的灵魂。



Group 26: brev, bri=short “短；缩短”

abbreviate［ə'bri:vɪeɪt］

v. 缩写，缩短

解　to reduce in scope while retaining essential elements

例　John Paul abbreviated his name to J.P. 约翰·保罗把他的名字缩写成J.P.。

同　abbreviation n. 缩短，删节；缩写词，略语

构　ab <zad (=to) + brevi (=brief, short) + ate

brevity［'brevəti］

n. 简短，简洁

解　shortness or conciseness of expression

例　The students appreciated the brevity of their principal's speech. 校长的演讲简短有力，学生们非常欣赏。

abridge［ə'brɪʤ］

v. ① 删节 ② 缩短

解　① to reduce the length of (a written text); to condense ② to cut short; to curtail

例　Since the book was very long and detailed, he abridged it to make a new version. 由于这本书内容冗长、细节繁琐，他将其加以删减，形成了一个新的版本。

近　ridge n. 脊 （如屋脊、山脊等）；隆起物；bridge n. 桥；drawbridge n. 吊桥；badge n. 徽章；badger v. 不断纠缠，一再要求

构　a (=to) + bridg < brevi (=to shorten) + e

brief［bri:f］

n. 诉讼摘要；简报 adj. 简短的

解　n. a short statement; summary adj. lasting only a short time; using few words

例　The lawyer prepared a brief of the facts and the points of law in the case. 律师准备了这个案件的事实摘要和法律要点。

debrief［di:'bri:f］

vt. 询问，听取 （飞行员的情况汇报）

解　to question to obtain knowledge or intelligence after a mission has been completed, in order to record information

例　The government officials debriefed the President when he returned back from the negotiations overseas. 总统从海外谈判回来之后，政府官员听取了他所作的工作报告。

Lesson 7





音频



Group 27: calc=stone “石头”

calcium［'kælsɪəm］

n. 钙

解　a soft, silvery-white metallic element

例　Milk is a good source of calcium for growing boys and girls. 牛奶富含钙质，对身体正在发育的孩子很有益处。

近　callous adj. 麻木的，无情的；结硬块的；callow adj. 年轻而无经验的，（人）未成熟的；（鸟）羽毛未丰的

calcification［ˌkælsɪfɪ'keɪʃən］

n. 石化，僵化

解　an inflexible, unchanging state

例　Calcification of his ligament caused a bone spur. 他的韧带钙化形成了骨刺。

recalcitrant［rɪ'kælsɪtrənt］

adj. 固执的，顽抗的

解　marked by stubborn resistance to authority

例　The recalcitrant solider disobeyed his orders. 这名顽抗的士兵违抗了他的命令。

同　recalcitrance n. 固执，顽抗





其他与“石头”意义有关的词汇

boulder n. 巨石，大鹅卵石

crystal n. 晶体，水晶

flint n. 打火石，燧石

granite n. 花岗石

limestone n. 石灰石

marble n. 大理石

pebble n. 小鹅卵石，石子

turquoise n. 绿松石 adj. 碧绿的

shale n. 页岩

quarry n. 采石场；猎物，追求物 v. 采石

ossified adj. 僵化的，石化的





Group 28: cand=white; glowing “白；发光”

candor［'kændə(r)］

n. 坦诚，坦率

解　the quality of being honest and straightforward in attitude and speech

例　She was moved by the candor in his expression of love for her. 她被他的表白中所流露出的坦诚所打动了。

candid［'kændɪd］

adj. 坦诚的

解　openly straightforward and direct without reserve or secretiveness

例　The successful businessman always believed that candid dialogue was the most efficient way to get what you want. 这位成功的商人一直相信坦诚的对话是达到目的最有效的方式。

candle［'kændəl］

n. 蜡烛

解　a stick of wax of tallow with a wick in it, burned to give light

例　Romantic restaurants normally have dimmed lighting, white tablecloth and candles on the tables. 浪漫的餐厅通常灯光暗淡，餐桌上布置着白色的桌布和蜡烛。

incandescent［ˌɪnkæn'desənt］

adj. ① 白热的，白炽的 ② 遇热发光的

解　① red-hot or white-hot; shining brightly ② glowing with heat

例　The embers of the fire were still incandescent even though the flames had disappeared. 尽管火已经灭了，灰烬仍然很炽热。



其他与“发光”意义有关的词汇

flash n./v. 闪光；闪现

glisten v. 闪烁，闪耀

glistening adj. 闪烁的

iridescent adj. 彩虹色的；闪光的

lightning n. 闪电

radiate v. 发光，放热

radiation n. 发光，散发





Group 29: cap=take; head “取；头”

capable［'keɪpəbəl］

adj. 有能力的，能干的

解　having fitness, power, or ability; able

例　She was such a capable teacher that the school appointed her as its principal the next year. 她是一位非常能干的老师，学校任命她从下一年开始担任校长。

同　incapable adj. 无能力的

incapacitate［ˌɪnkə'pæsɪteɪt］

v. 使无能，使无资格

解　to make unable to perform a certain action

例　His illness left him incapacitated for three days. 他的病使得他三天都下不了床。

近　debilitate v. 使衰弱

captious［'kæpʃəs］

adj. 吹毛求疵的

解　tending to find and call attention to faults

例　The old professor had a captious eye, enabling him to catch every mistake in his students' essays. 这位老教授眼光很犀利，能够发现学生论文中的任何一处错误。

capture［'kæptʃə(r)］

v. 逮捕；捕捉

解　to succeed in catching or seizing, esp. after a chase

例　He captured rabbits with a carrot and a metal trap. 他用一个胡萝卜和一个金属陷阱捕获了兔子。

captivate［'kæptɪveɪt］

v. 迷惑，吸引

解　fascinate, as by excellence, eloquence, or beauty

例　The movie captivated the audience and no one could take their eyes off it. 观众被电影深深吸引，没有人能将眼睛挪开。

capitulate［kə'pɪtjʊleɪt］

v. （有条件地）投降

解　to surrender under agreed conditions

例　The general in the fort capitulated under the condition that his soldiers could go free. 堡垒里的将军选择投降，条件是他的士兵们都被释放。

同　capitulation n. 投降





recapitulation［ˌri:kəpɪtjʊ'leɪʃən］

n. 扼要重述

解　a summary that repeats the substance of a longer discussion

例　The official 100-page report ended with a one-page recapitulation of the key points. 这份100页的官方报告的最后一页是要点概括。

音频



Group 30: cata=down; downwards “向下；相反”

cataclysmic［ˌkætə'klɪzmɪk］

adj. 灾难的

解　severely destructive

例　The poor economy has driven companies to a cataclysmic end. 萎靡的经济使许多公司遭受了灭顶之灾。

构　cata (=downwards) + clysm (=to wash) + ic

catastrophe［kə'tæstrəfi］

n. 大灾难，大祸

解　an event resulting in great loss and misfortune

例　The sinking of the Titanic was a historical catastrophe. 泰坦尼克号的沉没是历史上的一个重大灾难。

同　catastrophic adj. 大灾害的

构　cata (=downwards) + stroph (=to turn) + e





catalyze［'kætəlaɪz］

v. 催化，促进

解　to modify, especially increase, the rate of (a chemical reaction) by catalysis

例　Since the experiment was so slow, the chemist added a chemical to catalyze and speed the process. 由于实验反应发生得太慢，这位化学家添加了一种化学物质来催化并加速这一过程。

catalyst［'kætəlɪst］

n. 催化剂；促使事情发展的因素

解　a substance that initiates some event or chemical reactions

例　The introduction of an arbitrator served as a catalyst for the two parties to reach a peaceful accord. 仲裁人的介入促使双方达成了一项和平协议。

同　catalytic adj. 接触反应的



Group 31: cav=hole; hollow “洞；空的，凹的”

cave［keɪv］

n. 洞穴

解　a hollow space underground, especially one with an opening in the side of a hill or mountain

例　The cave was dark and filled with bats. 山洞很暗，到处都是蝙蝠。

近　carve v. 雕刻；（把肉等）切成片；curve n. 曲线

cavern［'kævən］

n. 大洞穴

解　a large cave or a large chamber in a cave

例　The cavern led to an underground city. 这个洞穴通往一座地下城市。

concave［kɒn'keɪv］

adj. 凹的

解　curving inward

例　The inside of his eyeglasses were concave. 他的眼镜内侧是凹的。

excavate［'ekskəveɪt］

v. 挖出，挖掘

解　to remove the inner part or the core of

例　The manager instructed the engineering team to carefully excavate the site. 经理指示工程队在现场小心挖掘。

构　ex (=out of) + cav (=hollow) + ate



Group 32: ced, cess=go; proceed “行走；前进”

accede［æk'si:d］

v. 应允，同意

解　agree or express agreement

例　If I accede to his demand for blackmail, I am afraid that I will be the victim of future demands. 如果我同意了他的勒索要求，我恐怕以后会遭到更多的勒索。

构　ac (=to) + ced (=to go) + e

accessible［ək'sesəbəl］

adj. ① 可接近的，易达到的 ② 可理解的

解　① capable of being reached or obtained ② capable of being read with comprehension

例　The professor was accessible for questions and discussions during his office hours. 在教授办公期间，可以向其提问或与其讨论问题。

构　ac (=to) + cess (=to go) + ible

accessory［æk'sesəri］

adj. 附属的，次要的 n. 附件；附属

解　adj. relating to something that is added but is not essential n. a subordinate or supplementary item; an adjunct

例　The woman loved to go shopping for wardrobe accessories, like shoes, purses and belts. 这位女士喜欢购买服饰搭配品，比如鞋子、手提包和腰带。

concede［kən'si:d］

v. ① 让步 ② 承认

解　① to make a concession; to yield ② to admit as true; acknowledge

例　I conceded that I had made a mistake. 我承认我犯了一个错误。

同　concession n. 让步；特许，特许权

构　con (=with) + ced (=to go) + e

excessive［ɪk'sesɪv］

adj. 过度的，过分的，过多的

解　beyond normal limits

例　The policeman was accused of using excessive force when he punched the innocent man. 这名警察拳击了这位无罪的男子，被指控为滥用武力。

同　excess n. 过多

构　ex (=beyond) + cess (=to go) + ive





antecedent［ˌæntɪ'si:dənt］

n. 先辈；前事 adj. 先行的

解　n. a preceding occurrence or cause or event adj. preceding in time or order

例　Scientists cannot agree on whether the egg or the chicken was the antecedent. 科学家们在“先有鸡还是先有蛋”这个问题上无法达成一致。

近　anterior adj. 较早的，以前的

构　ante (=before) + ced (=to go) + ent

recede［rɪ'si:d］

v. ① 倒退，后退 ② 撤回，撤退

解　① to move back and away from ② to retreat

例　We watched the harbor recede from view as our ship headed out to sea. 随着轮船驶入大海，码头渐渐从我们的视线中消失。

近　rescind v. 废除，取消

构　re (=back) + ced (=to go) + e

recess［rɪ'ses］

n. ① 壁凹 （墙上装架子、柜子等凹处）② 休息；休息、停顿等持续的时间

解　① a space set back or indented ② a pause from doing something (as work) ; the period of such cessation

例　During school recess, the children like to go to the playground and play games. 课间休息时，孩子们喜欢去操场上玩耍。

Lesson 9





音频



Group 33: centr=center “中心”

central［'sentrəl］

adj. ① 中央的 ② 重要的

解　① at the center; near the center ② main; chief

例　The marketing proposal was central to the company's survival in the new markets. 这个营销计划对公司能否在新市场中生存至关重要。

concentrate［'kɒnsentreɪt］

v. 浓缩；集中精力 n. 浓缩液

解　v. to make dense or denser; focus one's attention on sth. n. substance or solution made by concentrating

例　The student concentrated only on his studies during the examination period. 在考试期间，这名学生把所有精力都集中在学习上。

同　concentrated adj. 集中精力的；concentration n. 集中

centrifuge［'sentrɪfju:ʤ］

v. 分离 n. 离心机

解　v. to rotate (something) in a centrifuge or to separate, dehydrate, or test by means of this apparatus

n. such apparatus used for this

例　The chemist used the centrifuge to extract the desired particles from the liquid. 这位化学家使用离心机从液体中提取所要的粒子。

近　refuge n. 庇护

构　centr (=center) + i + fuge (=to flee)

eccentric［ɪk'sentrɪk］

n. 古怪的人 adj. 古怪的，反常的

解　n. a person with an unusual or odd personality adj. conspicuously or grossly unconventional or unusual

例　The new science fiction park attracted many eccentrics who liked to wear alien costumes. 这个新的科幻公园吸引了许多喜欢穿着奇装异服的古怪的人。

同　eccentricity n. 古怪，怪癖；反常

构　ec (=out) + centr (=center) + ic

egocentric［ˌi:ɡəʊ'sentrɪk］

adj. 自我中心的，利己主义的

解　limited to or caring only about yourself and your own needs

例　During medieval times, many men held the egocentric belief that the sun revolved around the earth. 在中世纪，许多人信奉以自我为中心的观念，认为太阳围绕地球旋转。

同　egotist n. 自我主义者



Group 34: circ, cycl=circle; around “圆；环绕”

circular［'sɜ:kjʊlə(r)］

adj. 圆形的

解　shaped like a ring

例　The Board always met at a circular table where everyone was equal. 董事会通常举行圆桌会议，这样人人都是平等的。

circulate［'sɜ:kjʊleɪt］

v. 流通；发行；传播；循环

解　to cause to be distributed; to flow freely, as of air or liquids

例　The boy circulated newspapers to houses throughout the neighborhood. 男孩在小区内挨家投递报纸。

近　articulate v. 发音清晰；清楚地说话；接合；immaculate adj. 洁净的，无瑕的；maculated adj. 有斑点的

同　circulation n. 流通；循环

circuitous［sə'kju(:)ɪtəs］

adj. 迂回的，绕圈子的

解　marked by obliqueness or indirection in speech or conduct; deviating from a straight course

例　The taxi driver took the tourists on a circuitous path to the airport. 出租车司机载着乘客绕路来到机场。

同　circuity n. 迂回，绕行

recycle［ˌri:'saɪkəl］

v. 再循环利用

解　to use again after processing

例　All the families in this neighborhood recycle their plastics and aluminum cans. 这个居民区的所有家庭都对塑料和铝制罐进行了循环利用。





cyclical［'sɪklɪkəl］

adj. 循环的

解　recurring in cycles

例　The cyclical seasons of the year are reversed between the northern and southern hemispheres. 南半球和北半球的四季更替是颠倒的。

近　cynical adj. 玩世不恭的，愤世嫉俗的；cynic n. 玩世不恭的人，愤世嫉俗者；cynicism n. 犬儒主义，愤世嫉俗；cronyism n. 任人唯亲

cyclone［'saɪkləʊn］

n. 旋风，飓风

解　violent rotating windstorm

例　The cyclone swept through the town uprooting trees and knocking down houses. 飓风横扫小镇，把树连根拔起，并且摧毁了房屋。

cylinder［'sɪlɪndə(r)］

n. 圆柱体；气缸

解　a solid bounded by a cylindrical surface and two parallel planes

例　Most people drink beverages from containers that are shaped like cylinders. 大多数人所喝的饮料都装在类似圆柱体的容器内。

encyclopedia［enˌsaɪkləʊ'pi:dɪə］

n. 百科全书

解　a reference work containing articles on various topics

例　The students used the encyclopedia to learn about different world topics. 学生使用百科全书来学习关于世界的不同主题。



Group 35: circum=around “环绕，周围”

circumference［sə'kʌmfərəns］

n. 圆周

解　the length of the closed curve of a circle

例　The circumference of the earth is about 25,000 miles. 地球的赤道周长大约为2.5万英里。

近　interference n. 干预

构　circum (=around) + fer (=to carry) + ence

circumlocution［ˌsɜ:kəmlə'kju:ʃən］

n. 迂回累赘的陈述

解　an indirect way of expressing something

例　The professor set a maximum number of 100 words for the essay so the students' circumlocution would not waste his time. 教授要求文章字数不能超过100字，这样他就不会因为学生的长篇赘述而浪费时间。

构　circum (=around) + locut (=to say) + ion

circumspect［'sɜ:kəmspekt］

adj. 慎重的，仔细的

解　cautious; well-considered; prudent

例　Investigating before taking any action, she tried always to be circumspect. 她在采取行动之前总会先进行调查，努力做到万无一失。

同　circumspection n. 谨慎小心

构　circum (=around) + spect (=to look)

circumvent［ˌsɜ:kəm'vent］

vt. ① 包围，智取 ② 绕行；避开

解　① to get the better of or defeat by trickery; to outwit ② to go around

例　The dishonest officer was always trying to circumvent the law. 这个不老实的官员总想设法规避法律。

构　circum (=around) + vent (=to come)



Group 36: cis=cut “切”

scissors［'sɪzəz］

n. 剪刀

解　a cutting implement having two crossed pivoting blades

例　The technician used scissors to cut the electrical wire. 技工用剪刀剪断了电线。

concise［kən'saɪs］

adj. 简洁的

解　expressing much in few words

例　Poetry is the most concise form of literature. 诗歌是一种最为凝练的文学形式。

构　con (=intensive) + cis (=to cut) + e

同　concision n. 简明，简洁





precis［'preɪsi:; (US)preɪ'si:］

n. 摘要，大纲

解　a summary of the main points of an argument or theory

例　The publishing magazine gave a precis on a new book that was published this summer. 这本出版方面的杂志对今年夏季出版的一本新书作了摘要。

precise［prɪ'saɪs］

adj. 精确的，准确的

解　exact in performance or amount; strictly correct

例　Legal contracts are usually written with precise language to avoid confusion and loopholes. 法律合同的措词通常很精确，这样可以避免混淆和漏洞。

同　precision n. 精确；imprecise adj. 不精确的

incise［ɪn'saɪz］

vt. 切割，雕刻

解　to make an incision into by carving or cutting

例　The cardiac surgeon incised the patient's diaphragm in order to reach his heart. 心脏外科医生切入患者的横膈膜以到达心脏。

同　incision n. 切割，切口

incisive［ɪn'saɪsɪv］

adj. 一针见血的

解　penetrating, clear, and sharp, as in operation or expression

例　The journalist wrote an incisive article about the political scandal. 这名记者写了一篇关于政治丑闻的尖锐的文章。

构　in (=in, into) + cis (=to cut) + ive

excise［ek'saɪz］

v. 切除；删去

解　to remove by erasing or crossing out

例　The doctor excised some scar tissue after the burn was healed. 烧伤痊愈之后，医生切除了一些瘢痕组织。

近　exercise n./v. 练习；运动，锻炼

构　ex (=out) + cis (=to cut) + e



其他与“切”意义有关的词汇

carve v. 雕刻；（把肉等）切成片

hamstring vt. 切断腿筋使成跛腿，使残废

sever v. 切断，脱离

slice v. 切开成片

truncate v. 把（某物）截短，去尾

Group 37: cite, cit=call; set in motion “呼叫；驱策”

excited［ɪk'saɪtɪd］

adj. 激动的

解　marked by uncontrolled excitement or emotion

例　The office staff was excited about the upcoming new year holidays. 职员对即将到来的新年假期感到兴奋。

同　exciting adj. 令人兴奋的；excitement n. 兴奋，激动

incite［ɪn'saɪt］

v. 煽动；激发，刺激

解　to urge on; to stir up; to rouse

例　The speaker incited the audience to quick action. 演讲者激励听众要有强的行动力。

solicitous［sə'lɪsɪtəs］

adj. ① 热切的 ② 挂念的，关心的

解　① desirous; eager ② full of anxiety and concern

例　During her daughter's surgery, the solicitou s neighbor stayed in the hospital waiting to hear news of her daughter's health. 在她女儿手术期间，邻居心神不宁地待在医院里，急切等待着女儿健康的消息。

同　solicitation n. 恳求；教唆；solicitousness n. 关心；焦虑

recital［rɪ'saɪtəl］

n. ① 朗诵，背诵 ② 独奏会，独唱会

解　① a reciting ② a musical entertainment, given usually by a single performer

例　My music teacher will give a piano recital Tuesday afternoon. 周二下午，我的音乐老师将举办一场钢琴独奏会。

同　recite v. 背诵；recitation n. 背诵

resuscitate［rɪ'sʌsɪteɪt］

v. （使）复苏，（使）复兴

解　to restore to life or consciousness

例　The lifeguard pulled the drowning woman to shore and resuscitated her. 救生员将这个溺水的女人拖上岸并救活了她。

同　resuscitation n. 复活，复兴



其他与“叫”意义有关的词汇

screech v. 尖叫

shriek v. 尖叫

exclaim v. 大喊大叫

yell n. 大叫

bluster v. 咆哮，恐吓

rant v. 怒吼，咆哮

uproar n. 咆哮





Group 38: claim=cry out “呼喊，叫喊”

claim［kleɪm］

v. 声称；声称有权利 n. 声明

解　v. to assert or affirm strongly; to state to be true or existing n. an assertion of a right (as to money or property)

例　She claimed that the car accident was his fault. 她声称这场交通事故是他的责任。

acclaim［ə'kleɪm］

v. 称赞；欢呼

解　to praise vociferously; to clap one's hands or shout after performances to indicate approval

例　The mayor acclaimed the firefighters as the city's heroes for their bravery. 消防员们勇敢无畏，市长赞扬他们是这座城市的英雄。

近　acclimate v. 使适应

构　ac (=to) + claim (=to cry out)

disclaim［dɪs'kleɪm］

v. ① 放弃权利 ② 拒绝承认

解　① to give up all claim to ② to refuse to recognize one's own; deny connection with

例　They disclaimed ownership of the house and explained that they were only renting it. 他们否认拥有这座房屋的所有权，声称只是租用。

同　declamation n. 高谈阔论，高声说话；高调

构　dis (=not) + claim (=to cry out)

exclaim［ɪk'skleɪm］

v. 大喊大叫

解　to utter aloud, often with surprise, horror, or joy

例　The children exclaimed with delight at the sight of the Christmas presents. 看到圣诞礼物，孩子们高兴地欢呼起来。

同　exclamation n. 尖叫



Group 39: clud, clus=close, shut “关闭”

include［ɪn'klu:d］

v. 包含，包括

解　to have as a part, to be made up out of

例　The dinner included salad, soup, a main course and dessert. 晚餐包括沙拉、汤、主菜和甜点。

同　inclusion n. 包含

conclude［kən'klu:d］

v. ① 得结论 ② 结束

解　① to reach a conclusion after a discussion or deliberation ② to bring to a close

例　The police investigation concluded that the prisoners had escaped the jail through the sewage pipes. 警察通过调查得出了结论：囚犯是通过排污管从监狱里逃走的。

conclusive［kən'klu:sɪv］

adj. 结论性的；（事实、证据等）确凿的

解　final and deciding

例　The conclusive evidence affirmed the defendant's guilt. 确凿的证据证实了被告的罪行。

occlude［ɒ'klu:d］

v. 使闭塞，封闭；排除出去

解　to close up to block passage through

例　The navy occluded any ships from entering the restricted area. 海军封锁航道，禁止任何船只进入禁航区。

recluse［rɪ'klu:s］

n. 隐士 adj. 隐居的

解　n. one who lives in solitude adj. withdrawn from society; seeking solitude

例　The recluse lived in the woods, eating the plants from his garden and the meat of animals he hunted. 这个隐士居住在森林里，以自己菜园中种植的植物和狩猎所得的肉类为食。

同　reclusive adj. 隐遁的，隐居的

构　re (=back) + clus (=to shut) + e





seclusion［sɪ'klu:ʒən］

n. 隐居，隐遁；隔离

解　the act of secluding; isolation

例　A hermit likes to live in seclusion. 隐居者喜欢居住在与世隔绝的地方。

构　se (=away) + clus (=to shut) + ion

Lesson 11





音频



Group 40: contra=against “反对；相反”

contradict［ˌkɒntrə'dɪkt］

vt. 同…矛盾，同…冲突

解　to be contrary to; to disagree with

例　The defendant contradicted his words and was accused of perjury. 被告的陈述与之前的供词相矛盾，被指控作伪证。

同　contradiction n. 矛盾

构　contra (=against) + dict (=to say)

contradictory［ˌkɒntrə'dɪktəri］

adj. 自相矛盾的

解　in disagreement

例　Her contradictory statements raised suspicion of her honesty. 她自相矛盾的陈述让人对她的诚实起了怀疑。

contrast［'kɒntrɑ:st］n.［kən'trɑ:st］v. 对比，对照

解　n. a great difference v. to compare (two things) so as to show their differences

例　Her dark hair is a sharp contrast to her sister's light hair. 她的深色头发和她姐姐的浅色头发形成了鲜明的对比。

contravene［ˌkɒntrə'vi:n］

v. 违背 （法规、习俗等）

解　go against rules and laws

例　The rebellious student contravened the school's formal uniform policy and attended class in casual clothes. 这名叛逆的学生违背学校要求统一着装的规定，穿着休闲服就来上课了。

近　intervene v. 介入，干涉

构　contra (=against) + vene (=to come)



Group 41: counter=against “反对；相反”

counterargument［'kaʊntəˌɑ:gjʊmənt］

n. 辩论，抗辩

解　an argument in opposition to another

例　The winning team of the debate contest had the best arguments and counterarguments. 这场辩论赛的获胜队拥有最好的论据和反论据。

同　argue v. 争论，争辩；argument n. 争论；论（据、证、点）；argumentative adj. 好争辩的

counterfeit［'kaʊntəfɪt］

v. 伪造，仿造 n. 伪造物；伪钞

解　v. to make a copy of with the intent to deceive

n. a copy that is presented as the original

例　This twenty-dollar bill looks genuine, but it is really a counterfeit. 这张20美元的钞票看起来很像真的，但其实是假钞。

近　forfeit v. 丧失，被罚没收 n. 丧失物；surfeit n. 过多，过度，过饱 v. 使吃饱

构　counter (=against) + feit (=to make)

countermand［ˌkaʊntə'mɑ:nd］

v. 取消订货；撤回（命令）

解　to withdraw or cancel (an order or command)

例　The general countermanded the air strike when it was discovered that the target had many innocent civilians. 当发现袭击地点有很多无辜的平民时，将军下令取消了空袭。

构　counter (=against) + mand (=to order)

encounter［ɪn'kaʊntə(r)］

v. 遭遇

解　to meet unexpectedly

例　The king's soldiers encountered heavy resistance from the Cyclops. 国王的士兵遭遇了库克罗普斯顽强的抵抗。

构　en (=to make ) + counter (=against)





Group 42: cracy=rule; government “统治；政体”

autocracy［ɔ:'tɒkrəsi］

n. 独裁统治，独裁政体

解　a political system governed by a single individual

例　The autocracy of the country allowed one man's opinion and prejudices to rule millions. 这个国家的独裁统治可以让一个人的主张与偏见统治百万民众。

aristocracy［ˌærɪs'tɒkrəsi］

n. 贵族阶级

解　a privileged class holding hereditary titles

例　Earls, duchesses, and princes belong to the aristocracy. 伯爵、公爵夫人和王子都属于贵族阶级。

bureaucracy［bjʊə'rɒkrəsi］

n. 官僚，官僚政治

解　governmental officialism or inflexible routine

例　Many people fear that the constant introduction of federal agencies will create a government of bureaucracy. 许多人担心长期采用联邦政府机制会形成官僚政府。

构　bureau (=desk; office) + cracy (=power; to rule)

democracy［dɪ'mɒkrəsi］

n. 民主，民主统治

解　a political system governed by the people or their representatives

例　Voting is not a privilege but a natural right for all citizens in a democracy. 在民主政体中，投票不属于特权，而是所有公民的自然权利。

gerontocracy［ˌʤerən'tɒkrəsi］

n. 老人统治

解　government by old people

例　Many native American tribes were governed under gerontocracies. 许多印第安人部落由老人统治。

technocracy［tek'nɒkrəsi］

n. 技术统治

解　a form of government in which scientists and technical experts are in control

例　A group of computer engineers dreamed of creating a technocracy based on the Internet. 一些电脑工程师梦想创建一个基于互联网的技术统治政府。



Group 43: cre=grow; make “增长；产生”

creative［kri:'eɪtɪv］

adj. 有创造力的

解　having the ability or power to create

例　Creative business strategies are necessary for a company to compete in the world markets. 创新性的商业策略对公司参与国际市场竞争至关重要。

同　creativity n. 创造力

creature［'kri:tʃə(r)］

n. 生物 （尤指动物）

解　any living person or animal

例　She loves all the earth's creatures. 她热爱地球上的所有生物。

accrete［æ'kri:t］

v. 自然增加（因不停地生长而增大）

解　to make larger or greater, as by increased growth

例　Over time the trees' roots accreted into one. 随着时间流逝，这些树的根长到了一起。

同　accretion n. 自然的增加；增加物

构　ac (=to) + cre (=to grow) + te

concrete［'kɒnkri:t］

adj. 具体的 n. 混凝土

解　adj. not abstract or imaginary n. a strong hard building material composed of sand, gravel, cement and water

例　The student used specific examples to give a concrete image of his story. 这个学生利用多个详尽的例子，使他的故事有了一个具体的形象。



Group 44: cred=believe, trust “相信，信任”

discredit［dɪs'kredɪt］

v. ① 败坏名声，丧失名誉 ② 怀疑

解　① to damage the reputation of ② to cast doubt on

例　Her poor performance in the orchestra discredited her fame as the best singer in the world. 她在管弦乐队的糟糕表现败坏了她作为世界最出色歌手的好名声。

构　dis (=not) + cred (=to believe) + it

credible［'kredəbəl; -ɪbəl］

adj. 可信的

解　capable of being believed

例　The mother accepted her son's credible excuse as to why he arrived home late. 母亲接受了儿子之所以晚回家的可靠理由。

同　credibility n. 可靠性，可信性

credence［'kri:dəns］

n. 相信，信任

解　belief

例　The credence of the woman's testimony led to the jury's verdict of not guilty. 这人女人证词的可信度使陪审团认定她无罪。

credentials［krɪ'denʃəlz］

n. 证明，证书

解　documents attesting to the truth of certain stated facts

例　His credentials include an MBA degree and over 10 years of work as a manager in a multinational company. 他的证明文件包括工商管理学硕士学位以及在跨国公司担任经理逾10年的证明材料。

credulous［'kredjʊləs］

adj. 轻信的，易信的

解　disposed to believe on little evidence

例　The credulous policeman was tricked by the cunning robber and let him go free. 这名容易轻信他人的警察被狡猾的盗贼所欺骗，将他放走了。

同　credulity n. 轻信，易信





Group 45: crimin=crime; guilty “罪行；犯罪”

criminal［'krɪmɪnəl］

n. 罪犯 adj. 刑事的，犯罪的

解　n. someone who has committed (or been legally convicted of) a crime adj. relating to crime or its punishment

例　The criminal had been set up and was truly innocent. 经过审查，这名嫌疑犯确实是无辜的。

同　criminality n. 罪行，犯罪

recriminate［rɪ'krɪmɪneɪt］

v. 反责，反控

解　to return an accusation against someone

例　The company defended that it had not infringed on any trademarks and recriminated the newspaper of libel. 这家公司辩称没有侵犯任何商标权，并反责报纸诬陷。

构　re (=again, back) + crimin (=crime) + ate

incriminate［ɪn'krɪmɪneɪt］

v. 归罪于，控告；牵连

解　to accuse of a crime; to show to be guilty

例　The robber's confession incriminated two others who helped to rob the bank. 盗贼的供词牵连出了其他两名协助抢劫银行的同伙。

同　incrimination n. 连累，控告

构　in + crimin (=guilty) + ate

Group 46: cur=care; take care “关心”

cure［kjʊə(r)］

v./n. 治疗，治愈

解　v. to make well; to bring back to health n. treatment intended to relieve or remove disease or any bad condition

例　She took the prescribed medicine to cure her cold. 她吃了医生开的药来治疗感冒。

近　curl n. 卷发；curt adj. （言词、行为）简短而草率的；curb n. 马路镶边石；马勒 v. 控制

curative［'kjʊərətɪv］

adj. 医疗的

解　tending to cure or restore to health

例　The pharmaceutical company created a new curative ointment for minor cuts and sunburn. 这家医药公司开发出了一款治疗轻微伤口和太阳灼伤的新型软膏。

curator［kjʊə'reɪtə(r)］

n. 博物馆馆长

解　the custodian of a collection (as a museum or library)

例　The museum curator organized exhibitions and auctions that brought much fame and high profits. 博物馆馆长组织了一系列展览和拍卖活动，为该馆赢得了广泛的声誉，并带来了可观的收入。

curious［'kjʊərɪəs］

adj. 好奇的

解　eager to investigate and learn more (sometimes about others' concerns)

例　A curious mind is a sponge for new information. 好奇的头脑就像海绵，不断吸收新的信息。

同　curiosity n. 好奇心

epicure［'epɪkjʊə(r)］

n. 美食家（享乐主义者）

解　a person devoted to refined sensuous enjoyment (especially good food and drink)

例　The epicure lived an exorbitantly expensive life. 这个享乐主义者过着一种过于奢侈的生活。

procure［prə'kjʊə(r)］

v. （努力）取得，获得

解　to get by special effort

例　The man filed an application to procure a business license from the relevant authorities. 这位男士向相关部门申请营业执照。

构　pro (=before) + cur (=to take care) + e



其他与“热心，关心”意义有关的词汇

ardent adj. 热心的，热烈的

ardor n. 热情，狂热

aspiration n. 渴望，热望

avid adj. 渴望的，热心的

crave v. 渴望，热望

fervent adj. 有热情的，热烈的；热的

fervid adj. 热情的

fervor n. 热诚，热心

fester n. 热诚，热心

heartiness n. 热诚，诚挚

passion n. 热情，激情

passionate adj. 热情的

solicitous adj. 热切的；挂念的，关心的

mania n. 狂热；癫狂

solicitude n. 热心，关心

zeal n. 热心，热情，狂热

zealot n. 狂热分子，热心者

zealous adj. 狂热的，一心一意的

zest n. 热心，兴趣





Group 47: cur=run “跑”

current［'kʌrənt］

n. 潮流；水流；气流 adj. 现代的，当前的

解　n. a steady flow (usually from natural causes) adj. occurring in or belonging to the present time

例　The river's current is too strong for us to swim across. 河水水流太湍急了，我们没办法游过去。

recurrent［rɪ'kʌrənt］

adj. 反复出现的

解　occurring again and again

例　We brought the car to a mechanic because the overheating engine was a recurrent problem. 由于发动机过热的毛病反复出现，于是我们把车送到机械师那里修理。

同　recurring adj. 重复发生的





concur［kən'kɜ:(r)］

v. ① 同意 ② 同时发生

解　① to be in agreement ② to be in accord

例　The directors concurred to accept a new company policy that would increase professionalism. 董事会成员同意接受一项新的公司政策，这项政策可以使公司更加专业化。

同　concurrence n. 同时发生的事

构　con (=together) + cur (=to run)

occurrence［ə'kʌrəns］

n. 事件，发生的事情

解　an event that happens

例　Solar eclipses are rare occurrences that draw the attention of many people. 日食很少发生，发生时会吸引很多人的注意。



Group 48: curs=run “流；跑”

cursory［'kɜ:səri］

adj. 草率的，粗略的

解　hasty and without attention to detail; not thorough

例　The chief editor was not responsible for reviewing cursory details such as spelling mistakes in the book, but more the general tone and subject matter. 主编不负责修改书中由于疏忽造成的细节错误，比如拼写错误，而更多的是负责大体风格和主题的确定。

构　curs (=to run) + ory (=relating to)

precursory［pri(:)'kɜ:səri］

adj. 先驱的，先兆的

解　warning of future misfortune

例　The black cat walking across the path was a precursory sign of bad luck. 黑猫从路上穿过是不祥之兆。

构　pre (=before) + curs (=to run) + ory

excursive［ɪk'skɜ:sɪv］

adj. 离题的，散漫的

解　 (of e. g. speech and writing) tending to depart from the main point or cover a wide range of subjects

例　Politicians often give excursive answers to sensitive questions that they do not want to answer. 对于不愿回答的敏感问题，政客们总是不作正面回答。

discursive［dɪ'skɜ:sɪv］

adj. 散漫的，离题的

解　wandering from one point or subject to another; digressing

例　They were annoyed and bored by his discursive remarks. 他东拉西扯的评论让他们既恼怒又厌烦。

构　dis (=apart) + curs (=to run) + ive

incursion［ɪn'kɜ:ʃən］

n. 袭击，侵入

解　temporary invasion

例　The incursion of the foreign army on the island was an act of war. 外国军队侵入岛屿是一种战争行为。

构　in (=into) + curs (=to run) + ion



其他与“流出，流动”意义有关的词汇

emanative adj. 流出的，发射性的

dash v. 奔流；猛冲

flush v. 淹没；奔流；脸红

overflow v. 漫流，流溢

torrent n. 急流

trickle v. 一滴滴地流，徐徐地流

meander v. 蜿蜒而流；漫步

exude v. 使慢慢流出，四溢

effusive adj. 感情奔放的；流出的

influx n. 流入





Group 49: dec=fitting “适当的；得体的”

decent［'di:snt］

adj. ① 体面的 ② 相当好的，像样的

解　① proper and right; respectable ② good enough

例　The decent thing to do is to pay for the damage you have done. 最合适的做法是赔偿你所造成的损失。

同　decency n. 体面

indecency［ɪn'di:snsi］

n. 粗鄙，下流

解　the quality of being indecent

例　The vulgar man spoke with indecency in front of women and children. 这个粗俗的男人当着妇女和孩子的面说话很下流。

decorous［'dekərəs］

adj. 有礼貌的，符合礼节的，相称的

解　characterized by propriety and dignity and good taste in manners and conduct

例　The princess was raised to have very decorous manners. 公主自小被培养出一种高雅的举止。

decorum［dɪ'kɔ:rəm］

n. 礼貌，礼节

解　propriety in manners and conduct

例　Decorum is required in the court or the judge will ask you to leave. 在法庭上要举止得体，否则法官会请你离开。





decorate［'dekəreɪt］

v. 装饰

解　to make more attractive by adding ornament, color, etc.

例　She decorated her office with flowers and hearts. 她用鲜花和心形饰物装扮了自己的办公室。

同　decoration n. 装饰



其他与“适当的；得体的”意义有关的词汇

adequate adj. 适当的，足够的

apposite adj. 相关的；适当的，贴切的

appropriateness n. 适当

apt adj. 适当的

condign adj. （指惩罚）严厉而适当的，罪有应得的

felicitous adj. （话语等）适当的，得体的

opportune adj. 合适的，适当的

seemly adj. 适当的；有礼貌的

Lesson 13





音频



Group 50: dem=people “人民”

democracy［dɪ'mɒkrəsi］

n. 民主，民主统治

解　a political system governed by the people or their representatives

例　People have the right to elect their political representatives in a democracy. 在民主国家，人民有权选举政治代表。

同　democratic adj. 民主的

demagogue［'deməɡɒɡ］

n. 煽动家，群众领导者

解　an orator who appeals to the passions and prejudices of his audience

例　He was accused of being a demagogue because he made promises which aroused futile hopes in his listeners. 他的承诺让听众燃起希望后又落空，因此他被指责为一名政治煽动家。

demography［di:'mɒɡrəfi］

n. 人口统计学，人口学

解　the branch of sociology that studies the characteristics of human populations

例　Local surveys of the town's demography report that the number of people has doubled within the last four years. 当地城镇人口统计报告显示，该地人口数量在过去四年里翻了一番。

endemic［en'demɪk］

adj. 地方性的，某地特有的

解　native to or confined to a certain region

例　People planning to visit that country are advised to have vaccinations for any endemic diseases. 打算去那个国家的人们被告诫要接种疫苗，以防感染当地的疾病。

构　en (=in) + dem (=people) + ic

epidemic［ˌepɪ'demɪk］

n. 传染病 adj. 传染性的，流行性的

解　n. epidemic disease adj. spreading rapidly among many people in the same place for a time

例　The epidemic disease spread throughout the city and into neighboring towns in a matter of days. 这种传染病在整个城市里传播，没过几天就传播到了邻县。

pandemic［pæn'demɪk］

adj. （病）大范围流行的

解　epidemic over a wide geographical area

例　Before modern medical advances, the pandemic outbreak of chickenpox spread throughout the world killing thousands of people. 在现代医学还不发达的时候，水痘疫情在全世界大面积爆发，夺走了数以千计的生命。



Group 51: dent=tooth “牙齿”

dent［dent］

n. 凹痕

解　a hollow made by a blow or pressure

例　The accident left a large dent in the side of the car. 这场事故在汽车的侧面留下了一大片凹痕。

dentist［'dentɪst］

n. 牙医

解　a person qualified to practice dentistry

例　A dentist fills cavities in teeth, cleans, straightens, or extracts them, and supplies artificial teeth. 牙医的工作包括填充蛀牙，清洗、矫正或拔出牙齿，以及植入人工假牙。





denture［'dentʃə(r)］

n. 假牙

解　a dental appliance that artificially replaces missing teeth

例　The old man relied on his dentures to eat food. 这个老人依赖假牙进食。

indent［ɪn'dent］

vt. 使成锯齿形，使成犬牙状

解　to make notches or jags in (an edge, line, border, etc.)

例　His punch indented a hole in the wall. 他用穿孔机在墙上钻了一个洞。

rodent［'rəʊdənt］

n. 啮齿类动物（如鼠等）

解　of a group of mammals with large front teeth especially adapted for gnawing

例　Rats, mice, and squirrels are all rodents. 老鼠和松鼠都属于啮齿类动物。



Group 52: dict=say; assert “说话；断言”

indict［ɪn'daɪt］

v. 控告，起诉

解　to charge with a crime

例　The police found his fingerprints at the scene of the crime and indicted him for a criminal offense. 警察在犯罪现场发现了他的指纹，于是控告他犯罪。

同　indictment n. 起诉

verdict［'vɜ:dɪkt］

n. 判决，决定

解　the decision of a trial jury

例　The jury gave the judge their verdict on the defendant. 陪审团告诉法官他们对被告的判决结果。

valediction［ˌvælɪ'dɪkʃən］

n. 告别演说，告别词

解　a speech or statement made as a farewell

例　The president gave a valediction at the party in honor of his last days in office. 在纪念其任期即将结束的宴会上，总统发表了告别演说。

vindicate［'vɪndɪkeɪt］

v. 为…平反；证明…正确

解　to clear of guilt; to justify or prove the worth of, especially in light of later developments

例　After the defendant was found not guilty, he sued the plaintiff to vindicate his reputation. 在被告被证明无罪之后，他对原告提起了诉讼以恢复自己的名誉。

vindictive［vɪn'dɪktɪv］

adj. 报复性的，报复心强的

解　bearing a grudge; wanting revenge

例　Her vindictive nature would not let her forgive and forget easily. 她天生报复心很强，无法轻易原谅他人、放下过去。

benediction［ˌbenɪ'dɪkʃən］

n. 祝福；祈祷

解　blessing; the asking of God's blessing at the end of a religious service

例　The bride and groom received a benediction from the priest. 新郎和新娘收到了神父的祝福。

dictionary［'dɪkʃənəri］

n. 字典

解　book that explains the words of a language or a language of some special subject

例　You can use this dictionary to find out the meaning, spelling, or pronunciation of a word. 你可以使用这个词典查找单词的释义、拼写或者发音。

predict［prɪ'dɪkt］

v. 预言，预测

解　to make a prediction about, to tell in advance

例　The weatherman predicted a sunny day for tomorrow. 天气预报员预测明天是晴天。

同　prediction n. 预言，预报；predictable adj. 可预言的，可预知的；平庸的；predictive adj. 预言的



其他与“说话”意义有关的词汇

archaism n. 古词，古语

argot n. 行话，职业术语

cant n. 隐语，术语

jargon n. 胡言乱语；行话；黑话

slang n. 俚语；行话

colloquialism n. 口语，俗语

euphemism n. 委婉语；委婉的说法

pun n. 双关语

articulate v. 清楚说话；接合 adj. 发音清晰的

enunciate v. 清晰发音；（清楚地）表达

babble v. 说蠢话；牙牙学语

belabour v. 过分冗长地说；痛打

chatter v. 喋喋不休

garrulous adj. 唠叨的，多话的

loquacious adj. 唠叨的，喋喋不休的

drawl v. 慢吞吞地说

slur v. 含糊不清地说；恶语相加

waffle v. 含糊其辞，胡扯

mutter n./v. 轻声低语；咕哝

murmur n./v. 小声抱怨；咕哝

stammer v. 结结巴巴地说；口吃

stutter v. 结结巴巴地说

drivel n./v. 胡言乱语，（说）傻话

gibberish n. 胡言乱语，快速而不清楚的言语

jabber v. 快而不清楚地说

rattle v. 急促地谈

reiterate v. 重申，反复地说

hum n./v. 嗡嗡说话（声）

intercede v. 说好话，代求情

parlance n. 谈话，说法

prate v. 瞎扯，胡说

Lesson 14





音频



Group 53: domin, domit=master “控制，支配”

dominate［'dɒmɪneɪt］

v. 控制，支配

解　to have control over

例　The dinosaurs dominated the planet before humans. 在人类出现以前，恐龙主宰着地球。

同　domination n. 控制，支配

dominant［'dɒmɪnənt］

adj. ① 显性的 ② 统治的，主要的

解　① (of groups of physical qualities passed on from parent to child) able to appear in the child even if only in the genes of one parent ② most powerful or influential; controlling

例　Humans are the most dominant species on the planet today. 如今，人类是地球上最主要的物种。

近　dome n. 圆屋顶；doomed adj. 命中注定的

predominant［prɪ'dɒmɪnənt］

adj. 占优势的；显著的

解　having greatest ascendancy, importance, influence, authority, or force

例　The United States is the predominant nation in the western hemisphere. 美国是西半球占支配地位的国家。

构　pre (=before) + domin (=to master) + ant

domineering［ˌdɒmɪ'nɪərɪŋ］

adj. 极权的，作威作福的，跋扈的

解　inclined to domineer; arrogant; overbearing

例　I dislike the domineering attitude of people who always want things done their own way. 我不喜欢有些人专横跋扈的态度，他们总希望事情按照自己想要的方式来处理。

indomitable［ɪn'dɒmɪtəbəl］

adj. 不可征服的，坚强不屈的

解　impossible to subdue

例　The businesswoman had an indomitable spirit, allowing her to succeed in the business world. 这位女商人有着不屈不挠的精神，这使得她在商界获得了成功。

构　in (=not) + domit (=to master) + able



Group 54: duc, duct=lead “领导”

duct［dʌkt］

n. 管道

解　tube, pipe, or channel for carrying liquid, air, etc.

例　The duct around the electrical wire will help prevent people from being electrocuted. 电线周围的胶管可以防止人触电致死。

近　duck n. 鸭子

aqueduct［'ækwɪˌdʌkt］

n. 引水渠，渡槽

解　an artificial channel or large pipe for bringing water from a distance; a structure that supports such a channel or pipe

例　The inland town built an aqueduct to transport water from the river to houses. 这个内陆城镇建造了一个引水渠，用来把水从河里输送到各家各户。

近　aquatic adj. 水生的，水中的

conductor［kən'dʌktə(r)］

n. 指挥家，乐队指挥

解　the person who leads a musical group; director of an orchestra, chorus, etc.

例　The conductor waved his arms around in the air as the symphony played on. 随着交响乐开始演奏，指挥家在空中挥舞着手臂。

misconduct［mɪs'kɒndʌkt］

n. 行为不端

解　bad behavior

例　The boy's misconduct in class led to his punishment. 男孩因为在班里行为不端而受到了惩罚。

conducive［kən'dju:sɪv］

adj. 有助于…的

解　helpful; contributing to

例　Exercise and proper eating habits are conducive to good health. 锻炼和合理的饮食习惯有益健康。

近　seductive adj. 诱人的，有魅力的

构　con (=together) + duc (=to lead) + ive

inducement［ɪn'dju:smənt］

n. 引诱物，诱因

解　something which provides encouragement to do something

例　He drank coffee as an inducement to stay awake. 他靠喝咖啡来保持清醒。

同　induce v. 诱导；引起

irreducible［ˌɪrɪ'dju:səbəl］

adj. 不能复归的，不能削减的；【数】不可约分的

解　impossible to reduce to a desired, simpler, or smaller form or amount

例　The most irreducible coin in the American currency is the one-cent penny. 美国货币中的最小面值是一美分。

deduce［dɪ'dju:s］

vt. 推论，演绎出

解　to reach (a conclusion) by reasoning; infer

例　The students deduced the answer by eliminating all other possibilities. 学生们通过排除其他可能的选项推断出了正确答案。

构　de (=down) + duc (=to lead) + e

deduct［dɪ'dʌkt］

v. 扣除

解　to make a subtraction

例　The restaurant manager warned the waitress not to break the dishware or it would be deducted from her salary. 餐厅经理警告女服务员不要打碎餐具，否则餐具的费用就要从她的薪水中扣除。

deductive［dɪ'dʌktɪv］

adj. 演绎的

解　involving inferences from general principles

例　Sherlock Holmes relied on deductive reasoning to solve most of the mysteries he investigated. 福尔摩斯依靠演绎推理法来破解他所研究的大多数谜题。

educate［'edju(:)keɪt］

v. 教育

解　to develop in knowledge or skill by teaching, training, or study; to teach

例　The parents educated their children in proper etiquette. 这对父母教孩子形成了良好的礼节。

同　educated adj. 受过教育的；education n. 教育；educator n. 教师



Group 55: dur=last “持续”

enduring［ɪn'djuərɪŋ］

adj. 持久的

解　unceasing

例　She held an enduring love for the soldier and waited years and years for his return. 她深爱着这个士兵，多年来一直在等他回来。

同　endure v. 持久；忍受；endurance n. 忍耐；忍受力，耐久力





durable［'djʊərəbəl］

adj. 耐久的，耐用的

解　able to withstand wear, decay, etc.

例　Work clothes are made of durable fabric. 工作服由耐用的布料制成。

同　durability n. 耐久性

构　dur (=to last) + able

duration［djʊə'reɪʃən］

n. 持续时间

解　length of time; time during which anything continues

例　The storm was sudden and of short duration. 这场风暴来得突然，持续的时间也很短。

indurate［'ɪndjʊəreɪt］

v. 使坚固，使僵硬

解　to become harden or unfeeling

例　The farmer's hands were indurated by the years of hard work. 这个农民的双手因为多年辛苦劳作而变得粗糙。

obdurate［'ɒbdjʊrɪt］

adj. 固执的，顽固的

解　stubbornly persistent in wrongdoing

例　The obdurate liar had told so many lies he could not differentiate between what was true or false. 这个顽固的骗子满口谎话，连他自己都分不清楚哪些是真的哪些是假的。

Group 56: ear=ear “耳朵”

earplug［'ɪəplʌɡ］

n. 耳塞

解　an object made of a soft, pliable material, such as cotton or rubber, and fitted into the ear canal to block the entry of water or sound

例　Don' t forget to put in your earplugs when you go swimming. 游泳的时候别忘了戴上耳塞。

earring［'ɪərɪŋ］

n. 耳环，耳饰

解　jewelry to ornament the ear, usually clipped to the earlobe or fastened through a hole in the lobe

例　On the day she got her ears pierced, her mother bought her a pair of diamond earrings. 在她打耳洞的那天，她母亲给她买了一对钻石耳环。

earshot［'ɪəʃɒt］

n. 听力范围

解　distance at which a sound can be heard; range of hearing

例　We shouted, but he was already out of earshot and could not hear us. 我们大声地叫喊，可是他离得太远，已经听不到了。

eavesdropper［'i:vzˌdrɒpə(r)］

n. 偷听者

解　a secret listener to private conversations

例　The eavesdropper was an undercover police detective trying to overhear a conversation to get clues to a crime. 偷听者是一位卧底警探，他试着从对话中听出犯罪案件的线索。

earsplitting［'ɪəspli:tɪŋ］

adj. 震耳欲聋的

解　loud and shrill enough to hurt the ears

例　The music that the rock band played was not only horrible; it was also earsplitting. 这个摇滚乐队演奏的音乐不仅糟糕透顶，简直到了震耳欲聋的地步。



Group 57: en “使…进入某种状态，使成为…”

enable［ɪ'neɪbəl］

v. 使能够

解　to render capable or able for some task

例　The invention of the telephone enabled people to communicate around the world in seconds. 电话的发明使世界各地的人们在数秒之内就能交流。

同　ability n. 能力；disability n. 残废；无能

ennoble［ɪ'nəʊbəl］

v. ① 使高贵 ② 使受尊敬

解　① to raise to a noble rank ② to raise the respect of others for; to dignify

例　The king ennobled the soldier with knighthood. 国王授予这位士兵骑士爵位。

ensemble［ɒŋ'sɒŋbəl］

n. ① 大合唱 ② 合奏；全体

解　① the chorus of a ballet company ② a group of musicians playing or singing together

例　Two violins, a cello, and a viola made up the string ensemble. 这个弦乐合奏由两把小提琴、一把大提琴和一把中提琴组成。

enfranchise［ɪn'fræntʃaɪz; en-］

v. ① 给予选举权 ② 释放（奴隶）

解　① to grant voting rights ② to grant freedom to, as from slavery or servitude

例　Ratified in August of 1920, the 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution enfranchised women, and they began to vote in local and national elections. 美国宪法第十九条修正案于1920年8月批准生效，它赋予了妇女选举权，之后妇女们开始在当地和国家选举中进行投票。

engulf［ɪn'ɡʌlf］

v. 卷入，吞噬

解　to swallow up; to overwhelm

例　The wild forest fire engulfed trees and bushes. 森林大火吞噬了树木和灌木丛。





enhance［ɪn'hɑ:ns; -hæns］

vt. 提高，增强

解　to make greater; to add to; to heighten

例　The gardens enhanced the beauty of the house. 花园提升了房子的美感。

构　en (=in) + hance (=high)

enlarge［ɪn'lɑ:ʤ］

v. 增大，扩大

解　to make larger

例　She used an electron microscope to enlarge the image of the cells. 她用电子显微镜来放大细胞的影像。

enrich［ɪn'rɪtʃ］

v. 使丰富，充实

解　to make rich or richer

例　His new love enriched his life with joy and happiness. 他的新恋情使他的生活充满了快乐和幸福。



Group 58: equ=equal; same “相等；相同”

adequate［'ædɪkwɪt］

adj. 适当的，足够的

解　enough to meet a purpose

例　The student's work was not outstanding, but it was adequate for a passing grade. 这名学生的成绩不算优秀，但是足以及格。

同　adequacy n. 足够；inadequacy n. 不充分

构　ad (=to) + equ (=equal) + ate

equal［'i:kwəl］

adj. 相等的，均等的

解　the same in amount, size, number, value, or rank

例　Ten dimes are equal to one dollar. 十个十美分的硬币等于一美元。

equate［ɪ'kweɪt］

v. 与…相提并论，视为同等，等同

解　to treat or regard as equal

例　He said nothing, but the expression on his face equated to a refusal. 他虽然一句话都没说，但是脸上的表情相当于拒绝了。

同　equation n. 方程式

equitable［'ekwɪtəbəl］

adj. 公平的，公正的

解　fair; just

例　It is equitable to pay a person good wages for work well done. 对出色完成工作的人给予丰厚的报酬是公平的。

equable［'ekwəbəl; 'i:k-］

adj. ① （脾气）温和的 ② 稳定的，不变的

解　 ① free from unpleasant extremes ② steady

例　The good-natured traffic officer had an equable disposition. 这位和蔼的交警性格很温和。

equity［'ekwɪti］

n. 公正，公平

解　fairness or impartiality; justice

例　The two companies negotiated the details of their cooperation until both parties were satisfied with the equity. 两家公司对合作的细节进行了商讨，最后双方都对结果的公平性表示满意。

同　inequity n. 不公平

equilibrium［ˌi:kwɪ'lɪbrɪəm］

n. 均衡，平衡

解　a stable situation in which forces cancel one another

例　The acrobat in the circus maintained equilibrium on a tightrope. 马戏团的杂技演员在钢丝上保持着平衡。

equivalent［ɪ'kwɪvələnt］

adj. 相等的，等值的

解　equal in amount or value

例　Nodding your head is equivalent to saying yes. 点头就相当于同意。

同　equivalence n. 相等，等价，等值

equanimity［ˌi:kwə'nɪməti; ˌekwə-］

n. 镇定，沉着

解　evenness of mind or temper

例　Despite the highly stressful time, John's e quanimity reassured his subordinates that he would make a prudent decision no matter what happened. 尽管时间非常紧张，约翰的镇定使下属相信不管发生什么事，他都会作出审慎的决定。

构　equ (=equal, same) + anim (=mind, life, breath) + ity
