Group 59: esthet=feel “感觉”

aesthete［'i:sθi:t; 'esθi:t］

n. 审美家

解　one who professes great sensitivity to the beauty of art and nature

例　The aesthete collected over one hundred pieces of artwork from around the world. 这位审美家从世界各地收集了100多件艺术品。

同　aesthetics n. 美学

anesthetic［ˌænɪs'θetɪk］

n. 麻醉剂 adj. 麻醉的

解　n. a drug that causes temporary loss of bodily sensations adj. characterized by insensibility

例　The doctor will give you some anesthetic before the surgery so you won't feel the pain. 在手术前，医生会给你注射麻醉剂，这样你就不会感觉疼了。

近　analgesic n. 止痛剂，镇痛剂 adj. 止痛的

anesthesia［ˌænɪs'θi:zjə］

n. 麻醉，麻木

解　loss of bodily sensation with or without loss of unconsciousness

例　The anesthesia around his mouth allowed him to be unconscious when the dentist extracted his teeth. 他的嘴巴周围被麻醉，这样在医生给他拔牙时他就不会感觉疼痛。



其他与“感觉”意义有关的词汇

perceive v. 察觉，发觉

perceptive adj. 感觉敏锐的

palpable adj. 明显的，易觉察的

sensation n. 感觉，知觉；轰动（的事件）

sentient adj. 有知觉的；知悉的

tactile adj. 有触觉的

intuition n. 直觉

intuitive adj. 直觉的；凭直觉得到的





Group 60: eu=well “好”

eulogy［'ju:ləʤi］

n. 颂词，颂文

解　a formal expression of praise

例　Senator Robert Kennedy gave a compelling eulogy at the funeral of Martin Luther King. 参议员罗伯特·肯尼迪在马丁·路德·金的葬礼上发表了一篇引人注目的颂词。

构　eu (=well) + logy (=to speak)

eulogize［'ju:ləʤaɪz］

v. 称赞，颂扬

解　to praise formally and eloquently

例　Before presenting the prize, it is customary for the principal to eulogize the recipient. 在颁奖之前，按照惯例，校长要对获奖人进行一番赞扬。

构　eu (=well) + log (=speech) + ize

euphoria［ju:'fɔ:rɪə］

n. 欣快症，幸福愉快感

解　a feeling of great (usually exaggerated) elation

例　Hiking to the mountain peak gave him a sense of achievement and euphoria. 徒步登上山顶使他有了一种成就感和愉悦感。

构　eu (=well) + phor (=to carry) + ia

euphonious［ju:'fəʊnɪəs］

adj. 悦耳的

解　having a pleasant sound

例　The sound of birds chirping in the morning is euphonious for many people. 清晨的鸟叫声让许多人感觉悦耳。

构　eu (=well) + phon (=sound) + ious



Group 61: ex=out “出去”

exit［'eksɪt; -zɪt］

v. 出去 n. 出口

解　v. leave, go n. outlet

例　Everyone exited the building when the fire alarm went off. 火警响起的时候，所有人都跑出了大楼。

exigent［'eksɪʤənt］

adj. ① 紧急的 ② 苛求的

解　① needing quick action or help ② requiring precise accuracy

例　The driver in the car accident needed exigent medical attention and was driven to a hospital. 遭遇车祸的司机迫切需要医疗护理，随即被开车送往了医院。

构　ex (=out) + ig (=to drive) + ent

exile［'eksaɪl; 'eɡz-］

n./v. 驱逐出，放逐

解　to expel from a country

例　The dictator was overthrown and lived in exile until he died. 独裁者被打倒后，一生过着流亡的生活。

external［ek'stɜ:nəl］

adj. 外部的

解　relating to or on the outside

例　Ron was in charge of the university's external affairs such as fundraising and recruiting. 罗恩负责大学的外事工作，例如募资和招聘。

同　externalize v. 使具体化，使形象化

extort［ɪk'stɔ:t］

v. 勒索，强索

解　to obtain by force or improper pressure

例　Blackmailers try to extort money from their victims. 勒索者试图从受害者手中强索钱财。

同　extortionist n. 敲诈勒索者

构　ex (=out) + tort (=to twist)





extract［ɪk'strækt］

v. 提炼；拔出；提取

解　draw or pull out, usually with some force or effort

例　The dentist extracted all four of her wisdom teeth. 牙医把她的四颗智齿全拔掉了。

同　extraction n. 血统；拔出，提取

extradition［ˌekstrə'dɪʃən］

n. 引渡逃犯

解　surrender of a fugitive or prisoner by one state, nation, or authority to another

例　The lawyers opposed the extradition of their client on the grounds that for more than five years he had been a model citizen. 律师反对引渡其委托人，理由是五年多以来他一直是模范公民。

exploit［ɪk'splɔɪt］

v. 开发利用；剥削

解　to make use of; to make unfair or selfish use of

例　A mine is exploited for its minerals. 矿山被用来开采矿物。

extricate［'ekstrɪkeɪt］

v. 拯救，救出

解　to set free from entanglements, difficulties, embarrassing situations, etc.; to release

例　Jim tried to extricate himself from the heated argument by saying he had to go to the bathroom. 为了从激烈的争吵中脱身，吉姆借口说要去趟卫生间。

构　ex (=out) + tric (=petty obstacle) + ate

同　extricable adj. 能救出的，能脱险的

exodus［'eksədəs］

n. 大批离去，成群外出

解　a departure of a large number of people or animals

例　The forest fire saw a mass exodus of wildlife leaving the woods. 森林大火使大批野生动物离开了森林。

构　ex (=out) + od < hod (=way) + us

Group 62: fac=face “面容”

facade［fə'sɑ:d］

n. 建筑物的正面，外表

解　the face or front of a building

例　The facade of the church had often been photographed by tourists because it was more interesting than the rear. 游客经常对教堂的正面拍照，因为它比背面更有意思。

facetious［fə'si:ʃəs］

adj. 轻浮的，好开玩笑的

解　cleverly amusing in tone, joking inappropriately

例　Your facetious remarks are not appropriate at this serious moment. 在这个严肃的时刻，你的诙谐言论不合时宜。

barefaced［'beəfeɪst］

adj. ① 面部无遮盖物的 ② 公然自傲的；厚颜无耻的

解　① having no covering over the face ② undisguisedly bold; brazen

例　The barefaced bank robbers were daring enough to walk into the bank without masks, knowing that the video camera would capture their identities. 劫匪竟敢公然走进银行，明知监控摄像头会拍下他们，也没有戴面具。

deface［dɪ'feɪs］

v. 毁坏外观；丑化，使失面子

解　to mar or spoil the appearance of

例　The newspaper article about the president's scandal defaced his image in the public's eye. 报纸上的这篇关于总统丑闻的报道损害了总统在公众心目中的形象。

构　de (=away) + fac (=face) + e

efface［ɪ'feɪs］

v. 擦掉，抹去

解　to obliterate by rubbing out

例　Even one hundred years would never efface her memory of his abuse. 即使过去一百年，她被他虐待的记忆也无法被抹去。

构　ef < ex (=out) + fac (=face) + e





preface［'prefəs］

n. ① 序言 ② 开端

解　① a short introductory essay preceding the text of a book ② beginning

例　The preface of the autobiography explained how the book was written. 这部自传的序言说明了这本书是如何写成的。

surface［'sɜ:fɪs］

n. 表面

解　the outside of anything

例　The surface of the wooden boat needs to be waxed before we can set it in the water. 在下水前，木船的表面需要打蜡。



Group 63: fact, fect=do, make “做”

factual［'fæktjʊəl］

adj. 事实的，实际的

解　concerned with facts; consisting of facts

例　The witness pledged in the court to give a factual account of what she had seen. 目击证人在法庭上宣誓对自己所看到的一切作真实陈述。

近　faculty n. （大学的）院系；全体教师

affected［ə'fektɪd］

adj. 做作的，不自然的；假装的

解　speaking or behaving in an artificial way to make an impression; pretended

例　His affected mannerisms irritated many of us who had known him before his promotion. 我们中的很多人在他升职之前就已认识他；他升职后的矫揉造作惹恼了大家。

同　affectation n. 做作，装模作样；虚假

affection［ə'fekʃən］

n. 亲情；爱，爱情；钦慕之情

解　friendly feeling; tenderness; love

例　The secret lovers could not openly express their affection in public. 这对秘密恋人无法在公开场合表达爱意。

affectionate［ə'fekʃənɪt］

adj. 充满深情的，挚爱的

解　having or displaying warmth or affection; loving

例　The dog was very active and affectionate at the sight of its owner. 看见主人后，这只狗变得非常活跃，开始讨主人欢心。

disaffect［ˌdɪsə'fekt］

v. 使不满，使叛离

解　to arouse enmity or indifference where there had formerly been love, affection, or friendliness

例　The inconsiderate words she spoke to him disaffected him and created a feeling of resentment. 她对他说的话没有体谅他的感受，这让他十分不满，心中产生一股怨恨。

同　disaffected adj. （政治上）不满的，叛离的；disaffection n. 政治上不满，叛离

defect［'dɪ:fekt］

n. 缺陷

解　a shortcoming or failing in a person or thing; fault or blemish

例　A hearing aid helps to overcome defects in hearing. 助听器有助于克服听力障碍。

同　defection n. 背叛，脱党，变节；defective adj. 有缺陷的

构　de (=from) + fect (=to do, to make)

feckless［'fekləs］

adj. 无目标的，无责任心的

解　not fit to assume responsibility

例　A company run by a feckless manager will not survive in such a competitive market. 一个由毫无责任感的管理者来经营的公司是无法在竞争如此激烈的市场中生存下去的。

infection［ɪn'fekʃən］

n. 感染

解　a causing of disease in people, animals, and plants by the introduction of germs or viruses

例　Without proper medical treatment, a deep cut can turn into an unwanted infection. 伤口如果很深又得不到正确的医疗护理，就可能受到不必要的感染。

disinfect［ˌdɪsɪn'fekt］

v. 杀菌，消毒

解　to destroy microorganisms or pathogens by cleansing; to sterilize

例　The nurse disinfected the surgeon's tools after every surgery. 在每次手术之后，护士都会给外科医生的手术工具消毒。

同　disinfection n. 消毒，灭菌

Lesson 18





音频



Group 64: fail, fall, fault=err; deceive “犯错误；欺骗”

failing［'feɪlɪŋ］

n. 弱点；缺点

解　weakness; defect

例　We all have our failings —no one is perfect. 我们都有缺点，毕竟人无完人。

failure［'feɪljə(r)］

n. 失败；失灵，故障

解　a lack of ability to do or become successful; failing

例　Failure is natural, since we are all human, but the ability to rise from that failure is what differentiates winners from losers. 我们都是凡人，所以失败是自然的，但是能否从失败中站起来则是区分胜利者和失败者的关键。

fallacy［'fæləsi］

n. 谬误，错误

解　a misconception resulting from incorrect reasoning

例　The testimony of the eyewitness was considered a fallacy because he was blind. 这位目击者的证词被认为是错误的，因为他是一位盲人。

同　fallacious adj. 谬误的；欺骗的

fallible［'fæləbəl］

adj. 会犯错的，易犯错的

解　likely to fail or be inaccurate

例　I know I am fallible, but I feel confident that I am right this time. 我知道我经常犯错，但是我相信我这次一定是对的。

同　fallibility n. 易犯错误；不可靠性；infallible adj. 绝不会错的；绝对可靠的

fault［fɔ:lt］

n. ① 断层 ② 过错，缺点

解　n. ① break in the continuity of layers of rock ② failure to perform a task or fulfill an obligation

例　She told the judge that the car accident was his fault, not hers. 她告诉法官那起交通事故是他的责任，而非她的。

default［dɪ'fɔ:lt］

n./v. ① 拖欠债务 ② 未履行责任

解　① failure to meet a financial obligation ② failure to perform a task or fulfill an obligation

例　She was in default of her bank loan and risked losing her house as collateral if she did not pay. 她拖欠银行贷款，如果不还清，就有可能失去用来抵押的房子。

faultless［'fɔ:ltləs］

adj. 完美无缺的

解　without a single fault or defect; perfect

例　The student's math test was faultless and he got a perfect score. 这名学生在数学测验中一道题都没有错，获得了满分。

faultfinder［'fɔ:ltfaɪndə］

n. 吹毛求疵者

解　someone who is critical of the motives of others

例　No one likes a boss who is a faultfinder. 没有人喜欢吹毛求疵的老板。

近　find v. 找到；finding n. 调查结果



其他与“欺骗”意义有关的词汇

beguile v. 欺骗，诱骗

bilk v. 欺骗

chicanery n. 狡诈，狡猾；欺诈

cozen v. 诱骗，哄骗

deceive v. 欺骗

deception n. 欺骗

deceptive adj. 欺骗性的

defraud v. 骗取，诈取

delude v. 欺骗，哄骗

double-cross n. 出卖，欺骗

duplicity n. 欺骗，口是心非

fraud n. 欺诈，欺骗；骗子

fraudulent adj. 欺骗的，不诚实的

guile n. 狡猾；诡计，欺骗

gull v. 欺骗 n. 海鸥

gullible adj. 易受骗的，轻信的

hoax n./v. 欺骗

imposture n. 冒名顶替，欺骗

inveigle v. 诱骗，诱使

swindle v. 诈骗，骗取

charlatan n. 江湖郎中，骗子

cajole v. （以甜言蜜语）哄骗

wheedle v. （用花言巧语）哄骗

coax v. 哄诱，巧言诱哄

fast-talking adj. 花言巧语的





Group 65: fend, fens=strike “打击”

defend［dɪ'fend］

v. 防护，防卫；辩护

解　to protect against a challenge or attack

例　The tigress would defend her babies with her life. 雌虎会用生命来保护她的幼崽。

同　defense n. 防御，保卫

defendant［dɪ'fendənt］

n. 被告

解　a person against whom an action is brought in a court of law

例　The defendant was deemed not guilty and did not even have to pay a fine. 被告被认为无罪，甚至都不用缴纳罚金。

offend［ə'fend］

v. 冒犯，伤害

解　to hurt the feelings of; to make angry; to displease

例　My friend was offended by my laughter. 我的笑声冒犯了朋友。

同　offense n. 冒犯，得罪；错事

offensive［ə'fensɪv］

adj. 令人不快的，得罪人的

解　violating or tending to violate or offend against

例　She slapped him in the face because of his offensive comment about her weight. 她掴了他一个耳光，因为他说的一些关于她的体重的话冒犯了她。

fender［'fendə(r)］

n. 挡泥板；护舷垫

解　metal frame over the wheel of a car, truck, bicycle, etc., that protects the wheel and reduces splashing in wet weather

例　He did not realize his bike's back fender had fallen off and the bike splashed rainwater all over his back. 他没有意识到自行车后轮的挡泥板脱落了，整个背部都被轮子溅起的泥水弄脏了。



Group 66: ferv=boil “沸，热”

fervent［'fɜ:vənt］

adj. 有热情的；热的；热烈的

解　characterized by intense emotion; impassioned

例　She expressed her feelings for him in a fervent love letter sealed with a kiss. 她在一封热情洋溢的情书里表达了对他的爱，然后以吻封缄。

构　ferv (=to boil; bubble) + ent

fervor［'fɜ:və(r)］

n. 热诚，热心

解　glowing ardor

例　He tackled his first day at work with great fervor. 他用极大的热情来迎接他工作的第一天。

fervid［'fɜ:vɪd］

adj. 热情的

解　characterized by intense emotion; ardent

例　The fervid poet wrote love sonnets that impassioned both women and men. 这位热情的诗人所写的爱情十四行诗打动了男男女女。





effervescent［ˌefə'vesnt］

adj. ① 冒泡的 ② 兴奋的

解　① giving off bubbles of gas; bubbling ② lively and gay

例　He had forgotten to close the soda bottle yesterday and the soda was no longer effervescent. 他昨天忘记将苏打水的瓶盖拧上，今天苏打水已经没有气泡了。



其他与“热”意义有关的词汇

sweltering adj. 酷热的

torrid adj. 酷热的

scorching adj. 灼热的





Group 67: fic=do, make “做”

official［ə'fɪʃəl］

n. 官员

解　person who holds a public position or who is in charge of some public work or duty

例　The mayor is a government official. 市长是政府官员。

officiate［ə'fɪʃɪeɪt］

v. 执行职务

解　to perform the duties of any office or position

例　When he was assassinated, John F. Kennedy was cut short of officiating his United States presidency. 约翰·F. 肯尼迪不幸遇刺，他的美国总统生涯也随之终结。

构　of < ob (=intensive) + fic (=to do, to make) + iate

officious［ə'fɪʃəs; ɔ'f-］

adj. 爱管闲事的；爱发命令的，好忠告的

解　intrusive in a meddling or offensive manner

例　Dan always makes an officious nuisance of himself by shouting orders, handing out papers and giving people unwanted advice. 丹总爱管闲事，比如大声指挥，分发文件，给别人不需要的意见，这让人很讨厌他。

构　of < ob (=in the way) + fic (=to do, to make) + ious

superficial［ˌsju:pə'fɪʃəl］

adj. 表面的，肤浅的

解　not deep or penetrating emotionally or intellectually

例　This essay will only give you a superficial understanding of the subject; several years of research are necessary to really understand it. 这篇文章只能让你对这个主题有个肤浅的了解，要想真正理解它，你还需要花费几年的时间进行好好研究。

构　super (=above, over) + fic (=to make, to do) + ial



Group 68: fid=trust, faith “相信”

fidelity［fɪ'delɪti］

n. 忠实，忠诚

解　the quality of being faithful; loyalty

例　His girlfriend broke up with him because she said he had no sense of fidelity. 他的女朋友和他分手了，因为她说他对她已经没有忠诚可言。

同　infidelity n. 不忠实，不贞

perfidy［'pɜ:fɪdi］

n. 不忠，背叛

解　betrayal of a trust

例　The king's most trusted soldiers waited until he was asleep before committing the perfidy of stabbing him. 国王最信任的士兵等他睡着之后背叛并刺杀了他。

同　perfidious adj. 不忠的，背信弃义的

构　per (=to violate) + fid (=faith) + y

affidavit［ˌæfɪ'deɪvɪt］

n. 书面证词，宣誓书

解　statement written down and sworn to be true

例　An affidavit is usually made before a judge or notary public. 签署宣誓书时通常需一名法官或者公证人在场。

confident［'kɒnfɪdənt］

adj. 自信的，有信心的

解　sure of oneself

例　Willie was so confident that he had passed the exam that he did not even bother to check the answers before handing in his answer sheet. 威利对通过考试十分有把握，甚至在交答卷之前都没有检查一下。

同　confidence n. 信心；self-confident adj. 有自信的

构　con (=completely) + fid (=trust) + ent

confidant［ˌkɒnfɪ'dænt］

n. 心腹朋友，知己

解　trusted friend

例　She had many friends but only one confidant to whom she recounted her deepest secrets. 她有许多朋友，但是只有一个知心朋友可以用来倾诉她心里最深处的秘密。

同　confidante n. 知心女友

confidential［ˌkɒnfɪ'denʃəl］

adj. 机密的

解　told or written as a secret

例　Only highly trusted employees could look at the confidential report. 只有被高度信任的员工才能看这份机密报告。

构　con (=completely) + fid (=trust) + ential

diffident［'dɪfɪdənt］

adj. 缺乏自信的，羞怯的

解　lacking self-confidence

例　The new kid at school was very diffident and would sit in the corner while the other boys and girls played games outside. 这个新来的小孩非常羞怯，当别的小孩在外面玩耍的时候，他总是一个人坐在角落里。

同　diffidence n. 羞怯

构　dif < dis (=not) + fid (=trust) + ent

Lesson 19





音频



Group 69: fin=end “结束；目的”

confine［kən'faɪn］

vt. 限制，禁闭

解　to keep within limits; to restrict; to keep in; to shut in

例　The farmer confined the pigs with a fence so they wouldn' t run away. 农夫把猪关在栅栏里，这样它们就不会跑掉。

同　confinement n. 监禁

构　con (=together) + fin (=end) + e

define［dɪ'faɪn］

v. 下定义

解　to make clear the meaning of; to explain

例　An English-Chinese dictionary can define words but can not truly explain the cultural significance behind them. 英汉词典可以给单词下定义，但是无法真正解释其背后的文化意义。

definite［'defɪnət］

adj. 确定的

解　clear or exact; not vague

例　I expect a definite answer, either yes or no. 我期待一个确切的答案，要么是，要么不是。

同　indefinite adj. 不清楚的，模糊的；不确定的

definitive［dɪ'fɪnɪtɪv］

adj. 最后的，确定的，权威性的

解　supplying or being a final or conclusive settlement; conclusive

例　Carl Sandburg's Abraham Lincoln may be regarded as the definitive work on the life of the Great Emancipator. 卡尔·桑德堡所写的《亚伯拉罕·林肯》可以被认为是把这位伟大的解放者的生平诠释得最好的作品。

构　de (=intensive) + fin (=end) + itive

definition［ˌdefɪ'nɪʃən］

n. ① 定义 ② （轮廓等）清晰，明确

解　① a statement of the meaning of a word, phrase, or term, as in a dictionary entry ② the state of being closely outlined or determined

例　Their marriage was doomed to fail because they each had a different definition of commitment. 他们的婚姻注定要失败，因为他们各自对承诺有着不同的定义。

finality［faɪ'nælɪti］

n. 结束

解　the state or quality of being final or complete

例　His boss ended the conversation with a tone of finality and he went back to work. 他的老板用结束的语气停止了谈话，于是他回去干活了。

finale［fɪ'nɑ:li］

n. 终曲；乐曲的最后部分

解　conclusion

例　It is not until we reach the finale of this play that we can understand the author's message. 直到看到剧本的结尾处，我们才理解了作者想要传达的信息。

infinite［'ɪnfɪnət］

adj. 无穷的，无限的

解　without limits or bounds; endless

例　The number of stars in the universe is almost infinite. 宇宙中星星的数量几乎是无穷的。

同　finite adj. 有限的

构　in (=not) + fin (=end) + ite





infinity［ɪn'fɪnəti］

n. 无限的时间或空间

解　boundless or immeasurable extension or duration

例　The infinity of the universe transcends logic. 宇宙的无穷无尽超越了逻辑的范畴。

infinitesimal［ɪnˌfɪnə'tesɪməl］

adj. 极微小的

解　infinitely or immeasurably small; tiny

例　High-powered microscopes have made infinitesimal objects visible. 高性能的显微镜使得极微小的物体变得可见。

affinity［ə'fɪnəti］

n. 亲密关系；吸引力

解　a natural attraction or feeling of kinship

例　She had a strong affinity for chocolate when she was depressed and she could not resist eating it. 当她情绪低落时，巧克力对她来说有一种强烈的吸引力，她忍不住要去吃。

构　af (=to, near) + fin (=end) + ity



其他与“结尾；终点”意义有关的词汇

coda n. 音乐尾声，尾声

denouement n. （小说的）结尾，结局

epilogue n. 尾声；收场白；后记

peroration n. 演讲结尾部分，结论

terminate v. 终止，结束

termination n. 终结

terminus n. （火车、汽车）终点站

interminable adj. 无尽头的





Group 70: flect, flex=bend “弯曲”

flex［fleks］

v. 弯曲

解　to bend

例　She flexed her stiff arm slowly. 她慢慢地弯曲僵硬的胳膊。

近　flax n. 亚麻；apex n. 顶点，最高点；appendix n. 附录；阑尾

flexible［'fleksəbəl］

adj. ① 灵活的 ② 柔软的，易弯曲的

解　① able to adjust readily to different conditions ② able to flex, able to bend easily

例　Leather, rubber, and wire are flexible. 皮革、橡胶和金属丝是可以弯曲的。

同　flexibility n. 弹性，灵活性；柔韧性；inflexible adj. 顽固的；不灵活的，僵硬的

deflect［dɪ'flekt］

v. 偏离，使偏斜，转向

解　to turn from a straight course or fixed direction; avert

例　Engineers deflected the runaway train onto a secondary track. 工程师把失控的火车转到备用轨道上。

构　de (=away) + flect (=to bend)

reflect［rɪ'flekt］

v. ① 反射 ② 仔细考虑

解　① to turn back or throw back (light, heat, sound, etc. ) ② to think carefully

例　Take time to reflect before making a decision. 在作决定之前，花点时间思考一下。

同　reflection n. 反射；思考；reflective adj. 深思熟虑的；反射的



其他与“弯曲”意义有关的词汇

askew adj. 弯曲的，歪斜的

bend v. 弯曲

curved adj. 弯曲的

devious adj. 不正直的；弯曲的

lithe adj. 柔软的，易弯曲的

pliable adj. 易弯的，柔软的

sinuous adj. 弯弯曲曲的，蜿蜒的

tortuous adj. 弯弯曲曲的；不直接阐明的

warp n./v. 翘起，弯曲

yielding adj. 弯曲自如的，灵活的

Lesson 20





音频



Group 71: flu=flow “流动”

fluent［'flu(:)ənt］

adj. 流利的

解　able to speak or write clearly and easily

例　A language student cannot be truly fluent without living in the country where the language is spoken daily. 对于学语言的学生来说，如果没有在每天使用这种语言的国家生活过，很难真正把外语说得流利。

构　flu (=to flow) + ent

affluent［'æflʊənt］

adj. 富裕的，丰富的

解　rich; having an abundant supply of money or possessions of value

例　Mr. Wilson must be very wealthy because his address is in the most affluent neighborhood in the city. 威尔逊先生一定很富有，因为他的住址位于这个城市的富人区。

同　affluence n. 富裕，富足

confluence［'kɒnflʊəns］

n. 汇流处；合流，汇流

解　the place where two things come together; a flowing together

例　The land near the confluence of the river would often get flooded when it rained heavily. 当雨下得很大时，河流汇合点附近的这片土地经常被淹没。

构　con (=together) + flu (=to flow) + ence

influence［'ɪnflʊəns］

n./v. 影响

解　n. power of acting on others and having an effect without using force v. to have an influence on

例　Use your influence to persuade your friends to join our club. 利用你的影响力来说服你的朋友们加入我们的俱乐部吧。

influential［ˌɪnflʊ'enʃəl］

adj. 有影响力的

解　having much influence

例　The influential politician was widely respected by both parties as well as the general public. 这位有影响力的政治家受到两个政党和普通群众的广泛尊敬。

fluid［'flu(:)ɪd］

n. 液体，流体 adj. 流动的，不固定的

解　n. substance that flows adj. able to flow as gases and liquids do

例　The triathlete was dehydrated because he didn't consume enough fluids during the race. 这位参加三项全能比赛的运动员脱水了，因为他在比赛期间没有补充足够的水分。

同　fluidity n. 流动性，液体性

influx［'ɪnflʌks］

n. 流入

解　flowing into

例　The influx of refugees into the country has taxed the relief agencies severely. 难民涌入这个国家，给救济机构带来了沉重的压力。





mellifluous［mə'lɪflʊəs］

adj. （声音、音乐等）流畅的，甜美的

解　sweetly or smoothly flowing

例　The poet always attracted a large audience to her public readings not really because of the quality of her poetry, but because of her mellifluous voice. 这位诗人总是能吸引大量的观众去参加她的公开读书会，这不是因为她的诗歌质量很高，而是因为她的嗓音甜美。

superfluous［ˌsju:'pɜ:flʊəs］

adj. 多余的，过剩的

解　more than is needed, desired, or required; unnecessary

例　The writing professor assigned a word limit to his essay assignment so students would be less likely to use superfluous words. 写作课教授对给学生布置的写作作业设置了字数限制，这样学生们就不太可能出现字数过多的情况。

同　superfluity n. 多余，累赘

fluctuate［'flʌktjʊeɪt］

v. 波动；（使）起伏，变化

解　to rise and fall; to change continually; to waver

例　The temperature fluctuates from day to day. 气温每天都在变化。

同　fluctuation n. 波动，变动



Group 72: fore=before “前面；预先”

forebear［'fɔbə(r)］

n. 祖先

解　a person from whom you are descended

例　Amanda did a genealogy study to find out who her forebears were. 阿曼达研究了家谱，想知道谁是她的祖先。

foreboding［fɔ:'bəʊdɪŋ］

n. 不祥预感，预兆

解　an unfavorable omen

例　The knight had a foreboding that something bad would happen if he entered the dragon's lair. 骑士有一种不祥的预感：如果自己进入龙穴，就会有不好的事情发生。

foresee［fɔ:'si:］

v. 预见

解　to realize beforehand; to anticipate

例　Nostradamus claimed he could foresee the future and wrote a famous book of all his prophecies. 占卜者诺斯特罗达姆声称自己能预测未来，并写了一本很著名的书，将自己所有的预言都囊括在内。

同　foresight n. 预见，先见，深谋远虑

forestall［fɔ:'stɔ:l］

v. 预先阻止，先发制人

解　to prevent by taking action in advance

例　By setting up a prenuptial agreement, the prospective bride and groom hoped to forestall any potential arguments about money in the event of a divorce. 通过制定婚前协议，这对将要结婚的新人希望能够提前避免将来万一离婚可能带来的财产纠纷。

构　fore (=before) + stall (=to put)



其他与“预见；预示”意义有关的词汇

prescience n. 先见之明，预见

prescient adj. 预知的，有先见之明的

presentiment n. 预感

prophesy v. 预言，预告

prophet n. 预言者

premonition n. 预感

adumbrate v. （对将来事件）预示

bode v. 预示

prefiguration n. 预示；预想

augury n. 占卜；预言，征兆

omen n. 征兆，预兆（指凶兆）

ominous adj. 凶兆的，不祥的

symptom n. 病兆，症状

precursory adj. 先驱的，先兆的

sibyl n. 女巫，女预言家，女先知





Group 73: form=shape “形状”

deform［dɪ'fɔ:m］

v. 使变形

解　to cause to assume a crooked or angular form

例　They left their favorite CD on the dashboard and the heat from the summer sun deformed it. 他们把最喜欢的那张CD放在了汽车的仪表板上，结果它被夏天的太阳给晒变形了。

构　de (=away) + form (=form)

transform［træns'fɔ:m］

v. 使…变形，变化

解　to change in structure, appearance, or character

例　Do you really think that you can transform your appearance by wearing your hair differently? 你真的认为换个发型就能改变你的形象吗？

构　trans (=across) + form (=form)

formality［fɔ:'mæləti］

n. 礼节，仪式；拘泥形式

解　something required by custom or rule; outward form; stiffness of manner, behavior, or arrangement

例　At a wedding there are many formalities. 婚礼上有许多仪式。

formation［fɔ:'meɪʃən］

n. 编队，队形

解　an arrangement of people or things acting as a unit

例　The band marched in perfect parade formation. 乐队以完美的队形进场。

formulate［'fɔ:mjʊleɪt］

v. 明确表达

解　to express clearly and exactly

例　If I were called on to formulate one basic rule for successful living, it would be Aristotle's: know yourself! 如果要我明确说出成功生活的一项基本的规则，我觉得应该是亚里士多德的那句话：认识你自己！

同　formulation n. 公式化表达；陈述；reformulate v. 重新系统表达

conform［kən'fɔ:m］

v. 使一致；遵守，顺从

解　to obey or be in accordance with established rules

例　The professor told the students blatantly that they can either conform to his rules or fail. 教授明确告诉学生，如果他们不遵从他制定的规则就会不及格。

同　conformity n. 符合，一致；遵从

conformist［kən'fɔ:mɪst］

n. 遵奉习俗者，墨守成规的人

解　someone who conforms to established standards of conduct

例　He was not a conformist and refused to follow the status quo. 他不是一个墨守成规的人，拒绝维持现状。

同　nonconformist n. 我行我素的人，不遵循社会常规的人 adj. 不遵循社会常规的

performance［pə'fɔ:məns］

n. ① 演出，表演 ② 行为，行动

解　① the giving of a play, concert, circus, or other show ② thing performed; act

例　His peerless performance won him a prize. 他无与伦比的表演使他获得了一个奖项。

同　performer n. 表演者

Group 74: fort, forc=strong “强大；力量”

effortless［'efətləs］

adj. 不费力的

解　requiring or showing little or no effort; easy

例　The cat pounced on the mouse with an effortless leap. 猫轻轻一跳，扑过去抓住了老鼠。

fortify［'fɔ:tɪfaɪ］

v. 加强

解　to make strong or stronger

例　The castle was fortified before it was attacked. 在遭到袭击前，城堡被加固了。

同　fortification n. 加强

fortitude［'fɔ:tɪtju:d］

n. 坚强

解　courage in facing pain, danger, or trouble; firmness of spirit

例　The spy's fortitude kept him from revealing his country's secrets when he was captured and questioned. 这名间谍拥有坚强的意志，在他被捕获并遭受拷问时，都没有泄露自己国家的机密。

forcibly［'fɔ:səbəli］

adv. 强行地

解　made or done by force; using force

例　The foreign traveler complained that he had been forcibly held by the local police without good reason. 这名外国游客控诉称，他被当地警察在没有正当理由的情况下强行扣留。

enforce［ɪn'fɔ:s］

vt. 强迫；执行，实施

解　to force obedience to; to cause to be carried out; force

例　The police enforced the law on the rioters. 警察对暴徒强制执行法律。

reinforce［ˌri:ɪn'fɔ:s］

v. 加强力量，增援

解　to strengthen or support

例　To stop the intruder from breaking in, she reinforced the door with her furniture. 为了阻止侵入者破门而入，她用家具抵住了房门。

构　re (=again) + in (=in) + forc (=strong) + e



Group 75: fract=break “打碎”

fractious［'frækʃəs］

adj. （脾气）易怒的，好争吵的

解　irritable, peevish

例　The headmaster warned the fractious student that if he caused any more trouble he would be expelled from school. 校长警告这名爱惹是生非的学生，如果他再制造麻烦，就将被开除。

fracture［'fræktʃə(r)］

v. （使）破碎；骨折 n. ① 骨折；折断 ② 裂口

解　v. to break; to crack n. ① a breaking of a bone or cartilage ② breaking

例　The doctor told him that his arm hurt so much because it had suffered a bone fracture and he would need to wear a cast for two months. 医生告诉他，他的胳膊骨折了，伤得非常严重，需要打两个月的石膏。

refractory［rɪ'fræktəri］

adj. ① 倔强的，难驾驭的 ② （病）难治的

解　① resisting control, discipline, etc., willful; stubborn ② not yielding to treatment

例　The refractory child would not sit still and drove his babysitter crazy. 这个不听话的小孩不愿安静地坐着，都快把保姆逼疯了。

构　re (=again) + fract (=to break) + ory

infraction［ɪn'frækʃən］

n. 违法

解　a breaking of a law or obligation; violation

例　The company was sued for its infraction of the copyrights of a rival company. 该公司因侵犯其竞争对手的版权而被起诉。

构　in (=in, into, against) + fract (=to break) + ion





其他与“碎，碎屑”意义有关的词汇

shatter v. 粉碎

mince v. 剁碎，切碎；小步走路

brittle adj. 易碎的；脆弱的

fragile adj. 易碎的；易坏的

friable adj. 易碎的，脆弱的

cracking n. 敲碎

crumble v. 弄碎，压碎；崩毁

crush v. 碾碎

chip n. 碎片

detritus n. 碎屑，无价值之物

scrap n. 小片，碎屑 v. 废弃

sawdust n. 锯末，锯屑

filing n. 锉屑

crumb n. 饼屑，面包屑；小量

gravel n. 碎石，砂砾

shard n. （陶器等的）碎片，破片

shred n. 碎布条





Group 76: front=forehead; face “前额；正面”

frontier［'frʌntɪə(r)］

n. 边疆

解　an international boundary or the area along such a boundary

例　The frontier between the United States and Canada is not fortified. 美国和加拿大之间的边界没有修建防御工事。

up-front［ʌp'frʌnt］

adj. ① 提前的 （指支付工资）② 坦率的

解　① paid or due in advance ② straightforward; frank

例　He would do the work only if he was paid up-front. 只有预先支付了薪水，他才愿意做这份工作。

affront［ə'frʌnt］

v. 侮辱，冒犯

解　to insult someone openly and on purpose

例　The boy affronted his sister by calling her a pig. 男孩侮辱他妹妹，说她是头猪。

构　af (=to) + front (=forehead, face)

confront［kən'frʌnt］

v. ① 面对，面临 ② 对抗

解　① to be or come face to face with ② to be opposite to

例　If you confront your problems honestly and openly, instead of trying to hide them, you will have a better chance of solving them. 如果你诚实、坦然地面对自己的问题，而不是试图隐瞒它们，那么你解决这些问题的可能性就更大。

同　confrontation n. 对抗

构　con (=together) + front (=forehead, face)

effrontery［e'frʌntəri］

n. 厚颜无耻；无礼

解　impudence; shameless, boldness

例　She had the effrontery to insult the guest. 她竟敢厚颜无耻地辱骂客人。

构　ef < ex (=out) + front (=forehead) + ery



Group 77: funct=perform “活动”

functional［'fʌŋkʃənəl］

adj. ① 实用的 ② 有功能的；在起作用的

解　① practical ② having a function; working

例　The functional wings of an insect are those used for flying. 昆虫翅膀的功能是飞翔。

functionary［'fʌŋkʃənəri］

n. 公务员；小职员

解　official

例　The functionary at the reception was responsible for making sure guests had tickets. 接待处的职员负责对来宾进行检票。

dysfunctional［dɪs'fʌnkʃənəl］

adj. 功能紊乱的；（人际关系）不良的，不和睦的

解　maladjusted; not following the normal patterns of social behaviour

例　Both parents were alcoholics and were considered dysfunctional. 这对父母都是酗酒者，关系不和睦。

malfunction［mæl'fʌŋkʃən］

n. 故障，障碍 v. 发生故障

解　n. an improper functioning; failure to work or perform v. to function badly; to work or perform improperly

例　The computer virus spread through the office intranet and caused the malfunction of the computers. 这种电脑病毒在办公室内网传播，使许多电脑发生故障。

perfunctory［pə'fʌŋktəri］

adj. 草率的，敷衍的

解　done as a duty or routine but without care or interest; doing things without concern or solicitude

例　He overlooked many weaknesses when he inspected the factory in a perfunctory manner. 他视察工厂的时候敷衍了事，忽视了许多问题。

构　per (=falsely) + funct (=to perform) + ory

Lesson 22





音频



Group 78: fus=pour “流，泻”

suffuse［sə'fju:z］

v. （色彩等）弥漫，染遍

解　to spread over

例　A blush suffused her cheeks when we teased her about her boyfriend. 当我们用她的男朋友跟她开玩笑时，她的脸颊一下子就红了。

diffuse［dɪ'fju:z］

adj. 漫射的，散漫的 v. 散布，（光等）漫射

解　adj. spread out, not concentrated in one place v. pour out or spread widely

例　The rumors diffused around the audience that the speaker was the prime minister. “演讲者就是首相”的传言在观众中传播开来。

effusive［ɪ'fju:sɪv］

adj. ① 过分表达感情的 ② 流出的

解　① showing too much feeling too demonstrative and emotional ② overflowing

例　Every visitor noticed that her effusive welcome was not sincere. 每个来访者都注意到，她过分表现出来的欢迎并不是真诚的。

构　ef < ex (=out) + fus (=to pour) + ive

infuse［ɪn'fju:z］

v. 灌输；使…充满

解　to teach and impress by frequent repetitions or admonitions

例　The new manager infused enthusiasm and responsibility in the staff. 新上任的经理向员工灌输了热情与责任。

profuse［prə'fju:s］

adj. 丰富的，大量的

解　produced or growing in extreme abundance

例　Pressure must be applied to a wound to stop profuse bleeding. 必须按压伤口，才能防止出血过多。

同　profusion n. 丰富，大量；浪费

构　pro (=forth) + fus (=to pour) + e

defuse［di:'fu:z］

v. 从（爆破装置）中卸除引信

解　to remove the fuse from (an explosive device)

例　The movie reached its climax when the spy had to defuse the atomic bomb before it blew up. 在间谍不得不在原子弹爆炸前拆除引信时，影片达到了高潮。

近　fuse n. 导火索 v. 融合；fusion n. 融合；fusillade n. （枪炮）齐射，连发；fuss n./v. 大惊小怪



Group 79: gen=birth; creation “出生；产生”

generality［ˌʤenə'ræləti］

n. 概说；大多数；大部分

解　a general or vague statement; the greater portion or number; the majority

例　Politicians are known to give generalities instead of specific responses when answering difficult questions from reporters. 众所周知，在回答记者们提出的刁难问题时，政治家通常会笼统作答，而不会给出确切的答案。

generalization［ˌʤenərəlaɪ'zeɪʃən］

n. 概括

解　a general idea, statement, principle, or rule

例　That all Americans have blonde hair and blue eyes is a rampant generalization. 人们通常将所有美国人的特征都泛泛归纳为金发碧眼。

generic［ʤɪ'nerɪk］

adj. 种类的，类属的

解　shared by or including a whole group or class

例　Generic products tend to be much cheaper than brand name products. 非专利产品往往比品牌产品便宜得多。

genial［'ʤi:niəl］

adj. 和蔼的，愉快的，脾气好的

解　cheerful, friendly, and good-tempered

例　It is easier to get along with genial people than rude people. 与友好的人相处要比与粗鲁的人相处简单得多。

同　geniality n. 和蔼，温和

congenial［kən'ʤi:niəl］

adj. 意气相投的

解　having similar tastes and interests; getting on well together

例　Congenial companions made the trip pleasant. 意气相投的伙伴使旅途变得愉快。

构　con (=with) + gen (=birth) + ial





generation［ˌʤenə'reɪʃən］

n. ① 产生，发生 ② 一代，一代人

解　① bringing into being; generating ② all the people born about the same time

例　This heirloom has been passed down from mother to daughter for over ten generations. 这件传家宝从母亲传到女儿，整整传了十几代人。

generator［'ʤenəreɪtə(r)］

n. 发电机

解　a machine that changes mechanical energy into electrical energy and produces either direct or alternating current

例　Our family bought a power generator for our house so that when a rainstorm cuts off our electricity next time, we can go along as though nothing had happened. 我们家买了一台发电机，这样当下次因风暴而断电的时候，我们就可以照常生活，不受任何影响。

近　progenitor n. 祖先，始祖

engender［ɪn'ʤendə(r)］

v. 产生，引起

解　to cause to exist

例　Janet used fertilizer when watering her garden in order to engender giant tomatoes. 为了让西红柿长得大一点，珍妮特在浇灌菜园时使用了化肥。

构　en (=to make) + gen (=birth, creation) + der

regenerate［rɪ'ʤenəreɪt］

v. 改过自新；再生 adj. 改过自新的，新生的

解　v. to be formed or shaped anew adj. born again spiritually; formed anew morally

例　Unlike humans who have to rely on prosthetics many insects can naturally regenerate a limb if it breaks off. 人类必须依赖修复术才能使自己康复；许多昆虫则不同，它们可以在肢体受到损坏时自然地重新生长出来。

degenerate［dɪ'ʤenəreɪt］

v. ① 退化，退步 ② 堕落

解　① become worse; deteriorate ② to sink into a low intellectual or moral state

例　The abandoned house degenerated into a pile of wood after many years. 许多年后，这所被废弃的房子最终变成了一堆木头。

构　de (=down) + gen (=birth, creation) + erate



Group 80: gnor, gnos=know “知道”

ignorant［'ɪɡnərənt］

adj. ① 无知的 ② 不知道的，消息不灵通的

解　① lacking basic knowledge ② unaware or uninformed

例　Because Barbara had been ill, she was ignorant of the change in the date for the final examination. 由于芭芭拉生病了，她不知道期末考试的时间已经发生了变化。

同　ignorance n. 愚昧无知

构　i < in (=not) + gnor (=to know) + ant

agnostic［æɡ'nɒstɪk］

n. 不可知论者

解　a person who doubts truth of religion

例　Rebelling against the religious training of his youth, he was for many years an agnostic. 他年轻的时候就反抗宗教培训，多年来一直是个不可知论者。

构　a (=not) + gnos (=to know) + tic

diagnose［'daɪəɡnəʊz］

v. 诊断

解　find out the nature of by examination and careful study; identify

例　The doctor diagnosed the disease as measles. 医生将这种疾病诊断为麻疹。

近　nose n. 鼻子；嗅觉；nostrum n. 秘方药，万灵丹



Group 81: grad=step; degree “步；级”

retrograde［'retrəɡreɪd］

adj. 倒退的，后退的 v. 倒退

解　adj. moving backward; becoming worse v. move or go backward

例　Instead of advancing, our civilization seems to have retrograded in ethics and culture. 我们的文明没有进步，似乎反而在道德和文化方面倒退了。

downgrade［'daʊnɡreɪd］

v. 贬低

解　to rate lower in value or esteem

例　He downgrades people he does not like, in spite of their merits. 他对他不喜欢的人统统进行贬低，不管他们有什么优点。





low-grade［ləʊ'ɡreɪd］

adj. 低品质的

解　of inferior quality

例　Purchasing low-grade gasoline can save you money in the short term, but may ruin your car and cost you a lot in the long run. 从短期来看，购买低品质的汽油可以为你省钱，但是从长远来看，却会毁坏你的汽车，而且会让你花费更多的钱。

gradual［'ɡrædjʊəl］

adj. 逐渐的

解　changing step by step; moving little by little

例　A child's growth into an adult is gradual. 从儿童到成人是一个逐渐变化的过程。



其他与“步子”意义有关的词汇

gait n. 步态，步法

pace n. 步调

lope v. 大步慢跑；轻快地迈着大步 n. 轻快的步伐

stride v. 大步行走，阔步

out-of-phase adj. 不同步的

asynchronous adj. 异步的，非同时性的

音频



Group 82: grand=great “大；伟大”

grandeur［'ɡrænʤə(r)］

n. 宏伟壮丽，伟大

解　the quality of being magnificent or splendid or grand

例　The backpackers delighted in the grandeur of the wilderness. 背包客们喜欢旷野的壮丽景色。

grandiose［'ɡrændɪəʊs］

adj. 宏伟的，浮夸的

解　impressive because of unnecessary largeness or grandeur

例　His grandiose words were always backed up with little action, which made people lose their faith in him. 他总是夸夸其谈而行动甚少，使得人们都对他失去了信任。

同　grandiosity n. 宏伟，浮夸

grandiloquent［ɡræn'dɪləkwənt］

adj. 夸张的，浮夸的

解　speaking in or characterized by a pompous style

例　The politician could never speak simply; she was always grandiloquent. 这个政客从来不会言简意赅地说话；她总是言语夸张，让人不明所以。

同　grandiloquence n. 夸大之辞

aggrandize［ə'ɡrændaɪz］

v. ① 增大，扩大（权势、地位、财富）② 赞美

解　① to make someone or a nation greater in power, wealth, rank, etc. ② to praise

例　Professor Osborne told the student that her question aggrandized the scope of today's class topic and he would explain the answer to her after class. 奥斯本教授告诉这名学生，她的问题超过了今天课堂主题的范围，他会在课后为她解答。

构　ag (=to) + grand (=great) + ize



Group 83: grat=thank; pleasing “感激；高兴”

gratify［'ɡrætɪfaɪ］

v. 使高兴，使满足

解　to give pleasure or satisfaction to; to give what is desired; to please

例　The mother bought her crying son the robot toy in order to gratify him. 为了让哭闹的儿子高兴，妈妈给他买了个机器人玩具。

同　gratification n. 满足；喜悦

gratitude［'ɡrætɪtju:d］

n. 感激

解　kindly feeling because of a favor received; desire to do a favor in return; thankfulness

例　The guests expressed their gratitude to the host by bringing a bottle of wine to the party. 为了感谢主人的款待，客人们带了瓶酒来参加聚会。

gratis［'ɡreɪtɪs］

adj. 免费的

解　free

例　Breakfast was gratis for hotel guests. 入住酒店的客人可以免费享用早餐。





gratuity［ɡrə'tju:əti］

n. 赏钱，小费

解　an award (as for meritorious service) given without claim or obligation

例　The restaurant automatically charged a 15% gratuity for a group of ten or more guests. 饭店对10人或10人以上的客人自动收取15%的小费。

gratuitous［ɡrə'tju(:)ɪtəs］

adj. ① 无缘无故的 ② 免费的

解　① without cause ② free

例　The opening ceremony offered gratuitous souvenirs for the visitors to take home with them. 开幕式为来宾提供免费的纪念品，他们可以带回去留作纪 念。



Group 84: greg=collect; group “收集；群体”

aggregate［'æɡrɪɡeɪt］

v. ① 聚集，集合 ② 合计

解　① to collect into a mass ② to sum; total

例　When her monthly expenses were aggregated, they amounted to double her salary. 她每月的开销合计起来是她收入的两倍。

同　disaggregate v. 分散

构　ag (=to) + greg (=to collect) + ate

congregate［'kɒŋɡrɪɡeɪt］

v. 聚集，集合

解　to move together

例　Everyone at the bar congregated around the big-screen TV when the football game started. 足球比赛开始的时候，酒吧里的所有人都聚集在了大屏幕电视机前。

同　congregation n. 聚集；集会；集合在一起的群众

近　conglomerate adj. 成团的 v. 聚集

gregarious［ɡrɪ'ɡərɪəs］

adj. ① 群居的 ② 爱社交的

解　① living in flocks, herds, or other group ② seeking and enjoying the company of others

例　The gregarious girl always seemed to have friends calling her. 这个爱社交的女孩似乎总有朋友打电话来找她。

同　gregariousness n. 喜爱社交，合群



Group 85: gress=walk “行走”

aggressive［ə'ɡresɪv］

adj. ① 好斗的；侵略性的 ② 敢作敢为的，有闯劲的

解　① marked by combative readiness ② having or showing determination and energetic pursuit of one's ends

例　We need an aggressive mayor to solve our city's problems. 我们需要一个敢作敢为的市长来解决本市的问题。

同　aggression n. 进攻，侵略

构　ag (=to) + gress (=to walk) + ive

digress［daɪ'ɡres］

v. 离题，把（话题）叉开

解　to turn aside esp. from the main subject of attention or course of argument

例　The conversation on politics at dinner digressed into an argument about which dessert tasted better. 晚餐时，大家原本关于政治的讨论最后演变成了关于哪个甜点更可口的争论。

同　digression n. 离题；枝节；digressive adj. 离题的

构　di < dis (=apart) + gress (=to walk)

progressive［prə'ɡresɪv］

adj. ① 进步的 ② 循序渐进的

解　① making progress; advancing to something better; moving forward ② proceeding in steps; continuing steadily by increments

例　The national economy has seen progressive reform within the last few years. 在过去短短几年的时间里，国家经济发生了渐变式的变化。

regressive［rɪ'ɡresɪv］

adj. 退步的，退化的，回归的

解　tending to return or revert

例　The unemployed banking executive preferred to wait for any opening in his profession rather than to take a regressive job. 这个失业的银行经理宁愿等待他所从事的行业出现职位空缺，也不愿找一个稍差一些的工作。

同　regression n. 退化

transgress［træns'ɡres; trænz-］

v. 违反，违背；冒犯

解　to go beyond (a proper or legal limit)

例　The safety rules for the science lab are based on long experience, and if you transgress them, you may have to pay a heavy price. 科学实验室的安全条例是基于长期的经验而制定的，如果违反了条例，可能就要付出沉重的代价。

同　transgression n. 违规，违背

构　trans (=across) + gress (=to walk)

egress［'i:ɡres］

n. 出口，出去 v. 外出

解　n. a place or means of going out v. to go out

例　The egress in case of a fire is on either side of the hallway and down the stairs. 发生火灾时的紧急出口位于走廊的两侧和楼梯的下面。

构　e (=out) + gress (=to walk)

Lesson 24

Group 86: hab, habit=live; have “居住；有”

habitable［'hæbɪtəbəl］

adj. 可居住的

解　fit to live in; able to be inhabited

例　The distant planet's habitable lands raised inquiries about the presence of life forms. 这个遥远的星球存在可居住的土地，这激发起了人们对其上是否有生命形式存在的探询。

habituate［hə'bɪtjueɪt］

vt. 使习惯于，使熟悉于

解　to make used; accustom

例　He never became habituated to American food and often cooked his own meals. 他一直没有习惯美国的饮食，总是自己下厨。

habitual［hə'bɪtjʊəl］

adj. 习惯的，惯常的

解　done by habit; caused by habit; regular

例　He can't get started in the morning without his habitual cup of coffee. 早上不习惯性地喝一杯咖啡的话，他就没法开始工作。

habitat［'hæbɪtæt］

n. （动植物的）生活环境，产地，栖息地

解　place where an animal or plant naturally lives or grows

例　The jungle is the habitat of monkeys. 丛林是猴子的栖息地。

cohabit［kəʊ'hæbɪt］

vi. （男女）同居（尤指未婚而同居者）

解　to live together as husband and wife do

例　They cohabited for two years until they could not bear each other any more. 他们同居了两年，直到无法再忍受彼此。

rehabilitate［ˌri:(h)ə'bɪlɪteɪt］

v. 修复，恢复（原状、名誉等）

解　to restore to one's former position

例　The athlete needed at least two weeks to rehabilitate his leg. 这名运动员至少需要两周的时间来恢复腿伤。

同　rehabilitation n. （身心等）康复，恢复；改邪归正

构　re (=again) + hab (=to have; to live) + ilitate



Group 87: hand=hand “手”

handily［'hændɪli］

adv. 轻易地

解　in an easy manner

例　The prolific factory handily met and welcomed the increased market demands for more Christmas gifts. 这个工厂产量很高，很轻松地就满足了市场对圣诞礼物的大量需求，并希望越多越好。

handle［'hændəl］

n. 把手，把柄 v. 处理

解　n. a part of a thing made to be held or grasped by the hand v. to deal with

例　Spoons, pitchers, hammers, and pails have handles. 调羹、水罐、锤子和提桶都有把手。

handcuff［'hændkʌf］

n. 手铐

解　a metal loop that can be locked around the wrist, usually used in pairs

例　The policemen put handcuffs on the thief as soon as they caught him on the bus. 警察在公共汽车上逮捕了小偷后，立刻给他戴上了手铐。

handshake［'hændʃeɪk］

n. 握手

解　act of clasping and shaking of each other's hands in friendship, agreement, greeting, etc.

例　A firm handshake with good eye contact is considered a prerequisite for the start of a good job interview. 有力的握手和良好的眼神交流是面试成功的先决条件。

handwriting［'hændraɪtɪŋ］

n. 笔迹，书法

解　writing by hand; manner or style of writing

例　He recognized his mother's handwriting on the envelope. 他认出信封上的字是母亲所写。





offhand［ˌɒf'hænd］

adj. 即兴的，当场的

解　without preparation

例　His offhand speech was given without notes or preparation. 他的即兴演讲是在没有草稿、没作事先准备的前提下进行的。



Group 88: hap=chance; luck “机会；运气”

hapless［'hæpləs］

adj. 不幸的

解　unlucky

例　It was a hapless day for him; everything seemed to be going wrong. 今天对他来说是不幸的一天，好像什么事情都不顺利。

mishap［'mɪshæp］

n. 不幸，坏运气

解　an instance of misfortune; mischance

例　When his basketball broke the window, Bruce immediately apologized and paid for the mishap. 布鲁斯的篮球把窗玻璃打碎了，他立即道歉并赔偿了损失。

haphazard［hæp'hæzəd］

adj. ① 偶然的 ② 随便的

解　① dependent upon or characterized by chance ② random

例　His haphazard approach to study resulted in him missing many homework assignments. 他对待学习的随意态度导致他有很多家庭作业都没有完成。

构　hap (=chance) + hazard (=game of chance)

音频



Group 89: head=head “头”

heading［'hedɪŋ］

n. ① 航向 ② 标题

解　① direction toward which an aircraft or ship is moving ② something written or printed at the top of a page or at the beginning of a chapter, topic, etc.

例　A letterhead and a chapter title are types of headings. 信笺的抬头和章节标题都是标题的不同形式。

headstrong［'hedstrɒŋ; (US)-strɔ:ŋ］

adj. 不听命令的，顽固的，任性的

解　habitually disposed to disobedience and opposition

例　The headstrong woman insisted she was right. 这个顽固的女人坚持认为自己是对的。

hot-headed［ˌhɒt'hedɪd］

adj. 急躁的，鲁莽的

解　characterized by undue haste and lack of thought or deliberation

例　Tyrone became very hot-headed if someone joked about his ethnicity. 如果有人拿蒂龙的种族开玩笑的话，他会变得非常冲动。

figurehead［'fɪɡəhed］

n. 傀儡领袖，名义领袖

解　a head or chief in name only

例　The army invaded the country and picked as a figurehead a local person that people could relate to. 军队入侵了这个国家，从当地人之中挑选了一个大家都比较熟悉的人作为名誉领袖。



Group 90: heart=heart “心”

heartfelt［'hɑ:tfelt］

adj. 衷心的

解　very sincere

例　He expressed his heartfelt sympathy to her for the death of her father. 她的父亲去世了，他对她表达了深切的慰问。

heartiness［'hɑ:tinəs］

n. 热诚，诚挚

解　the quality of hearty sincerity

例　The owners of the little inn always provided service to their guests with heartiness. 这家小旅馆的主人总是热心地为客人提供服务。

fainthearted［ˌfeɪnt'hɑ:tɪd］

adj. 懦弱的，胆小的

解　lacking courage; cowardly

例　The fainthearted boy was too scared to fight the older boy who bullied him. 这个胆小的男孩很害怕，不敢与欺负他的大男孩打架。

构　faint adj. 无力的；微弱的

lighthearted［ˌlaɪt'hɑ:tɪd］

adj. 快乐的，无忧无虑的

解　free from worry

例　The boss did not offer the lighthearted woman the position of manager because of his fear that she would be irresponsible. 老板没有让这个总是无忧无虑的女人担任经理一职，因为他担心她会没有责任心。

stouthearted［ˌstaʊt'hɑ:tɪd］

adj. 勇敢的

解　having courage; brave

例　Armed with a stouthearted spirit, the little boy was able to knock the giant down. 小男孩用刚毅的精神鼓舞自己，然后把巨人打倒了。

hearten［'hɑ:tən］

vt. 鼓励，激励

解　to cheer up; to encourage

例　This good news will hearten you. 这个好消息会使你振作起来。





Group 91: hydr=water “水”

hydrate［'haɪdreɪt］

v. 使成水化物，与水化合 n. 水化物

解　v. to add water or moisture n. any chemical compound made when certain substances chemically unite with water

例　The purpose of this experiment is to determine the empirical formula of a hydrate. 这个实验的目的是确定一种水化物的实验式。

近　hydrogen n. 氢气

dehydrate［ˌdi:haɪ'dreɪt］

v. ① 除去水分 ② （使）脱水

解　① to take water or moisture from; dry ② lose water or moisture

例　After traveling in the desert for five hours without water, they were dehydrated. 他们在沙漠中走了五个小时没有喝水，最后都脱水了。

同　dehydration n. 脱水，干燥

carbohydrate［ˌkɑ:bəʊ'haɪdreɪt］

n. 水化合物

解　substance made from carbon dioxide and water by green plants in sunlight

例　Athletes usually eat meals packed with carbohydrates before a big event in order to get the energy they need. 在重大比赛开始之前，运动员通常吃一些富含碳水化合物的膳食来获得所需的能量。

同　carbonated adj. 碳化的



其他与“水”意义有关的词汇

drip n. 水滴

droplet n. 小水滴，小雨滴

puddle n. 水坑，水洼

aquatic adj. 水生的，水中的

awash adj. 与水面齐平的，被浪冲打的

waterproof adj. 防水的

cistern n. （抽水马桶的）贮水池

aqueduct n. 引水渠，渡槽

faucet n. 水龙头

floodgate n. 水门，水闸

flooding n. 泛滥，水灾

current n. 潮流；水流；气流

eddy n. 漩涡，涡流

rapids n. 急流，湍流

whirlpool n. 漩涡

dew n. 露珠

drain v. 排水

drainage n. 排水；污水

sewer n. 排水沟，下水道

wade v. 涉水

saliva n. 唾液，口水

sprinkler n. 洒水车；洒水装置

watershed n. 分水岭，分界

reconstitute v. 加水使还原





Group 92: hyper=excess; excessively “超过；太多”

hyperactivity［ˌhaɪpɜ:'æktɪvɪti］

n. 多动症

解　having behavior characterized by constant overactivity

例　The boy's hyperactivity was intensified when he ate sweets. 在吃糖果的时候，这个男孩的多动症症状更加明显。

hyperbole［haɪ'pɜ:bəli］

n. 夸张法

解　extravagant exaggeration

例　“I could eat a horse” is a hyperbole commonly used to express extreme hunger. “我可以吃下一匹马” 是一种夸张的说法，通常用来形容极度 饥饿。

同　hyperbolic adj. 夸张法的

构　hyper (=excessively) + bol (=to throw) + e

hypercritical［ˌhaɪpə'krɪtɪkəl］

adj. 苛求的，吹毛求疵的

解　finding too much to criticize; excessively exacting

例　The father was hypercritical of his eldest son in order to make him tough. 为了让孩子变得坚强，父亲对他的长子要求十分严苛。

近　hypocritical adj. 虚伪的，伪善的

构　hyper (=excessively) + cri (=to judge) + tical



Group 93: hypo =under; beneath; below “下面；次等”

hypocritical［ˌhɪpə'krɪtɪkəl］

adj. 虚伪的，伪善的

解　professing feelings or virtues one does not have

例　His hypocritical smile did not fool me; I knew he was trying to get my job. 他虚伪的笑容骗不了我；我知道他想得到我的工作。

hypocrite［'hɪpəkrɪt］

n. ① 伪善者 ② 伪君子

解　① person who pretends to be very good or religious ② person who is not sincere; pretender

例　The policeman who took bribes was not only a hypocrite but a criminal as well. 这名受贿的警察不仅是个伪君子，更是一名罪犯。

同　hypocrisy n. 伪善，造作

hypochondria［ˌhaɪpə'kɒndrɪə］

n. 忧郁症，疑病症

解　chronic and abnormal anxiety about imaginary symptoms and ailments

例　Hypochondria often involves experiences of real pain when illness is neither present nor likely. 疑病症患者通常会在没有生病也不可能生病的情况下感到疼痛。

hypothesis［haɪ'pɒθəsɪs］

n. 假设，假说

解　a concept that is not yet verified but that if true would explain certain facts or phenomena

例　A hypothesis can only become a scientific law after it has been replicated and proven consistent under different isolated conditions. 只有在不同的、独立的条件下被反复证明是一致的，假说才能成为科学定理。

同　hypothetically adv. 假设地

构　hypo (=under) + thesis (=placed)

Lesson 26





音频



Group 94: -ia “某种病”

dyslexia［dɪs'leksɪə］

n. 阅读障碍

解　impaired ability to read

例　The child suffered from dyslexia and needed a special tutor to learn how to read. 这个小孩患有阅读障碍，需要一个特殊的家庭教师来教他怎样阅读。

amnesia［æm'ni:zjə］

n. 健忘症，记忆缺失

解　loss of memory

例　The man who hit his head suffered from amnesia and could not even remember his name. 这个男人在头部被撞后就失忆了，甚至连自己的名字都想不起来了。





anemia［ə'ni:mɪə］

n. 贫血症

解　a deficiency of red blood cells

例　Since she suffered from anemia, she was restricted to a special diet to keep her blood oxygenated. 她患有贫血症，只能吃一些特定的食物来使血液氧化。

hemophilia［ˌhi:mə'fɪlɪə］

n. 血友病

解　congenital tendency to uncontrolled bleeding

例　After being diagnosed with hemophilia, he had to be careful not to get cut or he could bleed to death. 在被确诊为血友病之后，他必须小心翼翼地避免被割伤，否则他会流血不止而死亡。

近　hemorrhage n. 【医】出血

hysteria［hɪ'stɪərɪə］

n. 歇斯底里症；过度兴奋

解　uncontrollable fear or outburst of emotion

例　A false report of aliens landing on Earth caused mass hysteria. 外星人登陆地球的虚假报道引发了群众的恐慌。

insomnia［ɪn'sɔmnɪə］

n. 失眠症

解　an inability to sleep, chronic sleeplessness

例　She could not sleep for one week because of a bad case of insomnia. 由于严重失眠，她已经一个礼拜都睡不着觉了。

近　insignia n. 徽章；袖章

mania［'meɪnjə; -nɪə］

n. 狂热；躁狂

解　an irrational but irresistible motive for a belief or action; insanity

例　Strictly, mania is a kind of madness which makes people violent. 严格来说，躁狂是一种使人们变得暴力的疯狂行为。

同　maniac n. 【医】躁狂者，疯子

nostalgia［nɒs'tælʤɪə］

n. ① 思乡病 ② 怀旧之情

解　① homesickness ② longing for the past

例　Looking at her childhood pictures brought her a sense of nostalgia. 看着小时候的照片，她产生了一种怀旧之情。

同　nostalgic adj. 怀旧的，思乡的

paranoia［ˌpærə'nɒɪə］

n. 偏执狂，妄想狂；多疑症

解　a psychological disorder characterized by delusions of persecution or grandeur

例　He had a severe case of paranoia and always looked over his shoulder to see if anyone was following him. 他有重度妄想症，总是朝身后观望，看看是否有人跟踪自己。

同　paranoid adj. 过分怀疑的；偏执狂的



Group 95: -ics “学科”

ethics［'eθɪks］

n. 伦理学；道德规范

解　the discipline dealing with what is good and bad and with moral duty and obligation

例　The habitual liar had no sense of ethics. 这个习惯说谎的人已经丧失了道德感。

同　ethical adj. 道德的

构　eth (=custom) + ics

genetics［ʤɪ'netɪks］

n. 遗传学

解　the branch of biology that studies heredity and variation in organisms

例　The Human Genome Project is a world-scale research project among leading scientists to decipher the genetics of humans. 这个人类基因组项目是一个世界级的研究项目，汇集了一批顶尖的科学家来破译人类的基因密码。

同　genealogy n. 家谱，血统；族谱学；geneticist n. 遗传学家

linguistics［lɪŋ'ɡwɪstɪks］

n. 语言学

解　the study of language or languages

例　She had majored in linguistics in college in order to assist people with speech impediments. 为了帮助言语有障碍的人士，她在大学修了语言学专业。

metaphysics［ˌmetə'fɪzɪks］

n. 形而上学，玄学

解　branch of philosophy dealing with the nature of existence, truth, and know-ledge

例　Metaphysics is the branch of philosophy that examines the nature of reality, including the relationship between mind and matter, substance and attribute, fact and value. 形而上学是哲学的分支，主要研究现实的本质，包括意识和物质、物质和属性以及事实和价值之间的关系。

mnemonics［ni:'mɒnɪks］

n. 记忆法，记忆术

解　a system to develop or improve the memory

例　After his course in mnemonics, he could remember all the names of the people he met. 在学完记忆法的课程之后，他能记住所有见过面的人的名字。



Group 96: insul=island “岛屿”

insulate［'ɪnsjʊleɪt］

v. 使绝缘；使隔离

解　to cover or separate something with non-conducting materials; to isolate

例　The polar bear's fur insulates it from the arctic cold. 北极熊的皮毛能抵御极寒。

构　insul (=island) + ate (=to make)

insularity［ˌɪnsjʊ'lærəti; 'ɪnsə-］

n. 岛国性格，孤陋寡闻，心胸狭窄

解　narrow-mindedness; isolation

例　The insularity of the islanders manifested itself in their suspicion of anything foreign. 岛上居民的褊狭性表现在他们怀疑一切外来事物。

insulin［'ɪnsjʊlɪn; (US)'ɪnsəlɪn］

n. 胰岛素

解　a hormone secreted by the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas

例　Without his injection of insulin, the diabetic patient would die. 如果不注射胰岛素，这个糖尿病患者就会丧命。

peninsula［pɪ'nɪnsjʊlə; -sə-］

n. 半岛

解　a large mass of land projecting into a body of water

例　The peninsula offered people beaches. 半岛为人们提供了海滩。

近　penicillin n. 青霉素

音频



Group 97: integr=whole “完整”

integrate［'ɪntɪɡreɪt］

v. 使成整体

解　to make whole; to make into one unit

例　The revolutionary artist integrated eastern and western art. 这位具有革新精神的艺术家将东西方的艺术融合在了一起。

近　disinter v. 挖出，掘土

disintegrate［dɪs'ɪntɪɡreɪt］

v. 分裂成小片，瓦解

解　to break into parts or small bits

例　A nuclear war could disintegrate the world as we know it. 我们都知道，一场核战争会毁灭世界。

同　disintegration n. 分裂，瓦解





integral［'ɪntɪɡrəl］

adj. ① 完整的 ② 构成整体所必需的

解　① entire ② necessary to make something complete; essential

例　Steel is an integral part of a modern skyscraper. 钢铁是现代摩天大楼不可缺少的组成部分。

integrity［ɪn'teɡrɪti］

n. ① 完整 ② 正直，诚实

解　① wholeness; completeness ② honesty or sincerity; uprightness

例　A person of integrity is respected. 正直的人受人尊敬。



Group 98: inter=between “在…之间；相互”

interval［'ɪntəvəl］

n. 间隔，空隙

解　the time between two events

例　The runner practiced by sprinting and jogging in intervals. 这个跑步者通过快跑与慢跑相结合的方式来训练。

近　internal adj. 内部的

intermittent［ˌɪntə'mɪtənt］

adj. 断断续续的，间歇的

解　coming at intervals

例　You cannot hope to make good at this job by exerting intermittent efforts; you must do your best every day and every hour of the day. 如果你总是三天打鱼两天晒网，你就不可能做好这份工作。你必须每时每刻都付出自己最大的努力。

构　inter (=between) + mit (=to send) + tent

intermission［ɪntə'mɪʃən］

n. 暂停，间歇

解　a time interval during which there is a temporary cessation of something

例　There were two intermissions during the orchestra concert so the audience could rest and the musicians could reorganize. 管弦音乐会期间有两次幕间休息，这样观众可以休息一会儿，乐师也可以休整一下。

interrupt［ˌɪntə'rʌpt］

vt. 中断；打断，打扰

解　to break the continuity of; break in upon a person's action, speech, etc.

例　It is not polite to interrupt when someone is talking. 打断别人说话是不礼貌的。

同　interruption n. 打断

构　inter (=between) + rupt (=to break)

intercede［ˌɪntə'si:d］

v. 调解

解　to act to reconcile

例　The referee had to intercede in the fight between the two basketball players. 裁判不得不对两个篮球运动员之间的冲突进行调解。

同　intercessor n. 代为求情者，调解人

构　inter (=between) + ced (=to go) + e

interfere［ˌɪntə'fɪə(r)］

v. 干涉

解　to come between so as to be a hindrance or obstacle

例　It is not customary for people to interfere in the issues between husband and wife. 人们通常不会干涉夫妻之间的事情。

同　interference n. 干预

interim［'ɪntərɪm］

adj. 暂时的 n. 中间时期，过渡时期

解　for the meantime; temporary n. time between; the meantime

例　After the previous director suddenly passed away, an interim director was selected until the trustees could vote on the candidates for the position. 前任董事突然去世了，董事会选定了一个临时董事，在董事会成员对竞选董事职位的候选人作出表决之前来处理相关事务。

interject［ˌɪntə'ʤekt］

vt. 插嘴，突然插入

解　to insert between other elements

例　The newspaper reporter tried to interject a question while the spokesman was speaking. 发言人正在讲话的时候，一名记者试图插入一个问题。

同　interjection n. 感叹词；突然呼喊，感叹

interloper［'ɪntələʊpə(r)］

n. 闯入者；（为图私利）干涉他人事务者

解　intruder

例　The merchant thought of his competitors as interlopers who were stealing his trade. 这位商人把他的竞争对手看成是想抢他生意的侵入者。

interpolate［ɪn'tɜ:pəleɪt］

v. 插入（额外的事）；篡改

解　to insert words into texts or a conversation

例　She talked so much that I could not interpolate a single remark. 她说个不停，我一句话都插不进去。

同　interpolation n. 插入；篡改

intersperse［ˌɪntə'sp:s］

v. 点缀，散布

解　to place at intervals in or among

例　The grass was interspersed with beds of flowers. 草地被花坛点缀着。

Lesson 28





音频



Group 99: judg, judic=judge “判断”

judgment［'ʤʌʤmənt］

n. ① 判断 ② 判决

解　① result of judging; opinion or estimate ② act of judging, especially a decision, decree, or sentence given by a judge in a court of law

例　In my judgment dogs make better pets than cats. 我认为狗比猫更适合当宠物。

judicial［ʤu:'dɪʃəl］

adj. 法庭的；法官的

解　of or by judges; of courts or the administration of justice

例　The Supreme Court is the highest authority in the judicial system and has the power to overturn the decisions of lower courts. 最高法院是司法体系中最具权威性的机关，它有权推翻下级法院作出的裁决。

judicious［ʤu:'dɪʃəs］

adj. 聪明的，明智的；有判断力的

解　sensible; showing sound judgment

例　With 20 years of experience, the manager made calculated and judicious business decisions. 经理有20年的从业经验，能够作出准确而审慎的商业决策。

同　judiciousness n. 明智

adjudicate［əˌʤu:dɪ'keɪt］

v. 判决，宣判，裁定

解　to hear and settle (a case) by judicial procedure; to study and settle (a dispute or controversy)

例　The claims of the surviving victims of the crash will be adjudicated by an international commission. 坠机幸存者的索赔要求将由国际委员会裁决。

同　adjudicator n. 裁决者

构　ad (=to) + judic (=to judge) + ate

prejudice［'preʤʊdɪs］

n. 偏见 v. 损害

解　n. unreasonable attitude for or against something; bias　v. to affect injuriously or detrimentally by a judgment or an act

例　Companies in the United States are not allowed to hold any prejudices towards people of different races when recruiting employees. 美国公司在招聘员工的时候不允许有种族歧视。



Group 100: jur=swear; law “发誓；法律”

jury［'ʤʊəri］

n. 陪审团

解　a body of citizens sworn to give a true verdict according to the evidence presented in a court of law

例　After two days of debate, the jury passed their verdict to the judge. 经过两天的讨论，陪审团将裁决结果告诉了法官。

jurist［'ʤʊərɪst］

n. 法理学家

解　a legal scholar versed in civil law or the law of nations

例　The newspaper consulted a jurist in order to report on the implications resulting from the new law. 为了报导新法的含义，这家报纸咨询了一名法理学家。

perjury［'pɜ:ʤəri］

n. 伪证，假誓

解　false testimony while under oath

例　When several witnesses appeared to challenge his story, he was indicted for perjury. 当几位目击者出庭来质疑他的陈述的时候，他被控告作了伪证。

构　per (=falsely) + jur (=to swear) + y

同　perjure v. 作伪证，发假誓

abjure［æb'ʤʊə(r)］

v. 发誓放弃，誓绝

解　to renounce upon oath

例　Most aliens must abjure foreign citizenship before becoming an American citizen. 在成为美国公民之前，大多数外国人必须承诺放弃原来的公民身份。

构　ab (=away) + jur (=to swear) + e

conjure［'kʌnʤə(r)］

v. ① 变魔术，变戏法 ② 使某物浮现于脑际

解　① to influence or effect by or as if by magic ② to make sth. appear as a picture in the mind

例　Her grandfather taught her to conjure. 她的祖父教她变魔术。

构　con (=together) + jur (=to swear) + e



其他与“发誓；法律”意义有关的词汇

defendant n. 被告

recidivism n. 累犯，重犯

felon n. 重罪犯

arsonist n. 故意纵火犯

misdemeanor n. 【律】轻罪

reprieve n. 缓刑，暂缓 v. 缓期执行

impeach v. 指摘；弹劾

extradition n. 引渡逃犯

evict v. （依法）驱逐

amnesty n. 大赦，特赦

acquittal n. 宣告无罪，开释

verdict n. 判决，决定

convict v. 定罪；使确信 n. 罪犯

incriminate v. 归罪于，控告；牵连，连累

inculpate v. 归罪，控告

statute n. 法规，法令

statutory adj. 法定的；受法令所约束的

citation n. 传讯；传票

subpoena v. 传讯 n. 传票

summons n. 【律】传唤；传票

testimony n. 证言，证词；证明

affidavit n. 书面证词，宣誓书

depose v. 宣誓作证 n. 免职，废黜

indict v. 控告，起诉

prosecute v. 告发，检举

repeal v. 废除（法律）

abstention n. 弃权

bill n. 单据；议案

amendment n. 修正案；改正，修正

provision n. 供应；（法律等）条款

rider n. 附加条款

constitution n. 宪法

abet v. 教唆；协助（罪犯）

accomplice n. 同谋者，帮凶

lien n. 扣押权，留置权

precedence n. 优先权

foreclosure n. 取消抵押品赎取权

pledge n. 誓言；抵押品

extenuate v. 减轻罪过，掩饰（罪行）

tribunal n. 法庭，裁判所

bench n. 法官席；长椅

gavel n. （法官所用的）槌，小木槌

mace n. 权杖

counsel n. 律师 vt. 劝告，建议

infraction n. 违法

illicit adj. 违法的；违禁的





Group 101: labor=work “劳动，劳作”

labored［'leɪbəd］

adj. 吃力的，费力地说或做的

解　requiring or showing effort

例　The labored breathing of this very ill person means he has a short time to live. 这位重病患者呼吸都很费力，意味着他所剩时日不多了。

laborer［'leɪbərə(r)］

n. 劳动者（尤指体力劳动者），工人

解　person who does work that requires strength rather than skill or training; workers as a group

例　A laborer for most of his life, my father liked to work with his hands. 我父亲当了大半辈子工人，他喜欢用自己的双手来劳动。

laboratory［lə'bɒrətəri; (US)'læbrətɔ:ri］

n. 实验室

解　a room or building equipped for scientific experimentation or research; a place where drugs and chemicals are manufactured

例　The patient's blood was analyzed in the laboratory. 医生在实验室里分析了病人的血液。

laborious［lə'bɔ:rɪəs］

adj. ① （指工作）艰苦的，费力的 ② （指人）勤劳的

解　① requiring great effort ② showing signs of effort, not fluent or easy

例　Moving a piano can be a laborious task. 移动钢琴是一件费力的事。

belabor［bɪ'leɪbə(r)］

v. ① （过分冗长地）做或说 ② 痛打

解　① to set upon with too much talk, advice, etc. ② to beat vigorously; thrash

例　The rider belabored the tired horse with a stick. 骑手用棍子痛打那匹疲惫的马。

collaborate［kə'læbəreɪt］

vi. ① 合作 ② 通敌

解　① to work together on a common enterprise or project ② to work treasonably especially with enemy forces occupying one's country

例　The world's scientific community collaborated in the immense task of deciphering the genetic makeup of human DNA. 国际科学界通力合作，一起参与到破译人类基因密码这项庞大的工程中来。

同　collaboration n. 合作；collaborator n. 合作者

构　col < con (=with) + labor (=to work) + ate

elaborate［ɪ'læbərət］adj. 复杂的，精致的［ɪ'læbəreɪt］v. 详尽地说明，阐明；精工细做

解　adj. developed or executed with care and in minute v. to talk or write in great detail; work out with great care

例　The president's spokesperson was asked to elaborate on his answer after he had given a short answer to a controversial question. 在针对一个有争议的问题作出简单的回答之后，总统的发言人被要求作出详细说明。

Lesson 29

Group 102: land=land “陆地，土地”

landlord［'lændlɔ:d］

n. 地主，房主

解　person who owns buildings or land for rent to others

例　The responsible landlord made repairs whenever something broke. 不管是什么东西坏了，这位负责任的房东都会修好。

landmark［'lændmɑ:k］

n. 里程碑

解　an event marking a unique or important historical change or one on which important developments depend

例　The inventions of the printing press, telephone, telegraph, radio, and televi-sion are landmarks in the history of communication. 印刷机、电话、电报、无线电以及电视的发明都是通信史上的里程碑。

landscape［'lændskeɪp］

n. 风景，地形

解　an expanse of scenery that can be seen in a single view

例　The two hills with the valley form a beautiful landscape. 这两座山和中间的峡谷构成了一幅美丽的风景。





landslide［'lændslaɪd］

n. ① 山崩 ② 压倒性的胜利

解　① a sliding down of a mass of earth or rock on a steep slope ② an overwhelming majority of votes for one candidate or political party in an election

例　The favored politician won the election by a landslide. 这位受欢迎的政客以绝对优势赢得了选举。

近　strand n. 股 v. 搁浅

island［'aɪlənd］

n. 岛屿

解　a land mass (smaller than a continent) that is surrounded by water

例　The islands in the sea were a product of the coolling lava from a volcanic eruption. 海上的小岛是由火山喷发出来的岩浆冷却形成的。

wasteland［'weɪstlənd］

n. 荒地

解　an uninhabited wilderness that is worthless for cultivation

例　The desert wasteland was uninhabitable for humans. 这片被遗弃的荒地不适合人类居住。



Group 103: lax, lys=loosen “放松”

lax［læks］

adj. 懒散的；松弛的，不严格的

解　careless; not strict or tense

例　The lax teacher wore casual clothes and called his students by their first names. 这位散漫的老师穿衣服很随意，连上课点名也只叫学生的姓。

laxative［'læksətɪv］

n. 轻泄药 adj. 通便的，放松的

解　n. something causing the bowels to empty easily adj. causing looseness or relaxation, especially of the bowels

例　The doctor recommended he take laxatives for his constipation. 医生建议他服用泻药来治疗便秘。

relax［rɪ'læks］

v. 放松

解　to become less tense

例　The students went to the swimming pool to relax at the weekend. 在周末，学生们去游泳来放松身心。

同　relaxed adj. 放松的

paralysis［pə'ræləsɪs］

n. ① 中风，瘫痪症 ② 瘫痪，停滞不能移动或运行

解　① loss of the power of contractility in the voluntary or involuntary muscles ② condition of powerlessness or helpless inactivity; crippling

例　The war caused a paralysis of trade. 战争导致贸易瘫痪。



Group 104: lect=choose; gather “选择；收集”

collection［kə'lekʃən］

n. 文集；收集

解　a number of similar objects grouped or found together

例　She kept a postcard collection of all the cities to which she had traveled. 她将她去过的所有城市的明信片都收集了起来。

collective［kə'lektɪv］

adj. 共同的，集体的

解　denoting or shared by a group

例　The team did not have any individual talents, but it was their collective effort that was their true strength. 这个团队中没有任何人是天才；大家的共同努力才是他们真正的力量所在。

election［ɪ'lekʃən］

n. 选举

解　a choosing or selecting for an office by vote

例　In our city we have an election for mayor every four years. 我们的城市每隔四年选举一次市长。

elective［ɪ'lektɪv］

adj. 随意选择的

解　open to choice; not required

例　The university curriculum mandates a number of requisite courses, but allows students to pick a few elective courses. 大学的课程指定了许多必修课，但是也允许学生选择几门选修课。

eclectic［ɪ'klektɪk］

adj. 折中的，综合性的

解　selecting what seems best of various styles or ideas

例　His style of interior decoration was eclectic: bits and pieces of furnishings from widely divergent periods, strikingly juxtaposed to create a unique decor. 他的室内装修风格不拘一格，属于多个不同时期的各式家具醒目地摆放在一起，形成了一种独特的风格。

同　eclecticism n. 折中主义

构　ec < ex (=out) + lect (=to choose) + ic

selective［sɪ'lektɪv］

adj. 选择的，选择性的

解　selecting; having the power to select

例　The university is highly selective of applicants and values a well-rounded profile. 这所大学对入学申请者的挑选非常严格，并且看重个人经历的丰富性。

同　selectivity n. 挑拣

Lesson 30





音频



Group 105: lect=speak; read “讲；读”

lectern［'lektən］

n. 讲经台

解　reading desk

例　Every Sunday morning, the priest stood behind the lectern and read scriptures from the Bible. 每个星期天早上，牧师都会站在诵经台后面，朗读圣经里的经文。

lecture［'lektʃə(r)］

n. ① 讲座，演讲 ② 谴责，教训

解　① a planned talk on a chosen subject; speech ② a scolding

例　The professor spoke so fast during his lectures that there wasn't any time to ask questions. 教授上课时讲得很快，学生都没有时间提问。

同　lecturer n. 教师；演讲人

dialect［'daɪəlekt］

n. 方言

解　variety of a spoken language peculiar to a particular district

例　Although Mandarin is the national language of China, there are many dialects. 虽然普通话是中国的官方语言，但是各地也有很多方言。



Group 106: leg=law “法律”

legislation［leʤɪs'leɪʃən］

n. 立法；法律

解　the act or process of legislating; lawmaking; a proposed or enacted law or group of laws

例　The president's power to veto is a control over the legislation passed by Congress. 总统的否决权是对国会通过立法的一种控制。

同　legislative adj. 立法的；legislator n. 立法者

legislature［'leʤɪsleɪtʃə(r)］

n. 立法机关

解　an officially elected or otherwise selected body of people who make or amend, repeal laws

例　The legislature was composed of a group of jurists. 立法机关由多位法学家组成。

legitimacy［lɪ'ʤɪtɪməsi］

n. 合法（性）；正统（性）

解　lawfulness by virtue of being authorized or in accordance with law

例　Politics was much simpler in the past, when the king did not need to prove his legitimacy to anyone. 在过去，政治要比现在简单得多，国王不需要向任何人证明自己所作所为的合法性。

同　legitimated adj. 合法化的



Group 107: lev=lift “抬升”

elevate［'elɪveɪt］

v. 提高，抬升

解　to raise from a lower to a higher position

例　Bruce sprained his ankle, so he had to elevate his leg and put ice on it. 布鲁斯扭伤了脚踝，因此他不得不将腿抬起来，并且在脚踝处敷上冰块。

elevation［elɪ'veɪʃən］

n. 海拔

解　height above sea level

例　The high elevation of the mountain made it difficult to breathe. 山的海拔很高，让人觉得呼吸困难。

elevator［'elɪveɪtə(r)］

n. 电梯

解　a moving platform or cage to carry people and things up and down in a building, mine, etc.

例　Some people have the inefficient habit of trying to get into an elevator before the people inside leave. 有些人在乘坐电梯时有种不良的习惯，总是在里面的人还没出来时就抢着要进去。

levee［'levi; lə'vi:］

n. 防洪堤；堤岸

解　a barrier constructed to contain the flow of water or to keep out the sea

例　The city built a levee so the river would not flood the street when it rained.这个城市建了防洪堤，这样下雨的时候河水就不会漫上街道了。



Group 108: lin, lign=line “直线”

outline［'aʊtlaɪn］

n. 大纲，轮廓 v. 画轮廓，打草图

解　n. a summary of the main points of an argument or theory v. to draw the outer line of

例　The English teacher told the students that they should write an outline before they wrote an essay in order to organize their thoughts and ideas clearly. 这位英语老师告诉学生，在写文章之前要先拟一个提纲，这样就能更清晰地组织思路和想法。

pipeline［'paɪplaɪn］

n. 管道

解　line of pipes for carrying oil or other liquids, usually over a considerable distance

例　The earthquake broke the city's main gas pipeline, releasing natural gas into the air. 地震破坏了这座城市的主要天然气管道，将天然气泄漏到了空气中去。

同　pipe n. 管道

byline［'baɪlaɪn］

n. 文章作者署名行（即报刊等的文章开头或结尾列出作者名字的一行）

解　a line giving the name of the writer of a story or article

例　The name of the reporter in the newspaper article's byline was misspelled. 这篇报纸文章署名行里的记者姓名被拼错了。

delineate［dɪ'lɪnɪeɪt］

v. 描绘，描画

解　to represent by sketch or diagram; to describe

例　I can't provide all the details at this time, but I will try to delineate the main features of my plan for reorganizing the student government. 这次我无法提供所有的细节，但是我会试着描述关于我的学生会改组计划的主要特点。

构　de (=down) + line + ate

streamline［'stri:mlaɪn］

vt. ① 使成流线型 ② 改善…的表面或效率；使现代化

解　① to construct or design in a form that offers the least resistance to fluid flow ② to improve the appearance or efficiency of; to modernize

例　Through evolution, fish were streamlined in order to swim faster, to catch prey and avoid predators. 通过进化，鱼类的身体变成了流线型，这样可以游得更快，从而可以捕捉到猎物并躲避猎食者。

同　stream n. 溪流，水流，河流

align［ə'laɪn］

v. ① 使排成一线 ② 使结盟

解　① to bring into line ② to bring into agreement, close cooperation, etc.

例　I aligned the sights of my gun with the target. 我把枪的瞄准器和目标对准成一条直线。

构　a (=to) + lign (=line)

Lesson 31





音频



Group 109: liter=letter “文字；字母”

literal［'lɪtərəl］

adj. 逐字的，照字面的，忠实原义的

解　being or reflecting the essential or genuine character of something

例　The literal meaning of words in dictionaries cannot fully express their cultural and historical significance. 词典中所给出的单词的字面意思无法完全表达出其文化和历史意义。

literary［'lɪtərəri］

adj. 文学的

解　of, relating to, or dealing with literature

例　The literary scholar published many books that analyzed Shakespeare. 这位文学学者出版了许多研究莎士比亚的书籍。

literati［ˌlɪtə'rɑ:ti:］

n. 文人，文学界

解　the literary intelligentsia

例　All the students wanted to enroll in the poetry course by the professor who represented the literati. 这个诗歌课程由足以代表整个文学界的教授所讲，所有的学生都想报名参加。

alliteration［əˌlɪtə'reɪʃən］

n. 头韵（法）（即在一组词或诗中，第一个字母或发音的重复）

解　repetition of beginning sound in poetry

例　“The furrow followed free” is an example of alliteration. “船行过留下四散的水纹”是头韵的例子。

illiterate［ɪ'lɪtərɪt］

adj. 文盲的

解　not able to read or write

例　People who have never gone to school are usually illiterate. 没有上过学的人通常都是文盲。

同　illiteracy n. 文盲





obliterate［ə'blɪtəreɪt］

vt. ① 涂去，删除 ② 彻底毁坏，毁灭

解　① to rub, or blot out; to remove all signs of ② to destroy completely

例　The bomb obliterated the small town. 炸弹摧毁了这个小镇。

构　ob (=against) + liter (=letter) + ate



Group 110: log=speech “说话”

log［lɒɡ］

n. ① 日志，记录 ② 圆木

解　① a written record of events on a voyage (of a ship or plane) ② a segment of the trunk of a tree when stripped of branches

例　Enter the new information in the log. 在日志里填入新的信息。

logic［'lɒʤɪk］

n. ① 逻辑学 ② 逻辑

解　① the branch of philosophy that analyzes inference ② reasoned and reasonable judgment

例　His argument had no logic and he was quickly proven wrong. 他的论据没有逻辑，很快就被证明是错误的。

logical［'lɒʤɪkəl］

adj. （指行为、事情等）合乎情理的，合乎常理的

解　in accordance with the rules of logic; able to reason correctly

例　There are times in life when you should be guided more by your feelings, without trying to be strictly logical about everything. 人生有的时候更需要跟着自己的感觉走，而不用事事都合乎常理。

同　illogically adv. 不合逻辑地

构　log (=speech) + ical

logistics［lə'ʤɪstɪks］

n. 物流学，后勤学

解　handling an operation that involves providing labor and materials supplied as needed

例　He was in charge of the logistics of the company's import and export operations, including shipment amounts, routes and schedules. 他负责公司进出口业务的物流，包括装运量、线路以及时间表。

catalog［'kætəlɒɡ］

n. 目录，产品目录

解　a complete list of things; usually arranged systematically

例　He received a store's spring fashion catalog in the mail and ordered some shirts and shorts. 他收到了一家商店寄来的春装产品目录，然后定购了几件衬衫和短裤。

apology［ə'pɒləʤi］

n. ① 为信仰等辩护 ② 道歉

解　① explanation or defense ② statement of regret

例　He expressed his apology to his girlfriend in a love letter. 他在情书里向女朋友表达了歉意。

同　apologist n. 辩护者

构　apo (=off) + log (=speech) + y

apologize［ə'pɒləʤaɪz］

v. 道歉

解　to acknowledge faults

例　The waitress apologized for spilling coffee on the man's lap. 女服务员因把咖啡洒到了一位男士的腿上而向他道了歉。

epilogue［'epɪlɒɡ］

n. 尾声；收场白；后记

解　last part of a literary work; short speech at the conclusion of a dramatic work

例　The epilogue of the story shed light on the future fate of the characters. 故事的结尾阐明了各个人物未来的命运。

analogous［ə'næləɡəs］

adj. 类似的

解　similar or correspondent in some respects though otherwise dissimilar

例　Many scientists wonder if there is any life that is analogous to our own living on distant planets. 许多科学家想知道在遥远的其他星球上是否有着和我们人类一样的生命体存在。

同　analogue n. 类比

构　ana (=upon) + log (=speech) + ous

dialogue［'daɪəlɔɡ; (US)'daɪəlɔ:ɡ］

n. 对话

解　a conversation between two persons

例　That book has a good plot and a lot of clever dialogues. 那本书情节很不错，而且有许多睿智的对话。

Lesson 32





音频



Group 111: logy=science “学科”

anthology［æn'θɒləʤi］

n. 诗集，文选；选集

解　a collection of selected literary passages

例　She used an anthology of bedtime short stories to read her children to sleep. 她通过读一本睡前短篇故事集来哄孩子们睡觉。

同　antho (=flower; collection) + logy

astrology［ə'strɒləʤi］

n. 占星学，占星术

解　a pseudoscience claiming divination by the positions of the planets, sun, moon and stars

例　The daily horoscope in the newspaper was based on astrology. 报纸上的“每日星座运势”是基于占星术而作出推测的。

biology［baɪ'ɒləʤi］

n. 生物学

解　the scientific study of plant and animal life, including its origin, structure, activities, and distribution.

例　Botany, zoology, and ecology are branches of biology. 植物学、动物学和生态学都是生物学的分支。

dermatology［ˌdɜ:mə'tɒləʤi］

n. 皮肤病学

解　the branch of medicine dealing with the skin and its diseases

例　He was concerned about his skin rash and visited a specialist in dermatology. 他担心自己的皮疹，于是拜访了一位皮肤病方面的专家。

epistemology［eˌpɪstɪ'mɒləʤi］

n. 认识论，知识起源学（对知识本质的研究）

解　the philosophical theory of knowledge

例　Epistemology had a serious impact on the direction of modern philosophy in the 20th century. 在二十世纪，认识论对现代哲学的走向产生了重大影响。

genealogy［ˌʤi:nɪ'æləʤi］

n. 家谱；族谱学

解　successive generations of kin

例　The family owned a book that recorded the genealogy of their ancestry. 这个家庭有一本记载祖先家谱的小册子。

meteorology［ˌmi:tjə'rɒləʤi］

n. 气象学

解　science dealing with phenomena of the atmosphere, especially weather processes and weather forecasting

例　The weatherman based his daily forecasts on calculated meteorology rather than lucky guesses. 气象员依靠经过测算的气象数据进行每日预报，而不是依靠侥幸猜测。

mythology［mɪ'θɒləʤi］

n. 神话学；神话

解　the study of myths

例　The mythology of many ancient societies saw the sun as a deity. 在很多古代社会的神话故事中，太阳都被看做神。

neurology［njʊə'rɒləʤi］

n. 神经病学

解　the branch of medical science that deals with the nervous system and its disorders

例　She visited several experts in neurology to get a comparative diagnosis of her nervous system disorder. 为了对自己的神经系统紊乱进行比较诊断，她拜访了好几位神经学专家。

phenomenology［fɪˌnɒmɪ'nɒləʤi］

n. 现象学

解　the study of the development of human consciousness and self-awareness as a preface to philosophy or a part of philosophy

例　Genetic science is very closely related to phenomenology. 遗传学与现象学之间有着紧密的联系。

zoology［zəu'ɒləʤi］

n. 动物学

解　the science of animals

例　The diversity of species in the rainforest provides a wealth of knowledge for zoology. 热带雨林的物种多样性为动物学的研究提供了大量的知识。

同　zoologist n. 动物学家



Group 112: loqu=speak “演说”

loquacious［lɒ'kweɪʃəs］

adj. 多嘴的，爱说话的

解　full of trivial conversation

例　The loquacious student was known as the school bigmouth. 这个多嘴多舌的学生是学校有名的大嘴巴。

同　loquaciousness n. 唠叨，喋喋不休；loquacity n. 唠叨，喋喋不休

colloquial［kə'ləʊkwɪəl］

adj. 口语的

解　characteristic of informal spoken language or conversation

例　The colloquial language in his essay made it seem as if he was speaking to you directly. 他文章里的口语化语言让你感觉他似乎在直接跟你说话。

同　colloquialism n. 口语，俗语

eloquent［'eləkwənt］

n. ① 雄辩的，有口才的 ② 动人的

解　① having the ability to express emotion or feeling in lofty and impassioned speech ② very expressive

例　The graduation speaker was very eloquent in his speech. 这位演讲者在毕业典礼上的演说十分精彩。

同　eloquence n. 雄辩；口才

grandiloquent［ɡræn'dɪləkwənt］

adj. 夸张的，浮夸的

解　speaking in or characterized by a pompous style

例　The politician could never speak simply; she was always grandiloquent. 这位政治家从来不会简单地说话，她总是言辞夸张。

同　grandiloquence n. 夸大之辞

soliloquy［sə'lɪləkwi］

n. 独白；自言自语

解　talking to oneself

例　The soliloquy is a device employed by the dramatist to reveal a character's innermost thoughts and emotions. 独白是剧作家用来揭示人物的内心想法和情感的一种表现手法。





其他与“演讲，演说”意义有关的词汇

address n. 演说

discourse n. 演讲，论述

lecture n. 讲座，演讲

extemporize v. 即兴演说

harangue n. 长篇演说

diatribe n. 长篇攻击性演讲，（口头或书面猛烈的）抨击

peroration n. 演讲结尾部分，结论

valediction n. 告别演说，告别词

podium n. 讲坛；指挥台





Group 113: luc=light “光；照亮；明亮的”

lucid［'lu:sɪd］

adj. ① 清澈的，透明的 ② 易懂的

解　① transparently clear ② easily understandable

例　A good explanation is lucid. 好的解释是清晰易懂的。

同　lucidity n. 清晰

pellucid［pə'lu:sɪd］

adj. ① 清晰的，清澈的 ② 易懂的

解　① transparent; clear; clearly expressed ② easy to understand

例　The lawyer wrote a pellucid letter to avoid any misunderstanding and to express her forthrightness. 律师写了一封意思清楚的信件来避免任何的误解，同时坦率地表达了自己的看法。

elucidate［ɪ'lu:sɪdeɪt］

v. 阐明，说明

解　to make clear; to explain

例　Since there were many questions in class, the professor elucidated on the topic. 由于同学们对这一话题有很多问题，教授对它进行了阐明。

构　e < ex (=out) + lucid (=bright) + ate

translucent［trænz'lu:snt］

adj. 半透明的

解　letting light through without being transparent

例　Silk screens are an example of translucent objects. 丝网是一种透明的物体。

同　translucence n. 半透明

构　trans (=through) + luc (=light) + ent
