Lesson 33





音频



Group 114: lud, lus=play “扮演”引申为“使浮现某种想法”

allude［ə'lu:d］

v. 间接提到，暗指

解　to refer indirectly; to imply

例　Don't tell them of our decision; don't even allude to it. 不要把我们的决定告诉他们，连间接提到也不行。

同　allusiveness n. 暗指

构　al (=to) + lud (=to play) + e

collude［kə'lu:d］

v. 串通，共谋

解　to act together secretly; to conspire in a fraud

例　The two thieves colluded in a plan to steal millions of dollars from the businessman. 两个盗贼合谋从这个商人家偷走了数百万美金。

同　collusion n. 串通共谋，勾结

delude［dɪ'lu:d］

v. 欺骗，哄骗

解　to mislead or deceive

例　Harry Houdini was a famous magician that made an art out of deluding people's perception. 哈里·胡迪尼是一位著名的魔术师，他创造了一种欺骗人们感知的艺术。

同　delusion n. 欺骗；幻觉，幻想；delusive adj. 使迷惑的，令人误解的

构　de (=from) + lud (=to play) + e

elude［ɪ'lu:d］

v. （机敏地）躲避，避开；记不起来

解　to escape, either physically or mentally

例　The student knew the response to the question but it somehow eluded his tongue at the most critical moment. 这名学生知道这个问题的答案，但是不知何故在关键时候却怎么也想不起来。

构　e < ex (=out) + lud (=to play) + e

elusive［ɪ'lu:sɪv］

adj. 难懂的，难捉摸的

解　difficult to detect or grasp by the mind

例　The elusive fox got away. 狡猾的狐狸逃走了。

构　e < ex ( =out) + lus (=to play) + ive

prelude［'prelju:d］

n. 序幕，前奏

解　introductory performance, event, or musical piece

例　There was a prelude before the main event in order to build a sense of drama for the audience. 在主要事件开始之前有一个前奏，这是为了为观众创造一种戏剧感。

occlude［ɒ'klu:d］

v. 使闭塞，封闭；排除出去

解　to close up to block passage through

例　The blockade occluded the passage of unauthorized boats into the gulf during the war. 该海域在战争期间实行了封锁，禁止未经许可的船只进入海湾。

illusion［ɪ'lu:ʒən］

n. 幻觉，错觉

解　an erroneous mental representation; delusion

例　Magic is a form of entertainment that is based on illusion. 魔术是一种基于错觉的娱乐形式。

同　disillusioned adj. 幻想破灭的；illusive adj. 幻觉的；illusory adj. 虚幻的，幻觉的

构　il < in (=in) + lus (=to play) + ion

illusionist［ɪ'lu:ʒənɪst］

n. 魔术师

解　someone who performs magic tricks to amuse an audience

例　We had an illusionist do tricks at the party. 在聚会上，我们请了一位魔术师表演魔术。

ludicrous［'lu:dɪkrəs］

adj. 可笑的，滑稽的

解　amusingly absurd; ridiculous

例　He wore a ludicrous revolving hat with various attachments on it. 他戴了一顶滑稽的帽子，帽子可以旋转，上面还有许多装饰。



Group 115: mal=bad “坏，恶”

maladroit［ˌmælə'drɔɪt］

adj. 笨拙的

解　lacking adroitness; unskillful

例　In his usual maladroit way, he managed to upset the cart and spilled the food. 他想方设法把马车推翻，把食物倒了出来，用的方法还是像往常那样笨拙。

构　mal (=bad) + a (=to) + droit < direct (=straight, right)

近　adroit adj. 熟练的，灵巧的；adroitness n. 灵巧





malaise［mə'leɪz］

n. 小恙

解　sense of being unwell; sickness

例　Since the businessman could not afford to get sick, he took medicine as a preventive measure whenever he felt a slight malaise. 这位商人承担不起生病可能带来的损失，所以只要感觉稍有不舒服，他就马上服药，以此作为一种预防的手段。

malapropism［'mæləprɒpɪzəm］

n. 词语的误用

解　the unintentional misuse of a word by confusion with one that sounds similar

例　When Mrs. Malaprop criticized Lydia for being “as headstrong as an allegory on the banks of the Nile,” she confused “allegory” and “alligator” in a typical malapropism. 马勒普夫人批评莉迪娅“和尼罗河岸边的寓言一样顽固”时，她是把“寓言”和“短吻鳄”这两个词弄混了，这是一种典型的词语误用。

malevolent［mə'levələnt］

adj. 有恶意的，恶毒的

解　wishing evil to others; malicious

例　The malevolent witch put a curse on the prince and turned him into a frog. 恶毒的女巫给王子下了咒语，把他变成了青蛙。

构　male < mal (=bad) + vol (=will) + ent

malicious［mə'lɪʃəs］

adj. 恶意的，恶毒的

解　showing ill will; wishing to hurt or make suffer; spiteful

例　The girls at school spread malicious gossip about her because they were jealous of her. 学校里的女生因为嫉妒她，到处散布关于她的恶意谣言。

malign［mə'laɪn］

v. 诽谤，中伤 adj. 邪恶的

解　v. to speak evil of; slander adj. evil

例　You malign an honest person when you call that person a liar. 当你说一个诚实的人说了谎的时候，你是在对他进行毁谤。

构　mali < mal (=bad) + gn < gen (=birth)



其他与“坏，恶”意义有关的词汇

baleful adj. 邪恶的，恶意的

iniquity n. 邪恶，不公正

spite n. 怨恨，恶意

turpitude n. 邪恶，卑鄙 （行为）

vicious adj. 邪恶的；残酷的；危险的

enormity n. 极恶，暴行；巨大

misdeed n. 恶行

Group 116: man, manu=hand “手”

manual［'mænjʊəl］

n. 手册，说明书 adj. 手的，手动的，手工的

解　n. handbook, instruction book adj. physical

例　The computer came with an operator's manual. 电脑附带一本操作手册。

manumit［ˌmænjʊ'mɪt］

v. 解放（奴隶）

解　to free from slavery or servitude

例　Lincoln was in support of manumitting slaves. 林肯支持解放奴隶。

近　mammal n. 哺乳动物；maul v. 撕裂皮肉，伤害；menu n. 菜单；mansion n. 豪宅，公馆；大厦

manufacture［ˌmænjʊ'fæktʃə(r)］

v. 制造

解　to put together out of components or parts; to produce

例　Because of the low cost of labor, the country manufactured many goods and exported them abroad. 这个国家的劳动力成本低，因此大量制造产品并出口到国外。

emancipate［ɪ'mænsɪpeɪt］

vt. 释放，解除

解　to set free from slavery or restraint; to release

例　American slaves were emancipated during the Civil War. 美国奴隶在内战期间得到解放。

构　e < ex (=out) + man < manu (=hand) + cip < cap (=to take) + ate





manipulate［mə'nɪpjʊleɪt］

v. 熟练地控制；操纵

解　to handle or treat, especially with skill; manage by clever use of personal influence, especially unfair influence

例　He is a clever man who knows how to manipulate public opinion. 他是一个深谙如何操纵舆论的聪明人。

同　manipulation n. 操纵；manipulative adj. 操纵别人的，老于世故的；manipulator n. 操纵者

构　man (=hand) + i + pul (=to drive) + ate



Group 117: mand=order “命令”

mandate［'mændeɪt］

n. （书面）要求；命令，训令

解　an authoritative command or instruction

例　The governor received a mandate from the voters to curb spending. 州长收到了选民关于控制开支的书面请求。

mandatory［'mændətəri］

adj. 命令的，强制的

解　of or containing a command; commanded; required

例　The professor made it clear that the class was not optional; it was mandatory if the students had any intention of passing. 教授清楚地告诉学生这门课不是选修课；如果学生们想及格的话，就必须修这门课。

command［kə'mɑ:nd］

n./v. 命令

解　n. order v. to give an order to; to direct

例　While Jess was under the hypnotist's spell, she obeyed his every command. 杰丝中了催眠术士的符咒，完全听从于他的命令。

近　commend v. 称赞，颂扬；commendable adj. 值得称赞的；recommend v. 推荐，建议；commence v. 开始；倡导

构　com < con (=intensive) + mand (=to order)

countermand［ˌkaʊntə'mɑ:nd］

v. 取消订货；撤回（命令）

解　to withdraw or cancel (an order or command)

例　Since Greg was late for work, he countermanded his order for a steak and ate a sandwich instead. 由于上班迟到了，格雷格取消了牛排的订单，改吃三明治了。

构　counter (=against) + mand (=to order)

demanding［dɪ'mɑ:ndɪŋ; (US)dɪ'mændɪŋ］

adj. 要求高的，苛刻的

解　requiring more than usually expected or thought due

例　The students were relieved when the demanding course ended. 当这个要求颇高的课程结束后，学生们如释重负。

同　demand n./v. 要求，命令

reprimand［'reprɪmɑ:nd］

n./v. 训诫，谴责

解　n. a severe of formal reproof v. to reprove severely or formally

例　The general reprimanded the soldier for disobeying orders. 将军因这个士兵没有服从命令而训斥了他。



Group 118: mark=sign “记号，符号”

hallmark［'hɔ:lmɑ:k］

n. ① 纯度标记 ② 明显特征

解　① an official mark indicating standard of purity, put on gold or silver articles ② a distinctive characteristic or attribute

例　The five stars next to the hotel's name in the directory was a hallmark of excellence. 在商行名录里，酒店名称旁的五颗星是高品质的象征。

landmark［'lændmɑ:k］

n. 里程碑；地标

解　an event marking a unique or important historical change or one on which important developments depend; a historical site

例　The inventions of the printing press, telephone, telegraph, radio, and television are landmarks in the history of communication. 印刷机、电话、电报、无线电以及电视机的发明是人类通讯史上的里程碑。

trademark［'treɪdmɑ:k］

n. 商标

解　a distinguishing characteristic of feature firmly associated with a person or thing

例　A registered trademark is legally protected and may be used only by the owner. 注册商标受法律保护，只有权利人才能使用。

remarkable［rɪ'mɑ:kəbəl］

adj. 非凡的

解　worthy of notice; noteworthy

例　The professor provided a recommendation of the remarkable student. 教授为这名出类拔萃的学生写了封推荐信。

同　unremarkable adj. 不显著的，平凡的



其他与“符号”有关的词汇

punctuation n. 标点符号

accolade n. 嘉奖，赞许；连谱号

apostrophe n. 撇号（'）

asterisk n. 星号

bracket n. 括号

caret n. 加字符（文章中插字使用）

colon n. 冒号

hyphen n. 连字符，即“-”

parentheses n. 圆括号［parenthesis的复数］

period n. 句号；时期

Lesson 35





音频



Group 119: max, magn=great “大的”

climax［'klaɪmæks］

n. 高潮

解　the highest point of anything; summit

例　The novel was so provocative that she could not set it down until she reached the climax. 这部小说写得太吸引人了，她直到看到高潮部分才放下书。

anticlimax［ˌæntɪ'klaɪmæks］

n. 高潮突降

解　a sudden change from an important state to a trivial state

例　The athlete's paralysis was an anticlimax to his promising career. 这位运动员的瘫痪使他正辉煌的事业突然走向了低谷。

maximal［'mæksɪməl］

adj. 最大的

解　of, relating to, or consisting of a maximum; being the greatest or highest possible

例　The coach required his players to exert their maximal effort during the game otherwise they would be substituted. 教练要求运动员在比赛时全力以赴，否则他们就会被替换下来。

magnate［'mæɡneɪt］

n. 财主，巨头

解　an important, powerful, or prominent person

例　The cattle magnate had opened many steakhouses around the country as a secondary business. 这位养牛业的巨头在国内开了许多牛排餐厅作为副业。

近　magnet n. 磁铁；magnetic adj. 有磁性的；吸引人的；magnetism n. 磁力，磁性；吸引力





magnanimous［mæɡ'nænɪməs］

adj. ① 宽宏大量的 ② 慷慨的

解　① generous in forgiving ② free from mean or petty feelings or acts

例　She has a magnanimous attitude toward her children when they misbehave. 当孩子们犯错误时，她对他们总是很宽容。

同　magnanimity n. 宽宏大量；慷慨

构　magn (=great) + anim (=mind) + ous

magnify［'mæɡnɪfaɪ］

v. 放大；夸大

解　to increase in size, volume or significance; to enlarge beyond bounds or the truth

例　A microscope magnifies bacteria so that they can be seen and studied. 显微镜能放大细菌，使它们能被看到和研究。

同　magnification n. 放大，扩大；夸大



其他与“大的”意义有关的词汇

elephantine adj. 巨大的，笨拙的

gargantuan adj. 巨大的，庞大的

monolithic adj. 巨石的，巨大的

prodigious adj. 惊人的；巨大的

tremendous adj. 惊人的；巨大的

boulder n. 巨石；大鹅卵石

colossus n. 巨型雕像；巨人





Group 120: memo, mnemo=remind; remember “记忆；记得”

memorial［mə'mɔ:rɪəl］

n. 纪念物；纪念碑 adj. 纪念性的

解　n. a structure erected to commemorate persons or events adj. helping people to remember some person, thing, or event

例　The memorial service was naturally a sad occasion, but the people tried to remember the good times they had with their deceased friend. 追悼会本该是一个悲伤的场合，但是人们总是努力回忆和已故的朋友在一起的开心时刻。

immemorial［ˌɪmɪ'mɔ:rɪəl］

adj. 太古的，极古的

解　long past; beyond the limits of memory or tradition or recorded history

例　The archeologist found the fossils of a three-headed creature that had been buried from time immemorial. 考古学家发现了一种三头生物的化石，它在远古时期就被埋葬了。

memorable［'memərəbəl］

adj. 值得记住的

解　worth remembering; not to be forgotten; notable

例　Chuck's 21st birthday party with all his friends and relatives was a memorable occasion for all. 查克的21岁生日派对和他所有的亲朋好友一起度过，对大家来说都很难忘。

commemorate［kə'meməreɪt］

v. 纪念

解　to be a memorial to a person or an event

例　The 4th day of July is celebrated by the American people to commemorate the independence of the country. 美国人民在7月4日这一天庆祝，以纪念这个国家的独立。

mnemonics［ni:'mɒnɪks］

n. 记忆法，记忆规则

解　a system to develop or improve the memory

例　Jerry practised mnemonics in order to get better grades on his exams and succeed in life. 为了在考试时取得更好的成绩并且获得成功的人生，杰里努力练习记忆法。



Group 121: ment=mind; spirit “思考；神智”

comment［'kɒment］

n. 评论

解　remark, a statement of fact or opinion

例　The teacher wrote down his comments on the student's essay on the last page. 老师在最后一页写下了对学生文章的评语。

commentary［'kɒməntəri］

n. ① 注释，解说词 ② 评论；批评

解　① a series of explanations or interpretations ② criticism

例　The fact that so many people are still living in poverty is indeed a sad commentary on our civilization. 如此多的人依然生活很贫困的事实是人类文明的悲剧。

同　commenter n. 评论员

构　com < con (=with) + ment (=mind) + ary

mentor［'mentɔ:(r); 'mentə(r)］

n. 导师

解　teacher

例　Doug learned from his mentor both professional skills and personal ethics, two values needed to succeed in life. 道格从他的导师那里学到了专业技能和个人道德，这正是成功的人生所需要的两种价值观念。

近　menthol n. 薄荷醇



其他与“思考”意义有关的词汇

cogitate v. 慎重思考，思索

deliberate v. 慎重考虑 adj. 深思熟虑的；故意的

mull v. 深思熟虑

premeditation n. 深思熟虑；预谋

reflect v. 反射；仔细考虑

reflective adj. 深思熟虑的；反射的

rumination n. 反刍；反复思考

contemplate v. 深思；（严肃）注视

meditation n. 沉思

meditative adj. 沉思的，冥想的

muse v. 沉思，冥想

pensive adj. 沉思的；愁眉苦脸的

ponder v. 沉思，仔细考虑

speculation n. 推测；思索；投机

thought-provoking adj. 引起思考的，发人深省的

harebrained adj. 轻率的，欠考虑的





Group 122: merc, merch=trade “交易”

commercial［kə'mɜ:ʃəl］

adj. 商业的 n. 电视或广播广告

解　designed for profit or for mass appeal n. advertisement

例　A 30-minute TV show is usually interrupted by two or three commercial breaks. 一个30分钟的电视节目通常会插入2至3个商业广告。

merchant［'mɜ:tʃənt］

n. 商人

解　a businessperson engaged in retail trade

例　The merchant sold fruit and vegetables from a portable cart on the street. 商人在停靠街边的轻便货车上售卖水果和蔬菜。

mercantile［'mɜ:kəntaɪl］

adj. 贸易的，商业的

解　of or relating to or characteristic of trade or traders

例　Silk Street is the best place to find cheap mercantile goods. 秀水街是找到便宜商品的最佳去处。

mercenary［'mɜ:sɪnəri］

adj. 唯利是图的 n. 雇佣兵

解　working only for money or other reward; inspired by love of money n. a person hired to fight in another country merely for wages

例　Mercenaries do not normally have any sense of loyalty; their only incentive is money. 雇佣兵通常都没有忠诚感；钱是他们唯一的动机。

merchandise［'mɜ:tʃəndaɪs］

n. 商品；货品

解　commodities offered for sale

例　The newspaper advertisement pictured the merchandise that was on sale. 报纸广告刊登了廉价出售的商品的图片。

Group 123: merg, mers=sink “沉，没”

emerge［ɪ'mɜ:ʤ］

v. 出现，露出

解　to come into view; to come out; to come up

例　The rabbit emerged from its hole in the morning to forage for breakfast. 早上兔子从洞里钻出来寻找食物。

emergency［ɪ'mɜ:ʤənsi］

n. 紧急情况，突然事件

解　a sudden need for immediate action

例　I keep a box of tools in my car for use in an emergency. 我在车里放了一个工具箱，以备紧急状况下使用。

submerge［səb'mɜ:ʤ］

v. 潜入水中；沉没；淹没

解　to place or plunge under water

例　The submarine submerged to escape attack. 潜艇潜入水中躲避攻击。

构　sub (=below) + merg (=to sink) + e

immerse［ɪ'mɜ:s］

v. ① 浸入 ② 沉浸于

解　① to enclose or envelop completely, as if by swallowing ② to absorb deeply, to engross

例　The student immersed himself in research in order to complete his thesis. 为了完成论文，这名学生沉浸在了研究中。

同　immersion n. 沉入，浸入

构　im < in (=into) + mers < merg (=to dip, to sink) + e



Group 124: meter=measure “计量，测量”

perimeter［pə'rɪmɪtə(r)］

n. 周围，周界；周长

解　outer boundary of a closed figure; the length of such a boundary

例　The outer perimeter of the castle was protected by a dangerous moat. 城堡的四周由一条危险的护城河来保护。

kilometer［'kɪləmi:tə(r); kɪ'lɒmɪtə(r)］

n. 千米；公里

解　a metric unit of length equal to 1,000 meters (about 0. 62 mile)

例　A marathon race usually covers a distance of a little over 40 kilometers. 马拉松比赛的赛程通常为40多公里。

odometer［əʊ'dɒmɪtə(r)］

n. （汽车等的）里程表

解　a meter that shows mileage traversed

例　Since his gas gauge was broken, he had to check his odometer to determine when he needed to get more gas. 由于汽油表坏了，他不得不检查里程表来决定是否需要加油。

近　optometrist n. 验光配镜师

thermometer［θə'mɒmɪtə(r)］

n. 温度计

解　instrument for measuring temperature

例　Little Timmy's mom feared he had a fever and used a thermometer to take his temperature. 小蒂米的母亲担心他发烧，用体温计给他测量了体温。

构　thermo (=heat) + meter (=to measure)

diameter［daɪ'æmɪtə(r)］

n. 直径

解　the length of a line segment; measurement from one side to the other through the center; width; thickness of a circle

例　The diameter of a circle is usually measured through the center. 圆的直径需要通过圆心来测量。



Group 125: metr, mens=measure “计量，测量”

symmetry［'sɪmɪtri］

n. 对称；均衡

解　regularity and balance in the arrangement of parts; even proportion and harmony

例　Scientists have proven that humans see symmetry as beauty. 科学家已经证实人类把对称看做美。

symmetric［sɪ'metrɪk］

adj. 对称的

解　having similarity in size, shape, and relative position of corresponding parts

例　A diagonal cut of a square makes two symmetric sides. 将正方形沿对角线切开可以得到两个对称的部分。

同　symmetrical adj. 对称的





asymmetric［ˌeisɪ'metrɪk］

adj. 不对称的

解　characterized by asymmetry in the spatial arrangement or placement of parts or components

例　The referee examined the basketballs before the game and disallowed use of any that were asymmetric. 比赛前裁判会检查篮球，不允许使用任何不对称的篮球。

同　asymmetrical adj. 不对称的

dimension［daɪ'menʃən］

n. 维度；尺寸；面积范围或大小；规模

解　size; extent or magnitude; scope

例　Children usually draw pictures that have only one dimension to them. 小孩子通常只会画一维的画。

commensurate［kə'menʃərɪt］

adj. 相称的；同样大小的

解　corresponding in size or degree or extent

例　Each employee received a bonus that was commensurate with his or her exceptional performance and attitude at work. 每位员工都获得了与他们的突出表现和工作态度相符的奖金。

构　com < con (=with) + mens (=to measure) + urate



其他与“计量，测量”意义有关的词汇

calibrate v. 量…的口径，校准

gauge n. 测量仪；标准规格

calorie n. 卡路里（热量单位）

cord n. 考得（木材的层积单位）

decibel n. 分贝（音量的单位）

denomination n. （长度、币值的）单位；面额；命名

fathom n. 英寻（量水深）

gallon n. 加仑

lumen n. 【物】流明（光通量单位）

ream n. 令（纸张的张数单位）

watt n. 瓦特

volt n. 伏特（电压单位）

Group 126: micro=minute, small “微，小”

microbe［'maɪkrəʊb］

n. 微生物

解　a minute life form (especially a disease-causing bacterium)

例　Town officials warned people against swimming in the local river because of the water pollution and the number of microbes floating around. 小镇的政府官员警告人们不要在当地的河里游泳，因为河水已被污染，并且水里有很多游离的微生物。

构　micro (=small) + be < bio (=life)

microorganism［ˌmaɪkrəʊ'ɔ:ɡənɪz(ə)m］

n. 微生物

解　any organism (animal or plant) of microscopic size

例　The invention of the microscope helped scientists understand the function and appearance of certain microorganisms. 显微镜的发明帮助科学家了解了某些微生物的功能和外表特征。

构　micro (=minute) + organ (=instrument) + ism

microphone［'maɪkrəfəʊn］

n. 麦克风

解　a device for converting sound waves into electrical energy

例　His voice was so loud and resonant that he did not need a microphone to speak to the crowd. 他的声音大而洪亮，对人群讲话时都不需要拿麦克风。

microscope［'maɪkrəskəʊp］

n. 显微镜

解　instrument with a lens or combination of lenses for making small things look larger

例　Bacteria, blood cells, and other objects not visible to the naked eye are clearly visible through a microscope. 细菌、血细胞以及其他肉眼看不见的东西在显微镜下都可以清楚地看到。

同　microscopic adj. 极小的；显微镜的



Group 127: mim, imit=imitate “模仿”

mime［maɪm］

n. 哑剧 v. 模拟，通过手势和身体的动作来表达

解　n. a performance using gestures and body movements without words v. to imitate; to mimic

例　The theatrical mime we saw last night was very interesting because the only sound we heard was the reaction of the audience. 我们昨晚在剧场看的哑剧十分有趣，现场唯一能听到的声音就是观众的反应。

pantomime［'pæntəmaɪm］

n. 哑剧

解　a performance using gestures and body movements without words

例　Pantomime is the telling of a story without words, by means of bodily movements, gestures, and facial expressions. 哑剧是一种不用语言，而通过肢体动作、手势和面部表情来讲故事的形式。

mimic［'mɪmɪk］

n. 模仿者（模仿他人言行的人）v. ① 模仿 ② 戏弄

解　n. person or thing that imitates v. ① to copy closely; to imitate ② to copy or imitate so as to ridicule; mock

例　A parrot can mimic a person's voice. 鹦鹉能模仿人的声音。

近　inimical adj. 为敌的，不友善的

构　mim (=to imitate) + ic

mimicry［'mɪmɪkri］

n. 模仿，（动物等的）拟态伪装

解　imitation

例　The mimicry of insects to look like leaves is a survival mechanism. 昆虫通过模仿伪装成树叶的样子是一种生存机制。





imitate［'ɪmɪteɪt］

vt. 模仿；仿效

解　to try to be like or act like; to follow the example of

例　I hate it when she imitates my actions. 我讨厌她模仿我的动作。

inimitable［ɪ'nɪmɪtəbəl］

adj. 无法仿效的，不可比拟的

解　incapable of being imitated or equaled

例　Faulkner's inimitable writing style has made his name synonymous with his style. 福克纳独特的写作风格使他的名字成了其风格的代名词。

构　in (=not) + imit (=to mimic) + able



其他与“模仿”意义有关的词汇

impersonate v. 模仿，扮演

mock v. （尤指以模仿）嘲笑，嘲弄

simulate v. 假装，模仿

travesty n. 拙劣的模仿

emulate v. 模仿并努力赶上或超越

emulation n. 竞争，仿效





Group 128: min=project “突出”

eminent［'emɪnənt］

adj. 著名的，杰出的，显著的

解　distinguished; outstanding; remarkable

例　The most eminent environmentalists from around the world met to discuss how to deal with the rising levels of global pollution. 来自世界各地的最为杰出的环保主义者聚集在一起，探讨如何应对日益严重的全球污染问题。

同　eminence n. 卓越，杰出

构　e < ex (=out) + min (=to project, to hang) + ent

imminent［'ɪmɪnənt］

adj. 即将发生的，逼近的

解　close in time, about to occur

例　When the outbreak of the war seemed imminent, the tourists rushed home. 战争似乎一触即发，游客们都纷纷回家。

构　im < in (=upon, over) + min (=to project) + ent

prominent［'prɒmɪnənt］

adj. 卓越的，显著的，杰出的

解　conspicuous in position or importance

例　The prominent leaders met to discuss peace negotiations between the two countries. 两国的主要领导人会面就和平问题进行谈判。

同　prominence n. 突出，显著

构　pro (=forth) + min (=to project) + ent

preeminent［pri:'emɪnənt］

adj. 显著的，杰出的

解　greatest in importance, degree, significance or achievement

例　Michael Jordan was the preeminent basketball player in the 1990s. 迈克尔·乔丹是上世纪90年代杰出的篮球运动员。

构　pre (=before) + e < ex (=out) + min (=to project) + ent



Group 129: min, mini=small “小”

diminish［dɪ'mɪnɪʃ］

v. （使）减少，（使）变小

解　to make or become less; reduce in size, degree, importance, etc.

例　Without insurance, your medical expenses can quickly diminish your savings. 如果没有医疗保险的话，你的积蓄很快就会被你的医疗费用所耗尽。

构　di < dis (=apart) + min (=small) + ish

minimal［'mɪnɪməl］

adj. 最小的，最小限度的

解　least possible; very small

例　Eric was so lazy that he only exerted the minimal effort to pass his courses. 埃里克太懒了，他只付出了最小的努力来通过各科的考试。

minimize［'mɪnɪmaɪz］

v. 低估；把…减到最小

解　to reduce to the smallest possible amount or degree

例　The company directors met to talk about ways to minimize risks and increase profits. 公司主管聚集在一起，讨论降低风险和提高利润的方法。

minority［maɪ'nɒrɪti; mɪ-］

n. ① 少数 ② 少数民族

解　① the smaller number or part; less than half ② a group within a country, state, etc., that differs in race, religion, national origin, etc., from the larger part of the population

例　A minority of the voters wanted a tax increase, but the majority defeated it. 少数选民希望增加税收，但是大多数选民都不同意。

minuscule［'mɪnəskju:l］

adj. ① 极小的，微小的 ② 小写的

解　① very small ② of, relating to, or written in a lowercase letter

例　The microbiologist used an electron microscope to examine minuscule objects. 微生物学家使用电子显微镜来检测微小的物体。





minutia［maɪ'nju:ʃɪə］

n. 微枝末节，细节

解　details, trivia

例　The media gives us more minutiae about movie stars than we really need to know. 媒体向我们报导很多关于电影明星的细节资料，比我们真正想知道的多得多。

diminutive［dɪ'mɪnjutɪv］

adj. 小巧可爱的 n. 爱称，昵称（极小的人或物）

解　very small; tiny n. a word that is formed with a suffix to indicate smallness

例　Though he was diminutive, he had a lot of power in the government. 他虽然身材矮小，但在政府里拥有很大的权力。

miniature［'mɪnətʃə(r)］

adj. 小型的，缩影的 n. 小画像；缩影

解　being on a very small scale n. a copy or model that represents or reproduces something in a greatly reduced size

例　His favorite hobby was collecting miniature models of cars. 他的爱好是收集汽车模型。

Group 130: mis=wrong; bad; ill “错误；坏”

misdeed［ˌmɪs'di:d］

n. 恶行

解　a bad act; wicked deed

例　The president's misdeed became a controversial scandal. 总统的恶劣行为变成了一个引起争议的丑闻。

misdemeanor［ˌmɪsdɪ'mi:nə(r)］

n. 【律】轻罪；不良行为

解　an offence less serious than a felony; minor crime

例　Since Brad was only charged with a misdemeanor, not a felony, he received a light sentence. 由于布拉德只是被指控为品行不端，而非刑事重罪，因此他被从轻判决。

misbehave［mɪs'bɪheɪv］

v. 行为不端，举止不当

解　to behave (oneself) in an inappropriate way

例　Although she was the brightest student in the class, she was not nominated to receive the “Model Student Award” because she misbehaved. 她是班里最聪明的学生，但是由于行为不端，她没有获得“模范学生奖”的提名。

miscreant［'mɪskrɪənt］

n. 恶棍，歹徒

解　wretch; villain

例　The miscreant became a lawless criminal when he grew up. 这个恶棍长大以后变成了一个违法犯罪的罪犯。



Group 131: mod=manner “模式；风度”

modish［'məʊdɪʃ］

adj. 时髦的

解　fashionable

例　She always discarded all garments which were no longer modish. 她通常会把所有过时的衣服都扔掉。

outmoded［ˌaʊt'məʊdɪd］

adj. 不再流行的，过时的

解　out of fashion

例　The crank telephone was outmoded long ago. 转动曲柄电话机很早以前就已经过时了。

remodel［ˌri:'mɒdəl］

v. 重建，改变形状

解　to make over; to change or alter

例　They tore down some walls when they remodeled the house in order to create a more spacious atmosphere. 改造房屋的时候，为了使空间更加宽敞，他们拆除了一些墙体。

modify［'mɒdɪfaɪ］

v. 修改，变更

解　to change something a little

例　He asked the mechanic to modify his car to include his preferences, such as a new sunroof and tinted windows. 他要求机械师按照他的偏好来改装汽车，比如换个天窗、换个深色的车窗玻璃。

同　modification n. 修饰，修改

modest［'mɒdɪst］

adj. ① 谦虚的，谦让的 ② 适度的

解　① not thinking too highly of oneself; not vain; humble ② not too great; not asking too much

例　In spite of many honors, the scientist remained a modest person. 虽然获得了很多荣誉，这位科学家依然很谦虚。

同　modesty n. 谦虚；节制





Group 132: mono=single; sole; alone “单；一个”

monocle［'mɒnɒkəl］

n. 单片眼镜

解　a lens for correcting defective vision in one eye

例　The professor used a monocle since one of his eyes was blind. 自从一只眼睛失明之后，教授一直使用单片眼镜。

monologue［'mɒnəlɒɡ］

n. ① 自言自语 ② 独白

解　① speech you make to yourself ② a (usually long) dramatic speech by a single actor

例　She entertained the audience with a witty autobiographical monologue. 她使用机智诙谐的自传式独白愉悦观众。

构　mono (=single) + log (=speech) + ue

monopoly［mə'nɒpəli］

n. 垄断，专利权

解　exclusive control or possession of something

例　The government refused to allow the two corporations to merge into one for fear that they would create a monopoly and charge customers any price they wanted. 政府不允许这两家公司合并成一家，因为担心这样会形成垄断，会导致他们向消费者任意要价。

同　monopolization n. 垄断

monotony［mə'nɒtəni］

n. 单调

解　sameness leading to boredom

例　The monotony in the professor's voice made many students doze off during class. 教授单调的声音使很多学生在课堂上打起了瞌睡。

同　monotonous adj. 单调的，无聊的

monolithic［ˌmɒnə'lɪθɪk］

adj. ① 整体式的 ② 完整的；坚定的；庞大的

解　① constituting or acting as a single, often rigid, uniform whole ② uniform, solid, and massive

例　Nothing could bend the monolithic will of the people. 没有什么能使人民坚定的意愿屈服。

构　mono (=one) + lith (=stone) + ic

音频



Group 133: mot=move “移动”

demote［dɪ'məʊt］

v. 降级，降职

解　to assign to a lower position; to reduce in rank

例　The student who had trouble doing fourth-grade work was demoted to third grade. 这个学生学习四年级的课程比较吃力，于是被降级到了三年级。

构　de (=down) + mot (=to move) + e

promote［prə'məʊt］

v. ① 提升 ② 促进

解　① to raise to a more important or responsible job or rank ② to contribute to the progress or growth of

例　After doubling company sales, she was promoted to regional sales director. 在使公司销售业绩翻了一番之后，她被提升为区域销售经理。

同　promotion n. 促进

remote［rɪ'məʊt］

adj. 遥远的；偏僻的

解　far away; out of the way; secluded

例　The North Pole is a remote part of the world. 北极是世界上很遥远的一个地方。





commotion［kə'məʊʃən］

n. 骚动，动乱

解　a disturbance or violent agitation

例　The couple's argument created such a commotion that the neighbors were worried and called the police. 夫妻之间的争吵变得越来越激烈，邻居都担心了起来，于是报了警。

构　com < con (=together) + mot (=to move) + ion

motility［məʊ'tɪlɪtɪ］

n. 能动性

解　ability to move spontaneously

例　The motility of frogs comes from the propulsion of their leg muscles. 青蛙之所以能跳动，是由于它的腿部肌肉具有推进力。

motive［'məʊtɪv］

n. 动机，目的

解　the reason for the action

例　The student had only one motive in college—to make good grades and find a good job after graduation. 这个学生上大学只有一个目的，那就是拿高分，然后在毕业后找一份好工作。

locomotive［ˌləʊkə'məʊtɪv］

n. 火车头，机车 adj. 运动的

解　n. self-propelled engine used to draw trains along railway tracks adj. able to move independently from place to place

例　Steam engines were used to drive locomotives, ships, and large machines. 蒸汽机被用来驱动火车头、轮船和大型机器。

motivate［'məʊtɪveɪt］

v. 促使，激发

解　to give a motive or incentive to

例　The coach motivated his players to play the best game of their lives. 教练激励运动员们打一场生平最好的比赛。

同　motivation n. 动机，目的；motivational adj. 激发积极性的



Group 134: nomin=name “名字；名誉”

nominate［'nɒmɪneɪt］

v. 提名

解　to propose as a candidate for some honor

例　The Democrats and the Republicans each nominate one candidate for the presidential election. 民主党和共和党分别推荐了一名候选人来竞选总统。

nominal［'nɒmɪnəl］

adj. 名义上的，有名无实的

解　existing in name only; not real

例　The president is the nominal head of our club, but the secretary really runs things. 我们社团在名义上的领导是会长，但真正处理事务的是书记。

构　nomin (=name) + al (=nature of)

denominate［dɪ'nɒmɪneɪt］

vt. ① 以…面值发行 ② 命名

解　① to issue or express in terms of a given monetary unit ② to give a name to

例　Most international securities are denominated in dollars or yen. 大多数国际证券以美元或者日元来发行。

同　denomination n. （长度、币值的）单位；面额；命名

ignominious［ˌɪɡnə'mɪniəs］

adj. 可耻的，可鄙的；屈辱的

解　bringing contempt, disgrace, shame; dishonorable; disgraceful

例　The losing team returned home from the tournament with sadness because of their ignominious defeat. 由于在比赛中惨败，队伍带着悲伤的心情回去了。

构　ig < in (=not) + nomin (=name) + ious

同　ignominy n. 羞耻，屈辱



其他与“名字”意义有关的词汇

alias n. 化名，别名

byline n. 文章作者署名行（新闻报道、文章等列作者名字的首行）

signature n. 签名，署名

pseudonym n. 假名，笔名

sinecure n. 挂名差事，闲职





其他与“名誉，名声”意义有关的词汇

prestige n. 声望

renown n. 名望，声誉

reputation n. 名声，名誉

repute n. 名望，名声

obscurity n. 费解；不出名

discredit v. 败坏名声，丧失名誉；怀疑

disrepute n. 坏名声

opprobrium n. 恶名声；侮辱





Group 135: norm=rule; norm “规则；规范”

normal［'nɔ:məl］

adj. 正常的，一般的

解　according to what is expected, usual, or average

例　The scorching heat is normal weather during the summer in Beijing. 在北京的夏天，高温天气很正常。

normalization［ˌnɔ:məlaɪ'zeɪʃən］

n. 标准化

解　the imposition of a standard

例　The quality control department assured the normalization of production processes, resulting in quality products for the company. 质量控制部门确保生产过程的标准化，从而使公司生产出质量合格的产品。

abnormal［æb'nɔ:məl］

adj. 不正常的，变态的

解　deviating from the normal or average

例　The Elephant Man is a movie about a man who had an abnormal face. 《象人》是一部关于一个面部畸形的男人的电影。

构　ab (=from) + norm (=rule) + al

anomalous［ə'nɒmələs］

adj. 反常的，不规则的

解　deviating from the general or common order or type

例　It would be anomalous for a principal to have no authority. 一个校长没有任何权威，这是很不正常的。

同　anomaly n. 异常，反常；反常的事件

enormity［ɪ'nɔ:mɪti］

n. ① 极恶，暴行 ② 巨大

解　① (an act of) extreme wickedness ② great size; immensity

例　The enormity of China makes it a country with immeasurable natural resources. 中国国土面积辽阔，因而有着大量的自然资源。

Group 136: nounce, nunci=speak “讲话，说出”

announce［ə'naʊns］

v. 宣告，宣布

解　to make known publicly

例　The teacher announced to the class the sad news of the national disaster. 老师在班上通报了国家遭受灾难的沉痛消息。

同　announcement n. 声明

pronounce［prə'naʊns］

v. ① 发音 ② 宣告，断言

解　① to make the sounds of; speak ② to declare solemnly or positively

例　People from the north and the south pronounce some words differently. 北方人和南方人对有些单词的发音不同。

同　pronouncement n. 公告；pronunciation n. 发音

pronounced［prə'naʊnst］

adj. 明显的

解　strongly marked; emphatic; decided

例　You could tell when Pinocchio was lying because of the pronounced growth of his nose. 匹诺曹说谎的时候你能看出来，因为他的鼻子明显地变长了。

denounce［dɪ'naʊns］

vt. 公开指责，公然抨击，谴责

解　to accuse or condemn openly or formally

例　The media denounced the police officer for his cruel treatment of the suspect. 媒体谴责警察虐待嫌疑犯。

同　denunciation n. 批评，谴责





renounce［rɪ'naʊns］

v. 正式放弃；宣布断绝关系

解　to give up, such as power or duties and obligations

例　The prince renounced his right to the throne and sought a life of enlightenment. 王子放弃了王位的继承权，去寻求一种大彻大悟的人生。

构　re (=back, against) + nounc (=to say) + e

enunciate［ɪ'nʌnsɪeɪt］

v. 清晰地发音；（清楚地）表达

解　to express or state clearly

例　Public speakers must be able to enunciate their words clearly in order for people to understand. 为了让听众理解自己所说的内容，演讲者必须做到吐字清晰。

构　e (=out) + nunci (=to announce) + ate



Group 137: onym=nam “名字”

anonymity［ˌænə'nɪmɪti］

n. 无名，匿名

解　state of being nameless

例　The donor of the gift asked the college not to mention him by name, and the dean readily agreed to respect his anonymity. 礼物捐赠人要求学校不要提到他的名字，校长也毫不勉强，同意尊重他匿名的要求。

synonymous［sɪ'nɒnɪməs］

adj. 同义的

解　having the same or nearly the same meaning

例　The name “Bill Gates” has been synonymous with Windows software in recent years. 最近几年，比尔·盖茨的名字几乎成了Windows软件的同义词。

pseudonym［'sju:dənɪm］

n. 假名，笔名

解　a fictitious name used when a person performs a particular social role

例　Many famous authors have pseudonyms so their real identity will not be directly associated with their books. 许多著名的作家都使用笔名，这样他们的真实身份就不会和其所著书籍有直接联系。



Group 138: ori=rise; begin “升起；开始”

orient［'ɔ:rɪənt］

v. ① 确定方向 ② 使熟悉情况 adj. 东方的

解　v. ① to set in a definite position ② to make familiar with or adjusted to facts, principles, or a situation adj. eastern; oriental

例　The Smith family decided to go to the orient country for summer vacation and see the Great Wall. 史密斯一家决定去中国过暑假，还要参观长城。

同　orientation n. 定向；熟悉环境

disoriented［dɪs'ɔ:rɪəntɪd］

adj. 迷失方向的

解　confused as to time or place or personal identity

例　It is easy to become disoriented in the forest. 在森林里很容易迷失方向。





origin［'ɒrɪʤɪn］

n. ① 起源，由来 ② 出身，血统

解　① the fact of originating; rise or derivation ② ancestry

例　The English language has Latin origins. 英语部分起源于拉丁文。

original［ə'rɪʤɪnəl］

n. 原物，原作 adj. ① 最初的，原始的 ② 独创的，新颖的

解　n. a first form from which other forms are made or developed adj. ① preceding all others in time; first ② being or productive of something fresh and unusual

例　The board members decided to discard the original plan in light of the new circumstances. 因为有新的情况发生，董事会成员决定放弃原先的计划。

同　originality n. 创造性，独特性

originate［ə'rɪʤɪneɪt］

v. 发起，创办

解　to cause or bring into existence

例　The long river originated from one ocean and ended in another. 这条长河发源于一片大海，最后注入另一片大海。



其他与“开始”意义有关的词汇

commence v. 开始；倡导

commencement n. 开始；（大学的）毕业典礼

inaugurate v. 举行就职典礼；开创

inception n. 开端，开始；取得学位

inchoate adj. 刚开始的，未发展的

incipient adj. 初期的，刚出现的

initiate v. 开始，着手；创始

preliminary adj. 初步的，开始的

Lesson 41





音频



Group 139: out=out; beyond “向外”引申为“超越，胜过”

outcast［'aʊtkɑ:st; (US)-kæst］

n. 被社会遗弃者

解　a person or animal cast out from home and friends

例　The criminal was an outcast from society. 这名罪犯是一个被社会遗弃的人。

outing［'aʊtɪŋ］

n. 外出郊游

解　a journey taken for pleasure

例　The father took his two sons on an outing as a male bonding experience. 父亲带着两个儿子去郊游，这是一种兄弟情谊般的旅行经历。

outgoing［'aʊtɡəʊɪŋ］

adj. ① 即将离职的 ② 对人友好的

解　① going out or away ② friendly and sociable; somewhat extroverted; at ease in talking to others

例　She was very outgoing and would always introduce herself to people she did not know. 她对人十分友好，总是向不认识的人介绍自己。

outskirts［'aʊtskɜ:ts］

n. 郊区，郊外

解　the outer parts or edges of a town, district, etc.

例　We have a farm on the outskirts of town. 我们在市郊有个农场。

outlandish［aʊt'lændɪʃ］

adj. 异国风味的；奇怪的，古怪的

解　looking or sounding odd, strange or foreign

例　He was known for asking outlandish questions that raised everyone's eyebrows. 大家都知道他喜欢问一些让人瞠目的古怪问题。





outlet［'aʊtlet］

n. ① 出口，出路 ② 发泄

解　① an opening that permits escape or release ② activity that releases or expresses creative energy or emotion

例　This lake's outlet is a stream that flows into the ocean. 这个湖的出口是一条流入大海的小溪。

近　amulet n. 护身符

outmaneuver［ˌaʊtmə'nu:və］

v. 以策略制胜

解　to overcome by being superior in maneuvering

例　The police were outmaneuvered by the bank robbers' trick and disguise. 警察被银行抢劫犯的花招和伪装所蒙骗。



Group 140: over=across; beyond “过度；太过”

overcome［ˌəʊvə'kʌm］

vt. 战胜；克服

解　to get the better of; to win the victory over; to conquer

例　The doctor gave her some drugs to help her overcome the depression of losing her parents. 医生给她开了一些药，帮助她克服失去双亲所造成的精神抑郁。

近　income n. 收入；outcome n. 结局，结果；unbecoming adj. 不合适的，不合礼节的；welcome v. 欢迎

overhaul［ˌəʊvə'hɔ:l］

v. 大修，彻底检查

解　to examine or go over carefully for needed repair

例　The economic reform overhauled the previous system and implanted a more open economy. 这次的经济改革全面审视了以前的制度，重新引入了一个更加开放的经济体系。

overturn［ˌəʊvə'tɜ:n］

v. ① 打翻；（使）翻过来；（使）倒转 ② 颠覆；打倒

解　① to cause to turn over or capsize; upset ② to cause the ruin or destruction of; overthrow

例　The high waves caused by the rainstorm overturned the small boat and the passengers had to swim to shore. 暴风雨引起的巨浪掀翻了小船，船上的乘客不得不游到岸边。

overwhelm［ˌəʊvə'welm］

v. ① 淹没；吞没，席卷 ② 控制，对思想或情绪影响深刻

解　① to surge over and submerge; engulf ② to affect deeply in mind or emotion

例　His grandmother always overwhelmed him with kisses every time she saw him. 他的祖母每次见到他都会热烈地亲吻他。

同　overwhelming adj. 压倒性的，无法抵抗的

overbearing［ˌəʊvə'bərɪŋ］

adj. 专横的，独断的

解　expecting unquestioning obedience

例　Her overbearing father would not let her go out with her friends at night. 她的父亲很专制，不让她在晚上和朋友一起出去。

overlook［ˌəʊvə'lʊk］

vt. ① 俯瞰，远眺 ② 忽视，没注意到

解　① to look over or at from a higher place ② to fail to notice or consider; miss

例　His Los Angeles apartment had a beautiful view that overlooked the bay area. 他在洛杉矶的公寓视野很好，可以俯瞰整个海湾地区。

overreach［ˌəʊvə'ri:tʃ］

v. 超过了限度，做过了头或所求过多而 （使自己）失败

解　to defeat (oneself) by going too far or by doing or trying to gain too much

例　His repeated apologies overreached his goal of her forgiveness and started to annoy her. 他不断地道歉，最后不仅没有达到让她原谅的目的，反而惹恼了她。

overwrought［ˌəʊvə'rɔ:t］

adj. 紧张过度的，兴奋过度的

解　excessively nervous or excited; agitated

例　After drinking five cups of coffee, he looked even more overwrought before the final examination. 他在期末考试前喝了五杯咖啡，但看起来比之前更加紧张了。

Group 141: par=equal “相等的”

disparage［dɪ'spærɪʤ］

v. 贬抑，轻蔑

解　to express a negative opinion of

例　He could not stand how she disparaged other people behind their backs. 他无法忍受她在背后说别人的坏话。

构　dis (=not) + par (=equal) + age

disparate［'dɪspərɪt］

adj. 截然不同的，不可并论的

解　basically different; unrelated

例　The marriage between the disparate couple was doomed to fail. 这对夫妻的性格截然不同，他们的婚姻注定会失败。

构　dis (=away) + par (=equal) + ate

parity［'pærɪti］

n. ① 同等；平等 ② 相同；类似

解　① equality ② close resemblance

例　I find your analogy inaccurate because I do not see the parity between the two illustrations. 我发现你的类比是错误的，因为我没看出这两个例子之间有什么相似的地方。

同　disparity n. 不同，差异

comparison［kəm'pærɪsən］

n. ① 比较，对照 ② 相似或相同的性质；类似

解　① act or process of comparing ② the likenesses and differences

例　The teacher's comparison of the heart to a pump helped the students to understand how the heart works. 老师把心脏比做泵，以帮助学生理解心脏的工作原理。



Group 142: part=part; to part “部分；分开”

partial［'pɑ:ʃəl］

adj. ① 部分的 ② 偏袒的

解　① only part of the entire thing ② inclined to favor one side more than another; favoring unfairly

例　Parents should not be partial to one of their children. 父母不应对某个孩子有偏袒之心。

同　partiality n. 偏见；偏袒，偏心

impartial［ɪm'pɑ:ʃəl］

adj. 公平的，无私的

解　showing no more favor to one side than to the other; fair; just

例　A judge should be impartial. 法官应该公正无私。

同　impartiality n. 公正，客观；无私

构　im < in (=not) + part (=part) + ial

impart［ɪm'pɑ:t］

v. 告知；透露

解　to make known; to disclose

例　The teacher imparted some final advice to the students at their graduation. 在学生们毕业之际，老师给了他们一些最后的忠告。

近　parlance n. 谈话，说法；pariah n. 贱民；被社会遗弃者

participate［pɑ:'tɪsɪpeɪt］

v. ① 参加 ② 分享

解　① take part in something ② share in something

例　Teams from countries all over the world participated in the international tournament. 来自世界各个国家的队伍都参加了此次的国际锦标赛。

同　participant n. 参加者

partner［'pɑ:tnə(r)］

n. ① 合伙人 ② 伙伴；伴侣

解　① member of a company or firm who shares the risks and profits of the business ② one who shares

例　A policeman usually works with a partner in case he needs backup. 警察工作的时候通常两人为一组，以防需要支援。

repartee［ˌrepɑ:'ti:］

n. ① 巧妙的应答 ② 巧妙应答的才能

解　① a quick, witty reply ② skill in making witty replies

例　The public considered the winner of the political debate to be the man with the most repartees. 公众认为这场政治辩论的获胜者是这个妙语连珠的人。

近　repatriate v. （自异国）遣返

构　re (=back) + part (=part) + ee

apartment［ə'pɑ:tmənt］

n. 公寓

解　room or group of rooms to live in; flat

例　The apartment in the inland city was very expensive because of its view of the lake. 由于市内有个湖，所以这个内陆城市的房价很高。





depart［dɪ'pɑ:t］

v. 离开

解　to go away; to leave

例　The plane should have departed an hour ago but was delayed because of the bad weather. 飞机一小时前就该起飞了，但是由于天气恶劣，所以被延迟了。

partisan［ˌpɑ:tɪ'zæn］

n. 狂热党徒，党派支持者

解　person devoted to a cause or party

例　A partisan often favors politics. 党派支持者都喜欢政治。

同　partisanship n. 党派偏见

partition［pɑ:'tɪʃən］

vt. 区分，隔开，分割

解　to divide into parts, pieces, or sections

例　 The real estate company partitioned the land into one-acre lots. 房地产公司把土地都划分成了一英亩的小块。



其他与“分开”意义有关的词汇

bifurcate v. 分为两支，分叉

disjoin v. 分开，使脱节

disjunctive adj. 分割的，分离的

diverge v. 分歧，分开

riven adj. 劈开的

watershed n. 分水岭，分界

Group 143: pass=pass “通过”

encompass［ɪn'kʌmpəs］

v. ① 包围，环绕 ② 包含或包括某事物

解　① go or reach all the way around; encircle ② include; contain

例　Our history book encompasses all the important events in the American history. 我们的历史书中包含了美国历史上的所有重要事件。

bypass［'baɪpɑ:s; (US)'baɪpæs］

v. 规避，绕过 n. 旁路

解　v. to avoid sth. unpleasant or laborious n. a highway that passes around or to one side of an obstructed or congested area

例　The company that bypassed paying taxes was sued for millions by the IRS. 这家逃税的公司被美国国税局起诉，并索赔数百万美元。

impassable［ɪm'pɑ:səbəl］

adj. 不能通行的，无路可通的

解　impossible to pass, cross, or overcome

例　The Great Wall made the hills almost impassable for any army. 长城使得任何军队几乎都无法进入山里。

trespass［'trespəs］

v. ① 侵犯，闯入私人领地 ② 侵占另一个人的时间、隐私或注意力

解　① to go on to privately owned land without right or permission ② to take too much of someone's time, privacy, attention, etc.

例　The boys trespassed into the private property out of curiosity, and were chased away by two big dogs. 男孩们出于好奇闯入了这个私人住宅，然后被两只大狗追赶了出来。

impasse［'æmpɑ:s; 'ɪm-］

n. ① 死路 ② 僵局

解　① a road or passage having no exit ② a situation that is so difficult that no progress can be made

例　The jury members reached an impasse and couldn't unanimously agree on the verdict. 陪审团成员间陷入僵局，无法对裁决达成一致意见。





Group 144: pass=feeling; to feel “感情；感觉”

passion［'pæʃən］

n. 热情，激情

解　strong feeling or emotion

例　The passion he felt for her was overwhelming. 他对她的感情非常强烈。

compassion［kəm'pæʃən］

n. 同情，怜悯

解　a deep awareness of and sympathy for another's suffering

例　Compassion for the earthquake victims brought a flood of contributions. 出于对地震遇难者的同情，大家纷纷捐款捐物。

近　compatible adj. 和谐共处的，相容的

构　com < con (=together) + pass (=to feel, to suffer) + ion

passionate［'pæʃənɪt］

adj. 热情的

解　having or expressing strong emotions

例　The soldier's wife gave him a passionate kiss when he returned home after so many years away. 士兵离家多年之后归来，他的妻子给了他深情的一吻。

impassioned［ɪm'pæʃənd］

adj. 充满激情的

解　characterized by intense emotion

例　Charlie gave an impassioned performance that earned him a standing ovation at the end of the play. 在演出的尾声，查理充满激情的表演赢得了观众的喝彩。

dispassionate［dɪ'spæʃənɪt］

adj. 冷静的，不带感情的，平心静气的

解　free from passion; not taking sides in a quarrel between others; calm

例　You must try to subdue the natural emotions of a parent and make a dispassionate decision that will be in the best interest of your son. 你必须努力克制住为人父母的自然感情，冷静地作出一个最有利于你儿子的决定。

构　dis (=not) + pass (=to feel, to suffer) + ion + ate

passivity［pæ'sɪvɪti］

n. 被动（性）；不活动性

解　submission to others or to outside influences

例　The bear entered into a state of passivity during its winter hibernation. 熊在冬眠期间进入不活动状态。

impassive［ɪm'pæsɪv］

adj. 无动于衷的，冷漠的

解　having or revealing little emotion or sensibility

例　It's not that he doesn't care about what you said. It's just his impassive personality. 他并不是不在乎你所说的话；他只是性格比较冷淡。

构　im < in (=not) + pass (=to feel, to suffer) + ive



其他与“感情”意义有关的词汇

sentiment n. 感情，感伤

demonstrative adj. 展示性的；感情外露的

ebullience n. 感情奔放，兴冲冲

effusive adj. 感情奔放的；流出的

emote v. 激动地表达感情

empathy n. 心意相通，（感情等）融为一体

empathetic adj. 感情移入的

impulsive adj. 易冲动的，感情用事的

maudlin adj. 感情脆弱的，爱哭的

mawkish adj. 自作多情的；令人作呕的

stolid adj. 无动于衷的，感情麻木的





Group 145: path=feel, suffer“感觉”

apathetic［ˌæpə'θetɪk］

adj. 冷漠的，无动于衷的

解　showing little or no emotion or animation

例　Many people are apathetic about social issues and are only concerned about their own self-interest. 许多人对社会事件漠不关心，而只在乎自身的利益。

构　a (=not) + path (=to feel, to suffer) + etic

同　apathy n. 漠然，冷淡

antipathy［æn'tɪpəθi］

n. 憎恶，反感

解　intense dislike

例　Women usually have an antipathy to mice and spiders. 女性通常都讨厌老鼠和蜘蛛。

构　anti (=against, opposite) + path (=to feel) + y

empathy［'empəθi］

n. 心意相通，（感情等）融为一体

解　understanding and entering into another's feelings

例　Robert Kennedy became very popular because of his charisma and empathy with the American public. 因为其个人魅力以及对群众心声的了解，罗伯特·肯尼迪在美国人民的心目中非常受欢迎。

同　empathetic adj. 感情移入的

构　em < en (=in) + path (=to feel, to suffer) + y

sympathy［'sɪmpəθi］

n. 同情

解　sharing the feelings of others (especially feelings of sorrow or anguish)

例　She felt sympathy for the bird with a broken wing and nursed it back to health. 她同情这只翅膀受伤的鸟儿，一直护理它直到康复。

近　symphony n. 交响乐，交响曲；sociopath n. 极端反社会的人

同　sympathetic adj. 有同情心的

Lesson 44

Group 146: pau, pu, po, penu=few; poor “少量，贫穷”

paucity［'pɔ:sɪti］

n. ① 极少量 ② 缺乏

解　① smallness of number; fewness ② scarcity; dearth

例　The long drought cause a paucity in crops for farmers. 长期的干旱使农民的庄稼歉收了。

pauper［'pɔ:pə(r)］

n. 贫民，乞丐

解　a person who is very poor

例　Paupers surrounded the crowded public places, begging people for money and food. 乞丐们在人潮拥挤的地方向人们乞讨金钱和食物。





puerile［'pjʊəraɪl; (US)-rəl］

adj. ① 幼稚的 ② 儿童的

解　① immature; childish ② belonging to childhood; juvenile

例　Her puerile jokes made her seem like a little girl. 她的笑话很幼稚，让她看起来像个小女孩。

pusillanimous［ˌpju:sɪ'lænɪməs］

adj. 懦弱的，胆小的

解　lacking in courage and manly strength and resolution

例　You should be ashamed of your pusillanimous conduct during this dispute. 你应该为你在这场争论中表现出的懦弱行为感到羞耻。

poverty［'pɒvəti］

n. 贫穷

解　the state of being poor; lack of the means of providing material needs or comforts

例　The bad economy has increased the number of people living in poverty. 萧条的经济形势使得贫困人口的数量又增加了。

impoverish［ɪm'pɒvərɪʃ］

v. 使成赤贫

解　to make indigent or poor

例　High taxes further impoverished the peasants. 高额的税收使农民变得更加贫困了。

构　im < in (=in) + pover (=poor) + ish

penury［'penjʊrɪ］

n. 贫穷

解　a state of extreme poverty or destitution

例　We find much penury and suffering in this slum. 我们在这片贫民窟看到了太多的贫穷和苦难。

同　penurious adj. 吝啬的，小气的；贫困的；缺乏的



其他与“贫困，贫穷”意义有关的词汇

destitution n. 缺乏，贫穷

impecunious adj. 不名一文的，贫困的

indigent adj. 贫困的，贫穷的

indigence n. 贫穷

needy adj. 非常贫困的





Group 147: pend, pens=expend “花费”

spendthrift［'spendθrɪft］

n. 挥霍者，败家子 adj. 挥金如土的

解　n. one who spends money recklessly or wastefully adj. wasteful or extravagant

例　The father never enjoyed taking his spendthrift daughters shopping. 父亲非常不喜欢带他的几个花钱大手大脚的女儿去购物。

同　thrift n. 节俭

expend［ɪk'spend］

v. 花费；用光

解　to consume; to use up

例　The bad manager expended the company's annual budget in one month. 这个不称职的经理在一个月内就花光了公司一年的预算。

expensive［ɪk'spensɪv］

adj. 昂贵的

例　Fresh strawberries are expensive in the winter. 在冬天，新鲜的草莓价格很高。

同　inexpensive adj. 便宜的，不昂贵的

expenditure［ɪk'spendɪtʃə(r); ek-］

n. 花费，消耗，支出

解　money paid out; the act of consuming something or spending money for goods or services

例　When they realized the expenditures were greater than the profits, they knew it wasn't worthwhile. 当他们意识到支出要远远超过收益时，他们知道这很不值得。



Group 148: person=person “人；容貌”

personable［'pɜ:sənəbəl］

adj. 容貌好的；有风度的

解　(of persons) pleasant in appearance and personality

例　The interviewer hired the personable candidate for the job of receptionist. 面试官雇用了这个长相漂亮的候选人来做前台接待的工作。

personality［ˌpɜ:sə'næləti］

n. 性格

解　the complex of all the attributes—behavioral, temperamental, emotional and mental—that characterize a unique individual

例　The survey reported that personality and appearance are the two top characteristics that men look for in wives. 调查显示，男士在寻找另一半时最看重性格和外貌。

personnel［ˌpɜ:sə'nel］

n. 人员，职员

解　group of people willing to obey orders

例　The human resource department is responsible for hiring personnel. 人力资源部门负责招聘员工。

impersonate［ɪm'pə:səneɪt］

v. 模仿，扮演

解　to assume or act the character of

例　Many comedians will impersonate and make fun of famous people at this wedding reception. 在婚宴上，许多喜剧演员将扮演名人并拿他们取乐。

同　impersonator n. 扮演者



其他与“人”有关的词汇

bungler n. 经验不够的人

cowhand n. 牧场工人

lumberjack n. 伐木工人

bricklayer n. 砌砖工

synthetic adj. 综合的；人造的 n. 人造品，合成品

artificial adj. 人工的；做作的

artifact n. 工人制品

margarine n. 人造黄油

Group 149: pha, phen, phan=show “显示”

diaphanous［daɪ'æfənəs］

adj. （布）精致的，半透明的

解　so thin as to transmit light

例　Gauze is a diaphanous fabric. 薄纱是一种半透明的织物。

构　dia (=through) + phan (=to show, to appear) + ous





phenomenon［fə'nɒmɪnən］

n. 现象

解　fact, event, or circumstance that can be observed

例　Lightning is an electrical phenomenon. 闪电是一种放电现象。

同　phenomenology n. 现象学

sycophant［'sɪkəfənt］

n. 马屁精

解　a person who tries to please someone in order to gain a personal advantage

例　A sycophant looks like a friend, but the way he flatters is like a dog. 马屁精看起来像是朋友，但是他们献媚的方式就像狗一样。

构　syco (=a fig tree) + phan (=to show) + t

emphasize［'emfəsaɪz］

v. 强调

解　to stress, single out as important

例　The dentist emphasized to the children the importance of brushing their teeth at least twice a day. 牙医向孩子们强调每天至少刷两次牙的重要性。

emphasis［'emfəsɪs］

n. 强调

解　special force; stress

例　That school puts emphasis on arithmetic and reading. 学校重视算术和阅读。

emphatically［ɪm'fætɪkəli］

adv. 着重地，强调地

解　in an emphatic manner; to an emphatic degree

例　He emphatically apologized for pronouncing her last name incorrectly in public. 他因为在公众场合把她的姓念错了而特意道了歉。



Group 150: phil=love “爱”

philanthropy［fɪ'lænθrəpi］

n. 仁慈，博爱

解　love of humanity shown by practical kindness and helpfulness

例　Tom showed a great deal of philanthropy by volunteering to organize the charity event. 汤姆自愿组织慈善活动，展现了他的博爱之情。

philanthropic［ˌfɪlən'θrɔpɪk］

adj. 博爱的

解　charitable; benevolent

例　The philanthropic association donated money to worthy causes. 慈善协会对值得捐助的事业捐助资金。

同　philanthropist n. 慈善家

近　misanthrope n. 厌世者，愤世嫉俗者

philatelist［fɪ'lætəlɪst］

n. 集邮家

解　stamp-collector

例　When she heard the value of the Penny Black stamp, Phyllis was inspired to become a philatelist. 菲莉斯听说了黑便士邮票（英国1840年发行的面值1便士的黑色邮票）的价值之后，受到激发成为了集邮爱好者。

同　philately n. 集邮



其他与“爱”有关的词汇

affection n. 亲情；柔情

affectionate adj. 充满情爱的，挚爱的

narcissism n. 自恋，自爱

platonic adj. 柏拉图式的，精神恋爱的，纯友谊的（爱情）

woo v. 向（女人）求爱；争取…的支持

flirt vi. 调情





Group 151: phon=sound “声音”

phonetic［fə'netɪk］

adj. 语音的

解　of sounds made with the voice

例　Phonetic exercises are drills in pronunciation. 语音训练就是发音的练习。

cacophony［kæ'kɒfəni］

n. 刺耳的音调，响亮而不和谐的声音

解　a disagreeable harsh sound

例　Some people seem to enjoy the cacophony of an orchestra that is tuning up. 许多人似乎很喜欢调过音后的管弦乐的音调。

同　cacophonous adj. （声音）刺耳的

构　caco (=bad) + phon (=sound) + y

symphony［'sɪmfəni］

n. 交响乐，交响曲

解　an elaborate musical composition for an orchestra

例　Tickets to the country's national symphony concert on National Day were sold out days before the event. 在国庆节当天举办的国家交响音乐会的门票在演出开始数天前就已经售罄。

近　symptom n. 病兆，症状；asymptomatic adj. 无征兆的

euphonious［ju:'fəʊnɪəs］

adj. 悦耳的

解　pleasing to the ear; sounding agreeable; harmonious

例　Many people believe that Italian and Spanish are the most euphonious languages. 许多人认为意大利语和西班牙语是最好听的语言。

microphone［'maɪkrəfəʊn］

n. 麦克风

解　a device for converting sound waves into electrical energy

例　She requested a cordless microphone for her lecture so she could walk around the audience. 她要求在演讲的时候使用无线麦克风，这样她就可以在听众面前走动。



Group 152: plac=peace “平静”

placate［plə'keɪt］

v. 抚慰，平息（愤怒）

解　to make someone or some creature less angry; soothe

例　Her husband bought her a gift and flowers to placate her anger. 妻子生气了，丈夫买了一件礼物和鲜花来安抚她。

同　placating adj. 安抚的

implacable［ɪm'plækəbəl］

adj. 难以抚慰的，难平息的；难以满足的

解　unable to be appeased; refusing to be reconciled

例　The new nation was constantly threatened by its implacable enemies. 由于敌人很难和解，这个新成立的国家一直处于其带来的威胁之中。

构　im < in (=not) + plac (=to soothe, please) + able

近　impeccable adj. 无缺点的；无瑕疵的

placid［'plæsɪd］

adj. 安静的，平和的

解　pleasantly calm or peaceful; quiet

例　The lake is placid now that the storm is over. 风暴过去后，湖水恢复了平静。

placebo［plə'si:bəʊ］

n. 安慰剂

解　harmless substance prescribed as a dummy pill

例　The effectiveness of the placebo confirmed some psychological factors involved in her disorder. 安慰剂对她有用，这证实了她的错乱行为与某些心理因素有关。

Lesson 46





音频



Group 153: place=place “放置；地方”

displace［dɪs'pleɪs］

v. ① 使移动 ② 取代

解　① to put out of the proper or accustomed place; to move ② to take the place of

例　The forest fire displaced hundreds of wild animals from their homes. 森林大火使数百个野生动物无家可归。

同　displaced adj. 替换的，转移的

misplace［ˌmɪs'pleɪs］

v. 错误放置（口语中也指忘记放在什么地方）

解　to put into a wrong place

例　He was late because he had misplaced his car keys and couldn't find them. 由于他忘了把车钥匙放在哪儿了，怎么也找不到，因此迟到了。

replace［rɪ'pleɪs］

v. ① 把…放回原处 ② 取代，代替

解　① to put back; put in place again ② to fill or take the place of

例　Johnny bought a new vase to replace the one he had broken while his parents were away on business. 父母出差的时候，约翰尼买了一个新的花瓶来替代被他打碎的那个。

commonplace［'kɒmənpleɪs］

adj. 平凡的，平常的

解　completely ordinary and unremarkable

例　It is commonplace to bring a bottle of wine to a dinner party with friends. 人们通常会带上一瓶酒去参加朋友的晚宴。



Group 154: port=carry “携带，运送”

port［pɔ:t］

n. 港口

解　a place (seaport or airport) where people and merchandise can enter or leave a country

例　New York was the most common port where Europeans immigrants arrived in America. 欧洲移民通常在纽约港登陆美国。

porter［'pɔ:tə(r)］

n. 搬运工

解　a person employed to carry loads or baggage

例　Please give your bags to the porter. 请把您的包给搬运工。

deport［dɪ'pɔ:t］

v. 驱逐出境

解　to expel from a country

例　Jack was deported because of his unlawful behavior. 杰克因其非法行为而被驱逐出境。

同　deportation n. 驱逐

构　de (=away) + port (=to carry)

import［ɪm'pɔ:t］

v. 进口

解　to bring in from abroad

例　The country imported food and goods from China and Japan. 这个国家从中国和日本进口食物和商品。





importune［ɪm'pɔ:tju:n］

v. 强求，不断请求

解　to beg persistently and urgently

例　He importuned her to marry him until she agreed. 他不断地请求她嫁给他，直到她同意才善罢甘休。

构　im < in (=in, into) + port (=to carry) + une

opportune［'ɒpətju:n; ˌɒpə't-］

adj. 凑巧的，恰好的；（指行动或事件）及时的，适宜的

解　suitable or at a time that is suitable or advantageous especially for a particular purpose

例　Janet stopped the car at an opportune place on the mountain to see the sunset. 珍妮特把车停在山上恰好可以看到日落的地方。

构　op < ob (=toward) + port (=to carry) + une

opportunity［ˌɒpə'tju:nəti］

n. 机会

解　a possibility due to a favorable combination of circumstances

例　 The country's economic reform will create opportunities as well as risks. 这个国家的经济改革在带来机遇的同时也会产生风险。



其他与“交通，运送”意义有关的词汇

fare n. 车船费，交通费；食物

vehicle n. 船只；交通工具；传播媒介

convey v. 运送

smuggle v. 走私，私运





Group 155: pos, posit=put, place “放置”

depose［dɪ'pəʊz］

v. 免职，废黜；宣誓作证

解　to force to leave (an office); to declare under oath

例　The military coup deposed the dictator from power. 军事政变使独裁者失去了权力。

同　deposition n. 免职；宣誓作证

构　de (=from, away) + pos (=to put) + e

depository［dɪ'pɒzɪtəri］

n. 仓库

解　a place where things can be deposited for safekeeping

例　The hotel depository stored the guests' valuables. 酒店的存放处寄存了客人的贵重物品。

dispose［dɪ'spəʊz］

v. 处理

解　to give, sell, or transfer to another; cast away

例　They disposed of the old truck at the landfill. 他们在垃圾填埋区处理了这台老旧的卡车。

同　disposal n. 处理，丢弃；disposable adj. 可任意处理的

disposed［dɪ'spəʊzd］

adj. 有…倾向的；有意，愿意

解　inclined

例　Since the president was unexpectedly busy, he was not disposed to meet his friends for dinner as he had planned. 总裁没想到自己会这么忙，所以他不打算按照计划去和朋友们吃饭了。

predisposition［ˌpri:dɪspə'zɪʃən］

n. 倾向，偏爱

解　tendency; inclination

例　He is a miserable person and has a predisposition to look on the dark side of things. 他是一个内心痛苦的人，总是倾向于看到事情的阴暗面。

expose［ɪk'spəʊz］

v. 曝光；暴露

解　to allow light to act on; to make visible or make known; to reveal

例　His back was badly burnt because he exposed it to the sun for too long. 由于暴露在阳光下的时间太长，他的背部被严重灼伤了。

同　exposure n. 暴露；曝光

exposition［ˌekspə'zɪʃən］

n. ① 说明，阐释 ② 博览会

解　① an interpretation of the meaning of sth. ② a collection of things for public display

例　The art exposition in New York displayed some of the world's finest works. 纽约举行的这场艺术展展出了一些世界顶级的作品。

构　ex (=out) + pos (=to put) + ition

oppose［ə'pəʊz］

v. 反对

解　to fight against sb. in a battle; to act against in an argument

例　Everyone but the founder of the company was opposed to selling the company during the period of economic hardship. 在经济不景气的时期，除了公司创办者，所有人都反对变卖公司。

同　opposing adj. 相反的；opposition n. 反对；opponent n. 对手，敌手

transpose［træn'spəʊz］

v. 交换位置

解　to reverse the order or position of

例　I transposed the number and mistakenly wrote 19 instead of 91. 我把数字的位置颠倒了，错把91写成了19。

juxtapose［'ʤʌkstəpəʊz］

v. 并排，并置

解　to place side by side

例　The two microorganisms were juxtaposed under the microscope so the students could compare and contrast them. 两个微生物被并排放在显微镜下，这样学生们就可以对它们进行比较、区分。

impose［ɪm'pəʊz］

v. ① 强加 ② 征（税）

解　① to put (a burden, tax, or punishment) on another or others by authority ② to establish or apply as compulsory; levy

例　President Bush was highly criticized for imposing new taxes after his election campaign. 在竞选活动之后，人们强烈谴责布什总统征收新税。

superimpose［ˌsu:pərɪm'pəʊz］

v. 加在上面，附加

解　to place on top of

例　The picture superimposed the picture of the Democrat on a donkey as a political joke. 这幅图片把民主党的照片叠合在一头驴上当做一个政治笑话。

repose［rɪ'pəʊz］

v. 躺着休息；安睡

解　to lie or sleep in a comfortable resting position

例　The cat reposed upon the cushion. 猫卧在垫子上休息。

构　re (=back) + pos (=to put) + e

Lesson 47





音频



Group 156: pre=before “…前面；预先”

precarious［prɪ'keərɪəs］

adj. ① 不稳定的 ② 危险的

解　① not firm or steady ② dangerously insecure

例　He was carefully walking up the precarious staircase of the old wooden house. 他小心翼翼地爬上了这个老旧木屋的危险的楼梯。

precedent［prɪ'si:dənt］

n. 先例，前例 adj. 领先的，居前的，优先的

解　n. an example that is used to justify similar occurrences at a later time adj. preceding in time, order, or significance

例　Without any precedent, there was no protocol for what action to take. 因为没有任何先例，所以也没有关于该采取什么行动的草案。

precipitous［prɪ'sɪpɪtəs］

adj. 陡峭的

解　extremely steep

例　Only the bravest hikers had traveled the precipitous path around the mountain. 只有最勇敢的徒步旅行者走过这座山周围的险峻小道。





premeditated［pri:'medɪteɪtɪd］

adj. 预谋的，事先计划的

解　characterized by deliberate purpose and some degree of planning

例　The judge determined that the crime was not a sudden act of violence; instead it was premeditated and planned. 法官认定这起犯罪不是一种突发的暴力行为，而是经过预谋与计划的。

premeditation［ˌpri:ˌmedɪ'teɪʃən］

n. 预谋，预先策划

解　planning or plotting in advance of acting

例　The lawyer had to prove premeditation before the jury would convict the murderer. 要想让陪审团裁定凶手有罪，律师必须先证明凶手是有预谋的。

近　meditation n. 沉思；meditative adj. 沉思的，冥想的；immediate adj. 马上的，立即的

premise［'premɪs］

n. 前提

解　statement made or implied as a basis of argument

例　The debater won the contest by pointing out that his opponent had no premise to his argument. 这名辩手通过指出他的对手的论点没有前提条件而赢得了比赛。

presume［prɪ'zju:m］

vt. ① 假定，推测 ② 擅自

解　① to take to be the case or to be true ② to venture without authority or permission; dare

例　The country's legal system presumed people were innocent until they were proven guilty. 这个国家的法律系统在人们被证明有罪之前会先假设其是清白的。

同　presumption n. 假定，推测；傲慢

构　pre (=before) + sum (=to take) + e

presumptuous［prɪ'zʌmptʃʊəs］

adj. 自大的，专横的，冒昧的

解　too bold or self-confident; assuming

例　She apologized for her presumptuous manner of speaking to the man once she realized he was the boss. 当她知道对方是老板之后，她为她傲慢的说话方式向他道了歉。

近　sumptuous adj. 奢侈的，华丽的；pompous adj. 浮夸的，夸大的；自大的；pomposity n. 华丽，夸耀



Group 157: press=press “挤压”

press［pres］

v. ① 熨平 ② 挤压 n. 挤压

解　v. ① to make smooth ② to push with steady force n. the act of applying pressure

例　Martha pressed the doorbell when she arrived at her friend's house. 到达朋友家之后，马莎按下了门铃。

pressure［'preʃə(r)］

n. 压力

解　the continued action of a weight or force; a state of trouble or strain

例　There was a great deal of pressure on the students to get the highest possible grade on the national examination. 为了在这次全国性的考试中尽可能获得高分，学生们承受着巨大的压力。

compress［kəm'pres］

v. 收缩；压缩

解　to press together or into a smaller space; to squeeze out; to squeeze

例　Compress your speech until only the relevant points remain. 压缩你的演讲，只保留相关的要点。

同　compressor n. 压缩机

构　com < con (=together) + press (=to press)

oppression［ə'preʃən］

n. 压迫

解　the act of subjugating by cruelty

例　The end of the country's civil war marked the end of the oppression of slaves. 这个国家内战的结束标志着奴隶被压迫时代的终结。

构　op < ob (=against, intensive) + press (=to press) + ion

repress［rɪ'pres］

v. ① 抑制 ② 镇压

解　① to keep under restraint or control ② to put down by force or intimidation

例　The authoritarian government repressed any signs of rebellion before one actually started. 在真正的造反开始之前，这个独裁政府就对任何造反的征兆进行了镇压。

同　repression n. 压制，镇压；irrepressible adj. 压抑不住的；unrepressed adj. 未受抑制或约束的

构　re (=back) + press (=to press)

suppress［sə'pres］

v. ① 抑制 ② 镇压

解　① to control and refrain from showing emotions ② to put down by force or authority

例　Men are taught to suppress their tears if they feel like crying. 男人总是被告诫在想哭的时候也要忍住眼泪。

depress［dɪ'pres］

vt. ① 使忧愁，沮丧 ② 使不景气，萧条

解　① make sad and without enthusiasm ② make less active

例　I was depressed by the bad news from home. 家里传来的坏消息使我心情低落。

同　depressed adj. 沮丧的；depression n. 沮丧，消沉；depressant n. 镇静剂

impress［ɪm'pres］

v. 打动，给予某人深刻印象

解　have a favourable effect on sb.

例　The interviewer was impressed by her credentials and attitude and hired her there on the spot. 面试官被她持有的证书和态度所打动，当场聘用了她。

同　impressed adj. 留下印象的；unimpressive adj. 给人印象不深的，不打动人的



其他与“挤压”意义有关的词汇

crumble v. 弄碎，压碎；崩毁

crushing n. 压碎

encapsulate v. 装入胶囊；压缩

pulverize v. 粉碎，压成细粉；彻底击败

ballast n. （船等）压舱物





Group 158: prim=first “第一”

primary［'praɪməri］

adj. ① 第一位的，主要的 ② 初步的，初级的

解　① first in importance; chief ② first in time or order; original; fundamental

例　Her primary motive in business was making money, not making friends. 他经商的首要动机是赚钱，而不是结交朋友。

primer［'praɪmə(r)］

n. 启蒙读物，启蒙书，识字课本

解　an introductory textbook

例　The schoolteacher passed out the primer to the children on their first day of school. 在开学的第一天，老师把识字课本分发给学生。

primitive［'prɪmɪtɪv］

adj. ① 原始的，上古的 ② 简单的

解　① of or relating to the earliest or original stage or state; primeval ② characterized by simplicity or crudity; unsophisticated

例　Primitive human beings lived in caves. 原始人生活在山洞里。





primordial［praɪ'mɔ:dɪəl］

adj. 最初的，原始的

解　in existence at or from the beginning; primeval

例　Left uncut by man, trees in the primordial forest grew to tremendous size. 这个原始森林里的树木没有被人们砍伐，都长成了参天大树。

Group 159: print=print “印于，打印”

printing［'prɪntɪŋ］

n. 印刷

解　reproduction by applying ink to paper as for publication

例　Benjamin Franklin began his career in the printing of newspapers. 本杰明·富兰克林的第一份工作是印刷报纸。

blueprint［'blu:prɪnt］

n. 蓝图

解　photographic print of plans or technical drawings, etc.

例　The architect presented her blueprints for the proposed museum to the executive board. 这位建筑师把她所制的关于这座计划建造的博物馆的蓝图提交给了执行委员会。

fingerprint［'fɪŋɡəprɪnt］

n. 指纹

解　a clue made by an impression of the ridges in the skin of a finger

例　The police dusted for fingerprints at the crime scene to find suspects. 为了找到犯罪嫌疑人，警察在犯罪现场提取了指纹。

imprint［ɪm'prɪnt］

v. 盖章，刻印

解　to stamp or mark by or as if by pressure

例　He imprinted a kiss on his grandmother's cheek. 他在祖母的脸颊上留下了一个吻。



Group 160: prob=try, test “测试，证明”

probity［'prəʊbɪti］

n. 刚直，正直，诚实

解　virtue or integrity tested and confirmed; honesty

例　People did not question him because of his reputation for probity. 由于他以正直闻名，人们并没有质疑他。

同　improbity v. 不正直，不诚实

reprobate［'reprəʊbeɪt］

n. 堕落者，道德败坏的人 adj. 堕落的

解　n. a person without moral scruples adj. marked by immorality; deviating from what is considered right or proper or good

例　I cannot understand why he has so many admirers if he is the reprobate you say he is. 如果他真如你所说是一个道德败坏的人，那么我就不理解为什么他有那么多崇拜者。

approbation［ˌæprə'beɪʃən］

n. ① 称赞 ② 批准，认可

解　① approval; praise ② official recognition or approval sanction

例　Popularity polls seem to be based on the mistaken idea that the basic task of a political leader is to win immediate approbation from the people. 民意测验似乎建立在这样一种错误的观念上，即认为一个政治领袖的基本任务就是从人民那里得到直接的认可。

构　ap < ad (=to) + prob (=to try, to test) + ation

opprobrium［ə'prəʊbrɪəm］

n. ① 恶名声 ② 诽谤

解　① a state of extreme dishonor ② the state of disgrace resulting from public abuse

例　He refused to defend himself against the slander and opprobrium hurled against him by the newspapers; he preferred to rely on his record. 他拒绝针对报纸上对他的诋毁和诽谤而为自己辩护，他更喜欢用事实说话。

构　op < ob (=against) + prob (=to test) + rium

同　opprobrious adj. 恶名声的；辱骂的



其他与“证明，证实”意义有关的词汇

authenticate v. 证明（某物）为真

corroborate v. 支持，证实；强化

substantiate v. 证实，确证

deposition n. 沉积；宣誓作证；免职

empirical adj. 经验的；实证的

perjure v. 作伪证，发假誓

perjury n. 伪证，假誓





Group 161: proper, propr=one's own “拥有”引申为“恰当的”

proper［'prɒpə(r)］

adj. 恰当的

解　marked by suitability or rightness or appropriateness

例　The prissy girl did everything in a very proper fashion. 这个谨小慎微的女孩所做的每件事都很得体。

同　improper adj. 不合适的

propriety［prə'praɪəti］

n. ① （常用作复）礼节，礼貌 ② 适当

解　① the usages and customs of polite society ② the quality of proper; appropriateness

例　Generally speaking, British society has a greater sense of proprieties than American society. 总体来说，英国社会比美国社会更注重礼节。

同　impropriety n. 不得体，不正当（的行为）

appropriate［ə'prəʊprieɪt］v. ① 拨款 ② 挪用，盗用［ə'prəʊpriət］adj. 合适的

解　v. ① to set apart for a specific use ② to take for oneself or for one's own use, esp. without permission adj. suitable for a particular person or place or condition, etc.

例　The judge decided on an appropriate sentence for the crime. 法官对这一罪行作出了适当的判决。

同　appropriately adv. 得体地；appropriateness n. 适当；appropriation n. 恰当；拨款，挪用公款



其他与“恰当的”意义有关的词汇

felicitous adj. （话语等）适当的，得体的

germane adj. 有密切关系的，贴切的

impertinence n. 不相关，不恰当；粗鲁

irrelevant adj. 不恰当的，不相关的；不重要的





Group 162: prov=test “测试，证明”

prove［pru:v］

v. 证明

解　to provide evidence for

例　Scientists have not released any information proving aliens have visited our planet. 科学家还没有发布过任何可以证明外星人曾造访过地球的消息。

近　proof n. 证据；disproof n. 反驳，反证；reproof n. 责备；waterproof adj. 防水的；foolproof adj. 万无一失的，错不了的；容易懂的

approval［ə'pru:vəl］

n. ① 批准 ② 赞同

解　① a message expressing a favorable opinion ② acceptance as satisfactory

例　Elected officials normally check ratings of their pubic approval in order to calculate their chances for reelection. 当选官员通常都会确认他们的公共支持率，从而计算出下次当选的几率。

disprove［ˌdɪs'pru:v］

v. 反驳，驳斥，证明…有误

解　to prove to be false or wrong

例　The new evidence was useless; it neither proved nor disproved anything. 这个新证据没有用，它既不能证明什么，也不能推翻什么。

disapprove［ˌdɪsə'pru:v］

v. 不赞成，不喜欢

解　to consider bad or wrong; refuse to approve

例　The board of directors disapproved of the merger proposal because of inequitable stipulations. 由于合同条款不公平，董事会没有批准合并计划。

同　disapproval n. 不同意

reprove［rɪ'pru:v］

v. 责骂，申斥

解　to express disapproval of; to censure

例　The student reproved herself for not getting a better grade on the test. 这名学生因为没有在考试中取得更好的成绩而责备自己。

构　re (=again) + prov (=to test) + e

improve［ɪm'pru:v］

v. 改进，提高

解　to make better in quality or more valuable

例　Economic reforms within the last few years have improved people's standard of living. 过去几年的经济改革已经提高了人民的生活水平。

同　improvement n. 改进，提高

Group 163: pur=pure “纯洁”

pure［pjʊə(r)］

adj. 纯的；纯净的

解　free of extraneous elements of any kind; not mixed

例　The statue of the businessman was made of pure iron. 这位商人的塑像是用纯铁铸造而成的。

purity［'pjʊərəti］

n. 纯净，纯度

解　the quality or state of being pure

例　The environmentalists tested the purity of the drinking water. 环保主义者检测了饮用水的纯净度。

同　impurity n. 杂质

purify［'pjʊərɪfaɪ］

v. 净化，提纯

解　to remove impurities from

例　Filters are used to purify water. 过滤器被用来净化水质。

同　purification n. 提纯，纯化

purist［'pjʊərɪst］

n. （语法、用字上）主张保存正统的人，力求纯化的人

解　a person who is very careful or too careful about purity in language

例　A purist dislikes slang and all expressions that are not formally correct. 纯粹主义者不喜欢俚语和一切在正式语言中不正确的表达。

purebred［'pjʊəbred］

adj. （动物）纯种的 n. 纯种的动物

解　adj. of pure breed or stock n. an animal descended from one breed with no mixture of other breeds

例　Purebred horses are much more expensive than mixed breeds. 纯种马比杂交马的价格昂贵得多。



Group 164: put=consider, reckon “认为，思考”

repute［rɪ'pju:t］

n. 名望，名声

解　the state of being held in high esteem and honor; fame

例　This is a district of bad repute because of the crime here. 这个地区因为犯罪活动而臭名昭著。

构　re (=again) + put (=to consider, to reckon) + e

reputation［ˌrepju'teɪʃən］

n. 名声，名誉

解　someone's or something's character in the opinion of others; name; repute

例　The founder considered the company's reputation to be more valuable than its profit. 这位创始人认为，公司的声誉比其利益更有价值。

disrepute［ˌdɪsrɪ'pju:t］

n. 坏名声

解　the state of being held in low esteem

例　Politicians are usually sensitive to anything that will bring disrepute to them when they are seeking reelection. 政客们在打算再次参加竞选时，通常会对败坏他们名誉的事情很敏感。





disreputable［dɪs'repjʊtəbəl］

adj. 品格不端的；名声不好的

解　lacking respectability in character, behavior or appearance

例　Eric was one of the most disreputable figures in the town because of his history of deceit and fraud. 埃里克由于其诈骗的前科而成为了这个镇上名声最不好的人之一。

构　dis (=not) + re (=again) + put (=to consider) + able

dispute［dɪ'spju:t］

n./v. 争论；异议

解　n. a verbal controversy; a debate v. to have a disagreement over something

例　Since the companies could not resolve the dispute themselves, it was taken to court. 由于公司间不能自行解决纠纷，于是交由法庭来解决。

近　deputy n. 副警长；代理人，代表

同　disputatious adj. 好争辩的



Group 165: quer, quir, quis=seek, search “寻求，询问”

query［'kwɪəri］

n. 质问，询问

解　an instance of questioning

例　The lecturer asked the audience to save their queries until he finished speaking. 演讲者要求听众在他讲完之后再提问。

acquire［ə'kwaɪə(r)］

v. 获得，得到

解　to come into the possession of something concrete or abstract

例　The tycoon acquired valuable assets from his many takeovers. 这个企业巨头从他的多项收购中获得了有价值的资产。

acquired［ə'kwaɪəd］

adj. 后天习得的

解　gotten through environmental forces

例　After studying for his Ph.D degree, he returned to his country to apply his newly- acquired skills to his profession. 取得博士学位后，他回到自己的祖国，把新掌握的技术应用到了自己的专业领域里。

acquisition［ˌækwɪ'zɪʃən］

n. 获得；获得物

解　the act of acquiring; anything gained or acquired

例　The company's many acquisitions practically gave it a monopoly in the market. 这家公司收购了许多公司之后，几乎可以垄断市场。

acquisitiveness［ə'kwɪzɪtɪvnəs］

n. 贪得无厌

解　strong desire to acquire and possess

例　The money-hungry businesswoman has always had a sense of acquisitiveness ever since she was a young girl. 当她还是个年轻的女孩的时候，这个视钱如命的女商人就有了一种获取利润的意识。

构　ac (=to) + quis (=to seek) + itive + ness

inquiry［ɪn'kwaɪəri］

n. 询问

解　a search for information, knowledge, or truth; question

例　Since her package did not arrive on time, she filed an inquiry with the post office. 由于她的包裹没有按时送到，她向邮局提交了查询申请。

同　inquire v. 询问

构　in (=into) + quir (=to search) + y

inquisition［ˌɪnkwɪ'zɪʃən］

n. 调查

解　official inquiry

例　The post office's inquisition of the lost package determined that it had been sent to another country by accident. 通过调查，邮局确定丢失的包裹已被意外送到了另一个国家。

inquisitive［ɪn'kwɪzɪtɪv］

adj. 过分好问的，好奇的

解　given to questioning, especially out of curiosity

例　Children are known to have inquisitive minds that are like sponges to new information. 众所周知，孩子们有着好奇的头脑，就像海绵一样，不断吸收新的知识。

构　in (=into) + quis (=to ask, to seek) + itive

Lesson 50





音频



Group 166: quest, quer=seek, search “寻求，询问”

questionable［'kwestʃənəbəl］

adj. 可疑的

解　not certain

例　The embassy refused to give him a visa because his intentions to study there were questionable. 该国大使馆拒绝给他签证，因为他想去那个国家学习的意图比较可疑。

questionnaire［ˌkwestʃə'neə(r)］

n. 调查表，问卷

解　a form containing a set of questions, submitted to people to gain statistical information

例　The students handed out questionnaires on the street in order to get a random pooling of people for their survey on social issues. 学生们在街上发放调查问卷，以便得到随机的人群来进行关于社会问题的调查。

querulous［'kwerʊləs］

adj. 抱怨的，多牢骚的

解　habitually complaining

例　His classmates were repelled by his querulous and complaining statements. 他总是抱怨和发牢骚，他的同学都感到厌烦。





request［rɪ'kwest］

n./v. 要求，请求

解　n. the act of asking v. to ask for; to ask as a favor

例　She requested a loan from the bank. 她向银行申请了贷款。

conquest［'kɒŋkwest］

n. 征服

解　the act of conquering

例　The famous Mongolian warrior's military campaign had a history of countless conquests. 这个著名的蒙古勇士战功显赫，征服的地方数不胜数。

近　conquer v. 征服

构　con (=together) + quest (=to seek)



Group 167: quiet, quie=still “静，静止”

quietude［'kwaɪətju:d］

n. 平静，寂静

解　a state of peace and quiet

例　During the weekend people from the city like to escape to the quietude of the country to relax. 在周末，城市里的人们喜欢逃离到寂静的乡村去放松身心。

近　platitude n. 陈词滥调；plenitude n. 丰富，大量；完全；solicitude n. 热心，关心

disquiet［dɪs'kwaɪət］

v./n. 担心，焦虑

解　v. to make uneasy or anxious; to disturb n. uneasy feelings; anxiety

例　Although she had done nothing wrong, the appearance of the police disquieted her. 尽管她没做过什么坏事，但警察的出现还是让她感到不安。

acquiesce［ˌækwɪ'es］

v. 勉强同意，默许

解　to give consent silently

例　The bank manager acquiesced to the robbers so that no one would get hurt. 银行经理答应了抢劫者的要求，这样其他人就不会受到伤害。

同　acquiescence n. 默许

构　ac (=to) + quie (=to be quiet) + sce



其他与“静止”意义有关的词汇

static adj. 静态的；呆板的

stationary adj. 静止的，不动的

dormancy n. 休眠；静止

dormant adj. 冬眠的；静止的

hush n. 肃静，安静

pacific adj. 和平的；宁静的

pastoral adj. 田园生活的，乡村的；宁静的

serene adj. 宁静的

serenity n. 宁静，安宁

tranquil adj. 宁静的，安静的

tranquility n. 宁静

placid adj. 安静的，平和的

restive adj. 不安静的，不安宁的





Group 168: secut, sequ=follow “跟随”

persecute［'pɜ:sɪkju:t］

v. ① 迫害 ② 不断困扰

解　① to cause to suffer ② to annoy persistently; bother

例　Thousands of Jews were persecuted during the era of the European Inquisition. 在欧洲宗教法庭时期，数以千计的犹太教徒被迫害。

近　execute v. 实行，完成；处决；execution n. 实施；executive n. 经理；行政人员；executor n. 遗嘱执行人

构　per (=through, throughout) + secut (=to follow) + e

prosecute［'prɒsɪkju:t］

v. 告发，检举

解　to bring a criminal action against (in a trial); to sue

例　The district attorney plans to prosecute her for burglary. 地方检察官准备以入室行窃罪起诉她。

同　prosecution n. 起诉，控告

构　pro (=before) + secut (=to follow) + e

sequential［sɪ'kwenʃəl］

adj. 连续的，一连串的

解　in regular succession without gaps

例　Casino players often organize their cards in sequential order. 人们玩卡西诺纸牌游戏时通常会把手中的牌按顺序排列起来。

consequence［'kɒnsɪkwəns］

n. ① 结果 ② 重要的地位

解　① a result or effect ② importance

例　The consequence of the fall was a broken leg. 这次跌倒的后果是把腿摔断了。

构　con (=with) + sequ (=to follow) + ence

consequential［ˌkɒnsɪ'kwenʃəl］

adj. 重要的；产生后果的

解　having important issues or results

例　Ben Franklin was a consequential figure in the American history. 本·富兰克林是美国历史上的一个重要的人物。

构　con (=with) + sequ (=to follow) + ential



Group 169: spir=breathe “呼吸”

spirit［'spɪrɪt］

n. 精神

解　the immaterial part of human beings; soul

例　Some people believe that their spirit lives on even after their body dies. 有些人认为，他们死后灵魂会继续存在。

同　spiral n. 螺旋状旋转；螺旋，螺线

spirited［'spɪrɪtɪd］

adj. 有精神的，生气勃勃的，活泼的

解　full of energy and spirit; lively

例　We played a highly spirited game against the cross-town rivals. 我们与同城的对手打了一场激烈的比赛。

dispirited［dɪ'spɪrɪtɪd］

adj. 垂头丧气的

解　lacking in spirit; depressed

例　The coach used all the tricks at his command to buoy up the enthusiasm of his team, which had become dispirited at the loss of the star player. 由于明星队员的流失，球队士气不振，教练想尽各种办法来调动球员们的热情。

spiritual［'spɪrɪtʃuəl］

adj. 精神的

解　relating to the spirit or sacred matters

例　Martin Luther King was a spiritual and political leader for African Americans. 对于非裔美国人而言，马丁·路德·金是一位精神领袖和政治领袖。

aspirant［ə'spaɪərənt］

n. 有抱负者，有野心者

解　seeker after position or status

例　These times of opportunity have invigorated a generation of aspirants. 这个充满机遇的时代使这一代人深受鼓舞、胸怀抱负。

aspiration［ˌæspə'reɪʃən］

n. 渴望，热望

解　noble ambition

例　Her aspiration to become a medical doctor was realized after many years of hard work. 通过多年的努力，她想成为医生的愿望终于实现了。

构　a < ad (=to, intensive) + spir (=to breathe) + ation



其他与“呼吸”意义有关的词汇

respiration n. 呼吸；呼吸作用

inhale v. 吸气

exhale v. 呼出（气）
